services.name: Baby Basics Wolverhampton
services.description:
Our centre is a low key operation working out of Holy Trinity Church Heath Town, Wolverhampton, mainly supporting vulnerable mums from the nearby Heath Town Housing estate in conjunction with the Hope Community Project - our small team of volunteers meet as and when required to pack moses baskets, to provide a lovely gift to an expectant or new mum in our community

Beneficiaries are to be referred in to this service by a supporting professional such as a midwife, or by a charity via email

services.name: Groundwork West Midlands
services.description:
Money and Me is a free service for Wolverhampton residents. We offer 1:1 sessions to build financial confidence, improve budgeting skills, and access grants. We also signpost to services that support with debt and finding work. Sessions can be one-off or ongoing, depending on your needs.

Hamza.Javaid@groundwork.org.uk 
0782 197 5847

Money and Me have a Facebook Page which details when drop in sessions are available

services.name: The Big Venture Centre Ltd
services.description:
Warm Space at the Big Venture Centre

Are you worried about putting the heating on? Why not spend some time at the Big Venture Centre?

We offer a free lunch, warm drinks, and a chance to meet others.
There is free WIFI, newspapers to read, you can watch TV, read a book, or get involved in various activites.

services.name: The Big Venture Centre Ltd
services.description:
Community Shop @ The Big Venture Centre
People join as members of our community shop for GBP 5 for the year. 
Members will then automatically receive a free bag of shopping and the opportunity to purchase more food and other essential items such as toiletries at a reduced cost. 

Just come along to sign up, we are open to everyone and anyone who is based in Wolverhampton.

services.name: Secret Angels CIC
services.description: Secret Angels CIC offer a foodbank service each Tuesday morning from 10.30am - 12.30pm. For self-referrals (two forms of I.D required).

services.name: HOPE INTO ACTION BLACK COUNTRY AREAS
services.description:
On receiving a referral form we meet the person to discuss their needs and explain / explore how HIA can help them. We never guarantee that someone has place if we have voids. An assessment is always necessary first.
We then meet again, or same day / time as above do a risk assessment which gives us an understanding of the risk they may or may not pose. We have a scoring mechanism. The support HIA gives is managed by our Empowerment Workers, who also manage the church volunteers that support the tenants. These volunteers are called a friend with a purpose!
A strength and needs based assessment is done that recognises the strength base of the tenant, so we can work with them in the best way possible bring out the best in them, working to their skills and abilities, this is often working with support from other agencies.
We have one refugee house and one room / place for a destitute asylum which is filled at present. We work with the Hope project to financially support a Destitute asylum until his case is heard

services.name: Embrace Outreach
services.description:
We are a food bank service dedicated to meet the needs of families with children with SEND and Adults with disability on low income. 
Our service is not exclusive to these groups, others are welcome. 
To qualify you must be able to provide proof of need .eg., EHCP, benefit statements, low-income verification. 
Referral needed emergency food parcels can be provided without a referral

services.name: Hope Community Project
services.description:
Breaking Bread Food Pantry 
Our pantry is open to all. 
We ask for a joining fee of GBP 5 for one year's membership and then each visit, the member pays GBP 5. 
Most weeks, clients walk away with around of GBP 10-15 worth of food including fresh fruit and vegetables. 
We would never turn anyone away if they can't afford their contribution.
Fresh fruit, dairy, cereals, tinned goods etc.
Please remember to bring a bag!

services.name: Hope Community Project
services.description:
Stay and Play @ Hope Project
Open to all parents and carers with children under 5 who live in WV10 postcode area.

Free fruit and veg bag each week for each family who attend. 

We also distribute the "Healthy Start" pack
If you’re more than 10 weeks pregnant or have a child under 4, you may be entitled to get this help to buy healthy food and milk.

services.name: Hope Community Project
services.description:
ESOL classes at Hope Community

In partnership with Wolverhampton Adult Education Service

If English is not your first language and you would like to improve your skills, then come along and learn with us.

One class is for beginners and then one class is for intermediate learners/

services.name: Hope Community Project
services.description:
Come along to our centre on Fridays between 12pm and 1pm for FREE homemade and healthy vegetarian meal - you can eat in or take away. 
You can also bring along your handheld devices and charge them too! 
Everyone is welcome.

We update our facebook page with the latest menu

services.name: Hope Community Project
services.description: Hope Community Project Wolverhampton have a clothing bank available for anyone who needs it. Please get in touch and the staff will arrange for you to visit and see what items are available.

services.name: Every Family Counts
services.description:
Our Food Bank is open every Wednesday and Thursday at Low Hill Nursery School, Low Hill.

Please call us on 01902 558124 between 9 and 11am on those days ONLY and we will help you with what we can.

We are able to offer one household two parcels in a five week period.

Our larder is dependent on the donations we receive but we try to offer a range of products as well as non-perishable foods.

Given the demand for food banks, we can only support families in genuine need from the Wolverhampton area. If you are outside this area, we will try to signpost you.

services.name: Hub for Grub
services.description:
Hub For Grub @ St Alban's Church Community Kitchen
Hub for Grub is a social enterprise. We highlight food waste and save wonky produce from landfill, cooking and serving beautiful meals for everyone in the community.

Come along and takeaway healthy wholesome food.

Pay as you feel. It is for you, your family, your neighbour, for anyone.

services.name: Ashmore Park Foodbank
services.description:
Ashmore Park Foodbank provides emergency food for people living in the WV11 (Wednesfield and Ashmore Park) area who are experiencing a temporary financial crisis. 

The first time you come, we will discuss your situation and give you a voucher entitling you to a parcel that day and for a number of future weekly visits to give you time to address the underlying problem. 

Where appropriate, we will also signpost you to other relevant support services. 

Please bring ID, evidence of address and other documentation that will help us understand your situation

services.name: Ashmore Park Foodbank
services.description:
Ashmore Park Foodbank provides emergency toiletries for people living in the WV11 (Wednesfield and Ashmore Park) area who are experiencing a temporary financial crisis. 

The first time you come, we will discuss your situation and give you a voucher entitling you to a parcel that day and for a number of future weekly visits to give you time to address the underlying problem. 

Where appropriate, we will also signpost you to other relevant support services. 

Please bring ID, evidence of address and other documentation that will help us understand your situation

services.name: Ashmore Park Foodbank
services.description:
Ashmore Park Foodbank provides emergency baby items for people living in the WV11 (Wednesfield and Ashmore Park) area who are experiencing a temporary financial crisis. 

The first time you come, we will discuss your situation and give you a voucher entitling you to a parcel that day and for a number of future weekly visits to give you time to address the underlying problem. 

Where appropriate, we will also signpost you to other relevant support services. 

Please bring ID, evidence of address and other documentation that will help us understand your situation

services.name: YMCA - Black Country Group
services.description:
YMCA Wolverhampton offers accommodation to 18-34 year olds. 

Contact us using our referral form

Or phone 01902450637

Our Y-Living accommodation is for people who economically active / working. To find out more contact 01902 371 550

services.name: YMCA - Cannock Road
services.description: Supported accommodation for young people aged 18-35

services.name: The Hub at Ashmore Park
services.description:
Warm Spaces are a network of spaces across the city that can provide warmth and shelter to families and communities who need it. This is part of the council’s cost of living support initiative to support people through the cost-of-living crisis. 

The council has a shuttle service to take citizens to and from a Warm Space venue if transport is a barrier to be able to access the warm space. Citizens can book a space on the shuttle by visiting Warm Spaces Shuttle Service. If they do not have access to the internet or anyone to assist them with booking online, they can either call their Carer Support/Social Worker/Community Team for help with booking, or they can call Customer Services on 01902 290241 option 0 

A Warm Space at the Hub at Ashmore Park will be open all week at various times apart from Wednesdays and Sundays 

Hot drinks and Wifi will be available

services.name: The Well - Wolverhampton
services.description:
We provide emergency food/toiletries/baby items for people experiencing a temporary financial crisis. This extends to 5 parcels in a 6 month period.

Each parcel contains 3 days of nutritionally balanced tinned and dried food for each person in the household, plus toiletries and baby items.

The aim of The Well is to support those in crisis whilst long term support is put in place, rather than create a cycle of dependency.

We rely on the agencies who partner with us to assess the need for emergency food.

We require the person/family’s main details to enable us to respond.

All parcels are delivered either to the person’s address or your office for collection.

We do not take referrals direct from the public, as we believe in working together with you as an agency/church.

All referrals are taken by phone (Tel: 01902 256523) 
Our referral line is open Tues - Friday from 9.30am. 
We are a daily limit on referrals after which the referral line is closed until the next working day.

We are unable to give out food to the public from our warehouse under any circumstances. All food is delivered - this is part of our support to the person/family in need.

Agencies can collect parcels on behalf of the person in need for direct delivery by prior arrangement

services.name: The Well - Wolverhampton
services.description:
The Well provides emergency food/toiletries/baby items for people experiencing a temporary financial crisis. This extends to 5 parcels in a 6 month period (each parcel contains 3 days of food).

If you are in need then it’s important that you get advice and help regarding your crisis or financial situation. If you already receive input from a local support agency/worker, then please speak to them about making a referral to us. We work with over 100 local support agencies.

*We do not take referrals direct from the public, as we believe in working together with the support agencies.

We do not give out food from our warehouse under any circumstances. All food is delivered - this is part of our support to you.

MAIN POINTS FOR REFERRAL AGENCIES: 
All referrals are taken by phone (Tel: 01902 256523) Our referral line is open Tues - Friday from 9.30am. We are a daily limit on referrals after which the referral line is closed until the next working day.

If you have just heard about The Well & wish to partner with us, please contact our office before making your first referral so that we can take the details of your organisation and answer any queries you may have regarding our service

services.name: Rethink Mental Illness
services.description: Rethink Mental Illness have a wellbeing hub located next to the entrance to Wolverhampton train station. Anyone can come drop in to speak to members of the team or their partner organisations if they need help. As it offers one-to-one mental health support, information, and signposting to local services, organisations, community-based projects, and groups.

services.name: Al-Anon family groups
services.description:
Al-Anon Family Groups meeting is about helping you to find solace with and support from others who have been affected by their relationship with a drinker.
Meeting day: Tuesday
Meeting time: 19:30
Accessibility: Disabled access

All those affected by someone else's drinking are welcome to all meetings, please just be aware that the additional meetings listed below may also be attended by professionals eg medical, educational or others interested in how Al-Anon works.
Helpline is available every day of the year from 10am to 10pm. 0800 0086 811

services.name: Alternative Giving Campaign - Wolverhampton
services.description: For more information on grants and funding visit website

services.name: Good Shepherd Wolverhampton
services.description:
Street Homeless Breakfast Engagement Sessions 
Hot Breakfast is served three mornings a week for individuals who are sleeping rough on the streets of Wolverhampton. During this time there is an opportunity for attendees to have one to one advice around housing and to access shower and laundry facilities.

services.name: Good Shepherd Wolverhampton
services.description:
The Good Shepherd provides a hot meal on Mondays and Fridays between 12 noon and 2pm.

All our food service is provided at the Centre on Waterloo Road and we are unable to deliver.

services.name: Good Shepherd Wolverhampton
services.description: The Good Shepherd offers support for people sleeping rough in Wolverhampton, including breakfast, showers, laundry, clothing, and a safe postal address. Drop-in sessions run three times a week. You can speak to the support team, get one-to-one help, and be linked with a keyworker to help you find housing, training, or other support.

services.name: Good Shepherd Wolverhampton
services.description:
COMMUNITY FOOD PANTRY

Good Shepherd’s Family Pantry offers a weekly shopping experience for Families. Service users visit the pantry and select their own food, meaning they can choose items they know they’ll use. This reduces food waste and recreates the ethos of a shop or supermarket and reduces the perceived stigma of accessing a food bank.

A referral is required to access this service, please contact us for more information.

services.name: YMCA - City Gateway [Y Living Accomodation]
services.description: 2 and 3 bed shared clusters for 18-35 year olds

services.name: Homes in the City - Wolverhampton
services.description:
Homes in the City is Wolverhampton’s official housing lettings service. It advertises available homes for rent from the City of Wolverhampton Council and local housing associations. To apply, you need to register online here and meet the eligibility criteria which can be found on the website . Once registered, you can bid for properties that suit your needs.

If you are homeless contact Housing Options on 01902 556789 (option 2)

services.name: Homes in the City
services.description: The Bidding Portal for Wolverhampton Council Housing

services.name: St Giles Trust
services.description: Support for young women is at the forefront of the Expect Respect programme, which provides intensive, tailored support to girls and young women aged 11 to 18 who have been affected by exploitation, violence, and abuse. With a focus on Wolverhampton, the service helps individuals escape harmful situations and rebuild their lives.

services.name: Wolverhampton Homes
services.description:
Young people
Our Young Persons team provides housing support for young people aged 16 to 25. This includes specialist support for young people leaving care.

If you know a young person who may need support, please email us.
YoungPersons.Team@wolverhamptonhomes.org.uk

More details on the Wolverhampton Homes Website

services.name: Wolverhampton Homes
services.description:
Help with finding work, training, or volunteering in Wolverhampton. Employment Coaches offer one-to-one support, career advice, and a personalised plan to help you reach your goals.

Contact: leap@wolverhamptonhomes.org.uk

Pippa - 07717 732982

Kelly - 07773 187968

services.name: Wolverhampton Homes
services.description:
We can help you keep your home, explore other housing options, give you advice on the council's statutory homelessness duty, and help you to access the rent deposit scheme.
You can contact us via:
Phone 01902 556789 
Text message 60066 (start your text WHomes followed by a space)
If you do have an emergency repair outside of office hours please ring 01902 552999

services.name: Wolverhampton Homes
services.description: Support with managing rent, debt, benefits, and household bills. The team can help with budgeting, finding grants, dealing with loan sharks, and getting affordable furniture or better deals on energy.

services.name: Wolverhampton City Council - Homelessness Service
services.description:
Housing Options Service

Support with understanding your housing options and rights.

If you are worried about someone you’ve seen sleeping rough in Wolverhampton, you can let the council know by 

1) contacting the P3 outreach team on 01902 296541 during the daytime Mon- Friday or 0800 107 6753 at any other time.

2) or use StreetLink to report it. 

If you have recently become homeless, or are at risk of homelessness, please contact the Housing Options team on 01902 556789 - option 2. If it is out of office hours, please call 01902 552999. If you are looking for a home, then it is option 3

services.name: Wolverhampton Homes
services.description: Support with managing rent, debt, benefits, and household bills. The team can help with budgeting, finding grants, dealing with loan sharks, and getting affordable furniture or better deals on energy.

services.name: Wolverhampton City Council - Homelessness Service
services.description:
The Young Persons Team provides support for young people 16-25. This includes specialist support and accommodation designed for young people aged 16 and 17 who find themselves homeless or at risk of homelessness.

The Young Persons Team also manage the Wolverhampton Young Persons Accommodation Forum (WYPAF). Applications for accommodation and support from WYPAF should be sent to the Young Persons Team.
youngpersonsteam@wolverhampton.gov.uk

For more information please visit the council's website

services.name: Stop Loan Sharks
services.description:
Stop Loan Sharks - Wolverhampton
Support for anyone affected by illegal money lending.
Access: Call 0300 555 2222 or visit www.stoploansharks.co.uk
Available: Nationwide, including Wolverhampton

services.name: Dogs Trust Hope Project
services.description: Free vet care for people experiencing homelessness with dogs. Available through partner vets in Wolverhampton.

services.name: Wolverhampton Homes
services.description: Wolverhampton Homes are an Arms Length Management Organisation and are responsible for managing most of the council homes in Wolverhampton.

services.description: SVP in Wolverhampton provides practical support for people in need and experiencing poverty in all its forms. If you are require help and need one of the items listed, please reach out by emailing request@svp.org.uk

services.description: SVP offers companionship and support to alleviate loneliness.

services.name: Wolverhampton Violence Reduction Service [Catch22]
services.description: The Wolverhampton Violence Reduction Service supports young people aged 18-30 who are gang-involved, at risk of exploitation, or have served time for violent offences. Support includes weekly one-to-one sessions in safe locations, help with housing, mental health, family support, and employment. The service is trauma-informed and aims to help individuals leave violence and crime behind.

services.name: Hope Into Action - Bushbury
services.description: Male only Accommodation in Wolverhampton

services.name: Relate Birmingham and Black Country
services.description:
Counselling Services offered in Wolverhampton
Relationship Counselling for couples
Family Counselling
Counselling for Individuals
Psychosexual Therapy

For further information about the above counselling services offered via our Wolverhampton office, please visit our website https://relatebirmingham.co.uk/ 
You can also find details of whether you are eligible to be referred in for a free counselling sessions, or have the counselling sessions subsidised.

You can also find details of whether you are eligible to be referred in for a free counselling sessions, or have the counselling sessions subsidised.

services.name: Gloucester Street Community Centre
The Refugee and Migrant Centre West Midlands [RMC]
services.description: RMC offers free English classes for asylum seekers and people who are unemployed or not working. Classes range from conversation groups to Entry 3 level and run on a rolling basis. Staff also support learners in progressing to accredited college courses when ready. For help with joining a class, email Steven at Steven@rmcentre.org.uk

services.name: The Refugee and Migrant Centre West Midlands [RMC]
services.description: RMC offers tailored support to help people achieve their personal goals through skills development, learning opportunities, and gaining experience. They can help with CVs, careers advice, digital skills, and access to education for adults and children. If you need support, you can ask for Jennifer at the Wolverhampton centre or email her directly at JenniferDinham@rmcentre.org.uk.

services.name: The Refugee and Migrant Centre West Midlands [RMC]
services.description:
The Refugee & Migrant Centre’s Boosting Advice Project supports refugees and migrants aged 65 and over living in Wolverhampton and Walsall to maximise their income and live independently. 

The team provides free, regulated immigration advice, help with benefit checks and applications, access to emergency grants, and practical cost-saving guidance such as energy advice, NHS cost-reduction schemes, and travel concessions. 

Support is available in over 50 languages, ensuring everyone can receive clear, trusted advice. 

Drop-in sessions run Monday, Tuesday, Thursday, and Friday from 9 am-1 pm at RMC’s Wolverhampton and Walsall offices.

services.name: The Refugee and Migrant Centre West Midlands [RMC]
services.description: RMC provides practical support to help clients access the healthcare they need. A health caseworker is based at each office, and in Wolverhampton, a resident community psychiatric nurse is available to support with mental health needs. Staff can help arrange GP or dentist appointments, navigate the NHS, and resolve more complex health access issues. For support, you can drop in or speak to a team member.

services.name: The Refugee and Migrant Centre West Midlands [RMC]
services.description: RMC provides advice in multiple languages to help people understand what financial support they’re entitled to. Whether you're working, unemployed, disabled, a parent, or an older person, RMC can support you in applying for the right benefits, accessing grants, and dealing with benefit-related issues.

services.name: The Refugee and Migrant Centre West Midlands [RMC]
services.description: RMC supports vulnerable clients facing housing issues, homelessness, or destitution. Advisors can help you understand your housing options, apply for emergency or supported housing, and access essential items like food and funds. If you’re in urgent need, drop in to the Wolverhampton centre for advice and support.

services.name: The Refugee and Migrant Centre West Midlands [RMC]
services.description:
RMC provides free, regulated immigration advice and representation to migrants, asylum seekers, and refugees. Their team includes 40 OISC-accredited advisors, able to support cases up to Level 3, including representation at the First-tier and Upper Tribunal. They help people navigate complex immigration rules and secure the right to remain for themselves and their families.

NB They do not assist with passport applications or visas

services.name: The Refugee and Migrant Centre West Midlands [RMC]
services.description:
The Refugee and Migrant Centre (RMC) offers free, confidential support to asylum seekers, refugees, and migrants. You can attend their open drop-in service on Monday, Tuesday, Thursday, and Friday mornings between 9am-1pm. Appointments are given on a first-come, first-served basis, but emergencies are prioritised.

Or otherwise phone 0800 0663 444

services.name: The Refugee and Migrant Centre West Midlands [RMC]
services.description:
The Refugee and Migrant Centre (RMC) offers free, confidential support to asylum seekers, refugees, and migrants. You can attend their open drop-in service on Monday, Tuesday, Thursday, and Friday mornings between 9am-1pm. Appointments are given on a first-come, first-served basis, but emergencies are prioritised.

Or otherwise phone 0800 0663 444

services.name: Momma Claire Bear Foodbank
services.description:
Momma Claire Bear Foodbank can provide those in need with food parcels.
Get in touch if you need help.
You can also join the facebook group and request support there.

services.name: The West Midlands Multibank
services.description:
Distribution of free essential goods to families in need through partner organisations

Organisations must register via westmidlandsmultibank@bvsc.org in order to be eligible to collect items for their beneficiaries

services.name: Access to Business
services.description:
Access to Business run a project called Bridges

Our award-winning BRIDGES project continues to go from strength to strength and has supported a large number of people to become their own boss and become self-employed, progress into employment or train for a career. The success achieved in our initial three year project from 2016 to 2019 led to BRIDGES being awarded a further three year extension

Eligibility Criteria
MUST be 25 years or older 
To become on of our clients and benefit from our services you MUST reach our age criteria
Recipient of Income Based Benefit 
JSA, ESA, Income Support or Universal Credit (working tax credits, child tax credits DO NOT APPLY)
Have Significant Barriers 
Disabilities, Convictions, Lone Parent, Lack Basic Skills, Family Carer, Debt issues & Worries
In NO Paid Work 
Cannot be involved in ANY paid work of ANY kind, including self-employment - (even if they are not registered yet as self-employed).

services.name: Black Country Womens Aid
services.description: Support for people affected by domestic abuse, sexual violence, stalking, or exploitation. Services include help for women and girls facing stalking, counselling for trauma, and support for victims of modern slavery. They also work with children and young people who have experienced abuse. Based in Wolverhampton. Call if it’s safe, or visit the website for more information - phone -0121 553 0090

Organisations must register via westmidlandsmultibank@bvsc.org in order to be eligible to collect items for their beneficiaries

services.name: The Haven - Wolverhampton
services.description:
Modern slavery includes being forced to work, abused, or trafficked against your will. It can happen in many ways, including sexual exploitation, forced labour, or being made to commit crimes.

If you need help or are worried about someone else, call our 24-hour confidential helpline: 08000 194 400.

services.name: The Haven - Wolverhampton
services.description: The Haven offers specialist support for women and girls affected by sexual abuse or exploitation, including child sexual exploitation. This includes counselling, therapies for children, court support, and help from qualified ISVAs and ChISVAs. Women-only support groups and safe spaces are available. They also provide safety planning, domestic abuse training, and safe accommodation.

services.name: The Haven - Wolverhampton
services.description: The Haven offers safe emergency accommodation for women fleeing domestic abuse. Some spaces are shared but include private bedrooms, with staff on hand for one-to-one emotional and practical support. The service includes help with housing options, benefits, and moving into safe, long-term housing. Support also covers employment advice and connecting with other services.

services.name: The Haven - Wolverhampton
services.description:
If you’re feeling unsafe at home, or someone is hurting, threatening, or controlling you - support is available.

Call our 24-hour confidential helpline: 08000 194 400.

We’re here any time. Calls are private. If someone’s in danger, we may need to act to help keep them safe.

services.name: The Haven - Wolverhampton
services.description: The Haven supports women who have experienced or are at risk of forced marriage. This includes emotional support and safety planning in a confidential and non-judgemental space. Forced marriage is illegal in the UK and help is available.

services.name: The Haven - Wolverhampton
services.description:
If you or someone you know is at risk of Female Genital Mutilation (FGM), or needs support after experiencing it, help is available.

Call our 24-hour confidential helpline: 08000 194 400.

We’re here any time. Calls are private, but we may need to act if someone is in immediate danger.

services.name: Citizens Advice Dudley and Wolverhampton
services.description:
The Housing Advice Service provides free, specialist legal advice and representation to people facing housing issues in Dudley, Wolverhampton, and Sandwell. The team includes housing solicitors and caseworkers who support clients in court, including possession and review hearings. If you’ve received a hearing notice, a notice seeking possession, or are facing eviction, get in touch straight away. Legal Aid cases are also supported where eligible.

Telephone 01902 932170 

Email - referral.support@dudleycabx.org

services.name: Citizens Advice Dudley and Wolverhampton
services.description:
If you're worried about debt or managing money, start by checking the helpful resources on the Citizens Advice Website 

Specialist Debt Advice Service mobile 07799 070595 text or ring and leave your name and contact number for someone to get back to you (within 48 hours)

services.name: Citizens Advice Dudley and Wolverhampton
services.description:
The Wolverhampton Information Hub at 68 Victoria Street is a drop-in space where you can get help finding information online. It’s open Tuesday to Thursday from 9:00am to 3:00pm (last entry 2:30pm). No appointment is needed - support is given on a first-come, first-served basis.

This is for general advice only. To receive tailored advice click here Accessing Our Services

services.name: Citizens Advice Dudley and Wolverhampton
services.description: Citizens Advice Dudley and Wolverhampton offers free Level 1 immigration advice. This includes simple queries like checking if you're a British citizen or if your status allows you to work, and help with straightforward applications to stay in the UK, change visa conditions, or request an administrative review. For more complex cases, they will signpost you to a specialist, such as The Refugee and Migrant Centre (RMC) which provides free casework, advice and guidance on immigration issues for those living across the Black Country.

services.name: Jobchange
services.description:
The Jobchange Wolverhampton would love to help and support you around your employment opportunities and how to improve your chances at securing a job.
In addition to a variety of training opportunities, Jobchange can help you refine your CV. 

"We will always ask about your CV first, we will guide you through the CV and help you to complete it. If you are not the best on a computer we will do it for you and suggest an IT course that will make you more independent. Creating a CV is a free service Jobchange offer."

I have a job, can I still get help 
Yes you can, as long as you are over 18 we can help you for FREE

How long will my appointment last? 
Your appointment will last 45 minutes and if you need to come back for more time we will book you in again 

Can i just walk in? 
Every Wednesday we do walk in sessions, so if you are a new customer come along to Walk In Wednesday 8:30am until 15:00pm. Or you can call and book a time that is convenient for you.

services.name: Jobchange
services.description:
Jobchange Wolverhampton regularly hold classes and courses from which you can gain a qualification. 
Courses are free to access, with a nominal fee for the certificate at the end of the course. 
Current courses in Wolverhampton can be found on their website here

There are also online courses you can access, these are listed also listed on the website

services.name: Jobchange
services.description:
Jobchange Wolverhampton regularly hold classes and courses from which you can gain a qualification. 
Courses are free to access, with a nominal fee for the certificate at the end of the course. 
Current courses in Wolverhampton can be found on their website here

There are also online courses you can access, these are listed also listed on the website

services.name: African Caribbean Community Initiative (ACCI)
services.description:
Gardening Projects
We have an established allotment in the locality of Wolverhampton. The gardening project is popular during the warmer months of the year which enables service users, carers and volunteers to take advantage of this seasonal activity. Participating in gardening and agricultural activities provides a sense of pride and achievement as the vegetables and fruits harvested are used in the kitchen at ACCI to provide service user meals.
We were also involved in a joint venture with The English Heritage at Wightwick Manor, a large historical building & estate on the out skirts of Wolverhampton. The project helped members in the art of managing, growing and, maintaining a vegetable garden within a group setting as well as exploring the medicinal uses of various herbs.

services.name: African Caribbean Community Initiative (ACCI)
services.description:
‘Nyela’ - Women’s Group

This provides a safe and supportive environment for women and particularly those that are new to the service experiencing a pathway into holistic services where they support each other. The group often arrange trips to places of interest and for socialisation. The creative writing sessions produce poetry, self-reflection and short stories, hand-crafted work e.g. sewing, embroidery etc is very popular and an excellent way to provide a non-challenging social activity.

services.name: African Caribbean Community Initiative (ACCI)
services.description:
Carers Support Group

The Carers Group provides a confidential and safe forum for African and African Caribbean carers to share their experiences, offer support and address the isolation that can occur when caring for someone with mental ill health.
The Carers Group helps to raise awareness of the pivotal role played by many carers in the treatment and recovery of the cared for individual. ACCI’s Carers are provided with opportunities for social networking and supported to confidently interact with welfare providers, the police and other health and social work practitioners.

services.name: African Caribbean Community Initiative (ACCI)
services.description:
Cookery Class
Provides an opportunity for learning to carry out basic cooking requirements in a hygienic and safe environment. How to shop and cook on a budget whilst maintaining a healthy diet. This activity helps to improve confidence and self esteem as they are able to prepare, cook and share a meal with their peers.

services.name: African Caribbean Community Initiative (ACCI)
services.description:
Walking Group
Walks occur throughout the year to aid fitness, stamina, and socialisation, which reduces isolation. Walks mainly occur in the local park.

Cycling Group
To enhance this activity we were able to obtain 10 brand new cycles via the Cycling Tourist Club (CTC), Wolverhampton. This is a socially inclusive activity which helps to reduce stigmas and discrimination against those with mental health issues and Promotes positive mental health awareness.

ACCI Newsletters and Poetry Workshops
Service users supported by staff and volunteers are assisted to produce a twice yearly newsletters and on-going poetry projects that are consistently very successful.

Healthy Living and Nutritional Advice
Short regular sessions aimed to raise and maintain better mental health via a holistic approach.

Anger Management Group
Sessions exploring issues around anger and seeking solutions, using Cognitive Behaviour Therapy and Person Centred Counselling techniques.

services.name: African Caribbean Community Initiative (ACCI)
services.description:
Wellbeing Services
The centre is staffed by experienced and dedicated day centre officers, who support, encourage and motivate members through the journey to recovery and restoration.

The centre hosts to a variety of health promotion activities, as well as structured training and educational sessions for members.

services.name: African Caribbean Community Initiative (ACCI)
services.description:
Housing Advice and Information

ACCI prioritises support to our members to ensure they have secure and appropriate accommodation that promotes safety, stability and well-being and works in partnership with other service providers to this end.

services.name: African Caribbean Community Initiative (ACCI)
services.description:
Men’s Group

Providing an environment where men are able to reason (discuss/debate) issues impacting on their emotional wellbeing e.g. relationships, unemployment, socialisation, lack of opportunities, education, mental and general health, understanding mental health medication and health service processes.
Art. Music, drumming and poetry, etc are used as a medium for them to express, and explore feelings and emotion and find common solutions. There is also the opportunity to learn and develop creative skills.

Sankofa Sesa
The purpose of this service is to promote mental wellbeing in young black males. It is designed to equip individuals with practical skills to improve mental health and develop resilience. It aims to provide comprehensive mental health promotion information in a way that is accessible to young men and makes clear the importance and relevance of protecting and improving wellbeing.

services.name: African Caribbean Community Initiative (ACCI)
services.description:
Outreach Support Team
The Outreach Team provides positive, pro-active outreach support that is both practical and therapeutic for African Caribbean individuals with mental health needs.
Our experienced team interact with members in their homes, hostels, hospitals and prisons. Their role is to enable members to cope with their daily activities by supporting them with domestic, budget and life skills, which will enhance their independence and reduces the risk of relapse. The team liaises with a range of statutory referral agencies and families; they also participate in care plan programmes and assist with mental health assessments where necessary.

services.name: African Caribbean Community Initiative (ACCI)
services.description:
The Good Night Project

The Good Night Project is a community led partnership with Wolverhampton City Council, ACCI and The Wolves Foundation aiming to reduce bed poverty and ensure everyone in Wolverhampton has a good night’s sleep in a suitable bed. 
‘Bed poverty’ is a term used to describe a situation where a person does not have access to a bed and a situation in which a household does not have enough income to afford necessary items.
Getting a good night’s sleep is essential to health and well-being. It is as essential to our bodies as eating, drinking and breathing, and is vital for maintaining good mental and physical health. Sleeping helps to repair and restore our brains, not just our bodies. (Mental health.org.uk) 
Bed bases, mattresses and bedding are all items that will be given out by the project. Some items will be new, but some will be pre-loved items, which have been recycled and refurbished by ACCI. 

If you feel you require support, please complete the Self Referral application found on the website.

If you are working with or supporting someone who requires assistance from the project, please complete the Referral application also found on our website

Once completed a member of the team will be in touch to discuss your request further.

All applications will be followed up with a telephone call and/or a home visit. If your application is successful, we aim to deliver the items within 7-10 days.

services.name: African Caribbean Community Initiative (ACCI)

services.name: African Caribbean Community Initiative (ACCI)
services.description:
The ACCI Counselling & Therapeutic Service
The Service aims to provide a range of holistic and culturally appropriate interventions aimed at assisting members to come to terms with their mental health diagnosis and, to provide a primary care service with the aim to promote psychological well-being and enable individuals to learn essential skills and knowledge in order to manage their distress independently.

In providing a holistic service a number of programmes have been developed and are continually reviewed to ensure that the programmes are relevant and meets the needs of the service users.

services.name: The Women and Families Resource Centre (WFRC)
services.description:
Baby Bank at The Women & Families Resource Centre (WFRC)

The Baby Bank at WFRC supports new mums and families who are struggling with the cost of caring for a baby. We provide free new and pre-loved baby items, including nappies, wipes, and clothes. We aim to make every family feel like they’re receiving a gift, not a handout. Collections take place from our School Street base on Thursday mornings.

We have a separate website for the baby bank with more details here
and facebook page https://www.facebook.com/Wolverhamptonbabybank/

services.description:

services.name: Hope into Action -Black Country Areas
services.description:
Hope into Action: Black Country offers supported accommodation for men in Wolverhampton and for mothers and babies in Sandwell. They partner with local churches to provide not just a home, but personal support to help people rebuild their lives. This is not emergency housing - a referral form must be completed by the individual or a support worker. Once received, the team will arrange to meet and talk through the person’s needs. An assessment is always required, and a place is never guaranteed, even if a vacancy exists.

To apply download the referral form and send to blackcountry@hopeintoaction.org.uk

services.name: Hope Into Action - Black Country Areas
services.description: Family Accommodation in West Bromwich available Oct 2021

services.name: HOPE INTO ACTION BLACK COUNTRY AREAS
services.description: Male only Accommodation in Wolverhampton

services.name: Job Centre Plus
services.description:
Job Centre Plus provides support into employment. 
Employment related benefits such and ESA can also be applied for and dealt with in the JobCentre Plus offices. 
If you wish to use the JobCentre Plus services, you can start the process by telephoning your local office and making an appointment or popping in and talking to someone face to face. This office now offers services to a whole range of people, from the employers advertising jobs, unemployed people looking for work, part time employees looking to get more work, students and school leavers looking to enter the job market and people with special needs who need a bit more assistance in getting a job. 
Offering schemes to help people find work or develop skills, they work closely with the local communities organising work initiatives and volunteering schemes to help people gain experience in their chosen field of work.

services.name: Changing Lives - IRIS Project Sexual exploitation, sex work and sexual violence support
services.description: Evening outreach sessions across Walsall and Wolverhampton, offering support to street sex workers and victims of sexual exploitation .

services.name: Changing Lives - IRIS Project Sexual exploitation, sex work and sexual violence support
services.description: Evening outreach sessions across Walsall and Wolverhampton, offering support to street sex workers and victims of sexual exploitation .

services.name: Periods Matter
services.description:
In addition to Period Products, Periods Matter also collect the items below to provide to people in need
New Underwear
Toiletries

They are then distributed, along with period products to those who need them via
Homeless Outreach Organisations
Women's Support Organisations
Hostels and Shelters
Schools/Colleges
Foodbanks

Please get in touch to find out more

services.name: Periods Matter
services.description:
Period Products from the Periods Matter

We distribute menstrual products to those experiencing period poverty, deliver menstruation workshops to schools and community groups, work with universities to deliver robust research and campaign tirelessly to end Period Poverty! .

How We Distribute 

Once feminine hygiene products are collected, our team of volunteers work tirelessly to put together Period Packs, containing sanitary products, new underwear and a range of toiletries and hygiene products.
The Period Packs are then distributed via:
Homeless Outreach Organisations
Women's Support Organisations
Hostels and Shelters
Schools/Colleges
Foodbanks

Get in touch to find out more

services.name: SUIT - Service User Involvement Team
services.description:
SUIT IPS Employment Programme

The Service User Involvement team work in partnership with Wolves at Work, Recovery Near You, and the Office For Health Improvement and Disparities to deliver an Individual Placement and Support Programme.

It is an approach to providing employment help and support to individuals experiencing mental health and addiction issues. 

For more details, please visit the SUIT website

services.name: SUIT - Service User Involvement Team
services.description:
SUIT’s art collective meet every Tuesday 12.30pm to 2.30pm for guided practical and applied work, including individual portfolio contributions, upcoming exhibition content, creative writing, exploration of mediums, art history, and how styles have emerged socially. 

The art group is a safe space for creative discussion, planning, and individual support. You don’t need any experience of art to come to our group; just be motivated within your recovery and open to learning. 

No referral necessary. 

Get in touch with christiane.jenkins@wvca.org.uk for more information.

services.name: SUIT - Service User Involvement Team
services.description:
For anyone interested in gardening or simply being outdoors, we have an allotment space in Wolverhampton that needs some attention
If you are a drugs service user in Wolverhampton you can join the network by texting the following -:
SUIT ALLOTMENT - 80809

services.name: SUIT - Service User Involvement Team
services.description:
Football is available to any drug service user in Wolverhampton. It is a great way of meeting new people in a safe environment and enjoying the ‘natural buzz’ that this wonderful sport can give. Also, it is a way of relieving some of the stresses that substance misuse can place upon an individual, and one of the main benefits is that participants release natural endorphins (which especially heroin, blocks the brain receptors to).

We play every Monday afternoon at Wolverhampton University Sports Hall facility, as well as entering local tournaments. We hope to join a league soon.

Recently, local charity Wolves Aid donated Wolverhampton Wanderers football kit for us to play in. So thank you Rachel and Barbara from Wolves Aid.

If you live in Wolverhampton and are interested in joining our team, then call Patrick on (01902 328983), or text SUIT Football to 88010 (standard network charges apply).

services.name: SUIT - Service User Involvement Team
services.description:
Support for people with drug/alcohol addiction

The thought of a life in recovery can seem overwhelming. If you need support on your journey or even taking that first step, we are here to help. 

Our staff and volunteers all have a lived experience of addiction and can offer support to people struggling with drug/alcohol related issues, who are working towards recovery or already maintaining successful recovery

Contact SUIT on 01902 328983 for more information.

services.name: Base 25
services.description: Base 25 offers counselling for adults aged 18 to 25 in Wolverhampton. Counsellors provide a safe, confidential space to talk and explore challenges such as anxiety, depression, PTSD, panic attacks and more. Therapies include person-centred and cognitive behavioural approaches. Sessions can take place at the centre, by phone, or online. Contact Base 25 to book an appointment.

services.name: Base 25
services.description: The SAFE and SAFE ’n’ SOUND project offers support for children aged 9‑11 and young people aged 12‑17 who have experienced or witnessed domestic abuse, including emotional, physical abuse or exposure to violence between caregivers. Specialist workers provide structured one‑to‑one support with interventions tailored to the individual. In addition to the core programme, there’s a Saturday Club with creative, sensory and skill‑building activities (music, creative arts, digital, kitchen, etc.) to help with wellbeing and development. There are also workshops offered in schools and the community on themes like healthy vs unhealthy relationships, teenage domestic abuse, and misogyny. Referrals can be made by professionals or the young people themselves, using Base 25’s referral form. found on their website

services.name: Base 25
services.description: Base 25 provides a range of tailored services designed to meet individual needs, working with children, young people and families. Key service areas include Emotional Wellbeing (in partnership with CAMHS, via referral & triage through CAMHS Single Point of Access), Exploitation (support around child criminal exploitation, sexual exploitation, gang involvement), Domestic Abuse (help for those experiencing or witnessing abuse), Behaviour Management (programmes including anger management), and the Wellbeing Hub (a drop‑in space for under‑25s with emotional support, peer connection, skill building, advice; no referral needed - just sign in). Base 25 also collaborates with partner organisations to embed best practices, share expertise, and ensure support is accessible.

services.name: Base 25
services.description:
Our Wellbeing Hub provides a safe space that any young person under the age of 25 can access without a referral. Simply sign in at Base 25 reception and a worker will guide you to the hub, located on the ground floor next to our café, charity shop and courtyard garden.

The Wellbeing Hub offers a welcoming space for young people to seek advice and guidance on wellbeing, provides emotional support and promotes resilience in a supportive community environment.

services.name: Micro Rainbow
services.description:
Moving On Programme

Micro Rainbow provides one-to-one support to LGBTQI people who have recently become refugees in order to:
obtain National Insurance numbers
register with Universal Credit
open bank accounts 
Micro Rainbow works with various partners, including the third and private sector, to:
provide one to one support over a period of six to twelve months to prepare and review a moving on plan (e.g. to find employment)
organise workshops around CV writing and interview skills
facilitate job opportunities

How to access

services.name: Micro Rainbow
services.description:
Why we run safe houses dedicated solely to LGBTQI asylum seekers and refugees

In 76 countries homosexuality is illegal. 1,500 LGBTQI refugees from those countries come to the UK every year.

When they come to the UK they are still not safe. Because of their sexuality, gender identity, gender expression or intersex status they often:
are abused in refugee accommodation by other refugees who often come from the same countries they are escaping from
become homeless and depressed
are rejected by their ethnic community and live in poverty

What we are doing to help LGBTQI asylum seekers and refugees

Micro Rainbow opened the first safe house in the United Kingdom dedicated solely to LGBTQI asylum seekers and refugees. Our houses provide a safe and temporary shelter for all LGBTQI asylum seekers and refugees. They are located in the London area, in the North West and in the West Midlands.

If you need a translator, please email housing@microrainbow.org to arrange this in advance.
Our support line number is 0800 3585851. This number is free to call Mon-Fri 2pm-5pm. Our support line is for urgent matters

services.name: Wolves Waste Not [The Real Junk Food Project Wolverhampton]
services.description:
Wolves Waste Not Surplus Food Market @ Gatis Community Space
Open every Wednesday 11:30am to 3pm and Thursday from 11:30am to 3pm (Or Until the food is gone) Please bring your own bags!

We intercept food that is past its expiration date and we use our own judgement on whether we believe that food is fit for human consumption or not. By smelling it, tasting it and visually inspecting it.

We do not turn food away simply because it has expired. But we will never serve food that we believe is unfit for human consumption. 

We operate on a Pay as You Feel basis

What do we mean by PAYF?

PAYF (Pay As You Feel) offers an alternative to the conventional payment system as there are no prices on any produce in the cafés or supermarkets. Our system transcends monetary transactions and liberates people to use their skills and attributes as well as money to pay for their meals.

Furthermore, we aim to highlight the absurdity that the produce we use has been stripped of it’s monetary value but still retains it’s nutritional value. by making people think about what they wish to contribute for their meals, that idea is to get Society thinking about how they value food as a resource

services.name: Aquarius
services.description:
Recovery Near You - Wolverhampton
Drug and alcohol support for adults, young people, and families in Wolverhampton.

Run by Aquarius with Nacro and NHS partners, services include medical care, detox support, needle exchange, BBV testing, one-to-one help, and links to housing, education, and employment.

services.name: Recovery Near You - Wolverhampton Substance Misuse Service and 360
services.description: Recovery Near You’s Clinical Team supports people with complex needs linked to alcohol or drug use. You may be referred if you’re using multiple substances, are pregnant, have a mental health diagnosis, or need a detox. The team includes a psychiatrist, GPs, nurses, and prescribers. They can provide substitute medication and create detox plans. You’ll usually see the same prescriber throughout your care.

services.name: Recovery Near You - Wolverhampton Substance Misuse Service and 360
services.description: The Specialist Alcohol Team includes alcohol liaison nurses based in Wolverhampton hospitals. They support people with serious alcohol issues and help with hospital-based detox. After treatment, they can refer individuals to other Recovery Near You teams for ongoing support.

services.name: Aquarius
services.description:
W360 is the young people’s service run by Wolverhampton Recovery Near You, a service Aquarius runs in partnership with Nacro and Birmingham and Solihull Mental Health Foundation Trust. W360 works with anyone under the age of 18 who wants information or advice on anything to do with alcohol or drugs. In some cases we can work with people age 18-25 if you face particular challenges.

Contact / referral details
W360 Website
Tel 0300 123 3360

services.name: Recovery Near You - Wolverhampton Substance Misuse Service and 360
services.description: Recovery Near You runs a free and confidential needle exchange service in Wolverhampton. Anyone who injects drugs can access clean equipment and safely return used items. Staff also offer friendly advice, blood-borne virus testing, and support with safer drug use. No appointment or referral is needed-just walk in during opening hours.

services.name: Recovery Near You - Wolverhampton Substance Misuse Service and 360
services.description:
Wolverhampton360 supports children and young people under 18 with issues around alcohol or drugs. They also help 18-25s who are vulnerable or have extra needs, and children aged 5-18 affected by a parent's substance use. Services include one-to-one support, advocacy, and advice for families. 

You can self-refer by phone, live chat on the website or by email. Support is confidential and age-appropriate. We may need to obtain the consent from your parents but not always. Call us and we can talk this through.

services.name: Recovery Near You - Wolverhampton Substance Misuse Service and 360
services.description: Recovery Near You offers friendly, expert help for anyone in Wolverhampton concerned about their drug or alcohol use. You can get one-to-one or group support, vaccinations and testing for blood-borne viruses, and access to a needle exchange. They also help families and friends and can link you to support for housing, education, and employment. Call or drop in - no referral needed.

services.description: This service offers free courses to help adults improve their skills in English, maths, ESOL, and IT - from beginner to Level 2. Classes are friendly and practical, designed to help with everyday life and job prospects. All learners are supported to work at their own pace and prepare for OCR qualifications. Courses cover speaking, reading, writing, using email, the internet, and common software. Contact to enrol.

services.name: Bilston Resource Centre
services.description: Our advisers support clients to secure long-term employment, and provide help with job interviews, cover letters, job application forms and CVs. We provide several computers for clients to search for work independently. Clients can book in for one-hour slots during our opening hours.

services.name: Excel Church
services.description:
The Excel Food bank operates on a referral based system. In order to collect a food parcel you must live in WV2 or WV14 and you will need to be referred by a professional. 

A list of potential people who could refer you to our food bank can be found on our website here

If the organisation or person that you ask to refer you does not have a referral form, they can email us for one. Referral forms must be received by 10am on Monday in order to collect a parcel that day. Please note that we can currently fulfil 30 referrals per week. A maximum of 3 parcels per person can be collected in a 6 month period. 

Food parcels must be collected between 12pm and 2pm on a Monday.

When collecting a parcel, our team will also be on hand to offer support to help people overcome their financial challenges. This may include signposting to other organisations, helping to check that a client is claiming all the benefits they are entitled to, help with form filling etc. 

Please be aware and prepared that the food bank volunteers will also offer to pray for people's situations since the food bank is facilitated by a church community. Please feel free to accept or decline prayer if this is offered to you. You do not need to have a faith or believe in God to benefit from this food bank. 

When collecting a parcel we ask that you bring ID and also recommend bringing information about any benefits you are in receipt of, so that we can do our best to assist you.

services.name: Bilston Resource Centre
services.description: This service offers free courses to help adults improve their skills in English, maths, ESOL, and IT - from beginner to Level 2. Classes are friendly and practical, designed to help with everyday life and job prospects. All learners are supported to work at their own pace and prepare for OCR qualifications. Courses cover speaking, reading, writing, using email, the internet, and common software. Contact to enrol.

services.name: Excel Church
services.description:
A Welcome Brew Community Drop in at Excel Church

Drop in for a friendly chat, free refreshments, activities, crafts, advice and guidance and much more.

If you need some advice or someone to talk to during these challenging times, we offer a free, impartial and confidential service. We can even offer help with form filling and advice on benefits etc.

A Welcome Brew Community Drop In takes place every Wednesday and is open to anyone who fancies dropping in! A warm welcome awaits.

If you have any questions, please get in touch.

services.name: Excel Church
services.description:
Advice and Guidance at Excel Church

If you need some advice or someone to talk to during these challenging times, we offer a free, impartial and confidential service. We can even offer help with form filling and advice on benefits etc.

Call Trisha Mon or Tues, 10am-12pm
07856573668

Or come along to our Community Drop In on Wednesday mornings.

services.name: Wolverhampton Special Care Dental Service (WSCDS)
services.description:
The Wolverhampton Special Care Dental Service (WSCDS) is a unique service that provides dental care and treatment for special care patients including vulnerable and hard-to-reach groups in the area.

We provide comprehensive NHS dental care for individuals living in Wolverhampton or who have a Wolverhampton GP, who may have difficulty obtaining such care in general dental services.

Our service user groups include socially excluded groups (eg. people seeking asylum, people experiencing homelessness)

Referring In 
We only accept referrals from:
General dental practitioners
GPs
Other healthcare professionals

Referral Forms can be obtained by the health care professional by contacting WSCDS
phone: 01902 446681
email: rwh-tr.pennfields-dental-services@nhs.net

Please note, we cannot accept self referrals

services.name: Aspiring Futures CIC
services.description:
Skills & Employment

Learn new skills, make new friends and improve your emotional and mental health. Our support offers one to one mentoring and coaching and group training sessions. We offer volunteering and work placements.

Support includes:
Employment support (job search, cv writing and driving theory) for eligible participants
Basic ESOL

services.description:
Health and Wellbeing

Manage your health and adopt a healthier lifestyle. Meet other women, share cultural recipes or natural herbal remedies; learn new skills or just have fun. Sessions include:

Self-Care

Health & Beauty

One to one counselling and psychotherapy
One to one mentoring and coaching
Talking Therapy for girls aged 12+

maths

services.name: Alcoholics Anonymous UK
services.description:
AA meetings are sessions run by and for, alcoholics. There are two basic types of meetings, "open" and "closed". Anyone is welcome to attend an open meeting, while closed meetings are limited to addicts and to people who think they may have a problem with alcohol. 

A comprehensive list of meeting times, locations and descriptions for wolverhampton can be found on the [AA website] (https://www.alcoholics-anonymous.org.uk/AA-Meetings/Find-a-Meeting/wolverhampton)

services.description:
Men's Woodwork Group

Lunt Community Centre - Tuesdays, Wednesdays and Thursdays from 9:30am to 1pm

For any further information please get in touch.
Contact: Daphne Darby
Phone: 01384 620396 / 07530071068
Email: wdarby@sky.com

services.name: Citizens Advice - Sandwell and Walsall
services.description:
The Citizens Advice service offers information and advice through face-to-face, phone and online services.

CA Willenhall
Whatever your problem is, you are not alone - we are here to help, just call our adviceline, pop-in or email us and we will point you in the right direction. It can be about your health, your money, your house, your family, your rights, immigration or anything in between.

Contact Us
office@citizensadvicesandwell-walsall.org
Advice Line: 0300 330 9017

services.name: Job Centre Plus
services.description:
Job Centre Plus provides support into employment. 
Employment related benefits such and ESA can also be applied for and dealt with in the JobCentre Plus offices. 
If you wish to use the JobCentre Plus services, you can start the process by telephoning your local office and making an appointment or popping in and talking to someone face to face. This office now offers services to a whole range of people, from the employers advertising jobs, unemployed people looking for work, part time employees looking to get more work, students and school leavers looking to enter the job market and people with special needs who need a bit more assistance in getting a job. 
Offering schemes to help people find work or develop skills, they work closely with the local communities organising work initiatives and volunteering schemes to help people gain experience in their chosen field of work.

services.name: Foodcycle West Midlands
services.description:
FoodCycle Wolverhampton Wednesdays @ 5pm

What is a community meal? 
It’s just that - tasty food and great company! 

Every week, our volunteers collect surplus food and cook it, Ready, Steady, Cook-style, into delicious three-course meals which they serve to you, our guests.
Everyone is welcome
Meals are totally free
Meals are meat and fish free making them suitable for people of all cultures/religions
You don’t need a referral or a voucher
If we have extra surplus food that week, our guests are welcome to take it home 

Everyone is welcome at FoodCycle. We know that the cost of living continues to increase, so whatever your reason for needing a meal, you are welcome to join us. Some people come for the food. Some people come for the company. No matter your background, you’ll be greeted warmly by our friendly volunteers who’ll sit down together with you to enjoy a meal and a chat. We don’t ask questions and you don’t need any particular reason to come other than fancying a meal and some company. 

Feel like joining us? 
Freecycle Wolverhampton welcomes anyone to attend as a guest and enjoy a FREE hot meal. No need to book. Just turn up on the day

If you need to get in touch you can email wolverhampton@foodcycle.org.uk or check out our dedicated Foodcycle Walsall and the Black Country Facebook Page

services.name: Wolves Waste Not [The Real Junk Food Project Wolverhampton]
services.description:
Wolves Waste Not Surplus Food Market @ St Chad's and St Mark's

Open every Saturday from 2pm to 4pm (Or Until the food is gone)

We intercept food that is past its expiration date and we use our own judgement on whether we believe that food is fit for human consumption or not. By smelling it, tasting it and visually inspecting it.

We do not turn food away simply because it has expired. But we will never serve food that we believe is unfit for human consumption. 

We operate on a Pay as You Feel basis. Please bring your own bags!

What do we mean by PAYF?

PAYF (Pay As You Feel) offers an alternative to the conventional payment system as there are no prices on any produce in the cafés or supermarkets. Our system transcends monetary transactions and liberates people to use their skills and attributes as well as money to pay for their meals.

Furthermore, we aim to highlight the absurdity that the produce we use has been stripped of it’s monetary value but still retains it’s nutritional value. by making people think about what they wish to contribute for their meals, that idea is to get Society thinking about how they value food as a resource

services.name: Wolverhampton City Of Sanctuary
services.description:
ESOL at Wolverhampton City of Sanctuary 

We offer basic English lessons for those with some knowledge of the language, from 11 am to 12pm during our Drop-In each Wednesday. The aims are to give learners a knowledge of English grammar, spelling and punctuation, and also to give learners the confidence to speak, write and read English. Just come along

services.name: Wolverhampton City Of Sanctuary
services.description:
Sewing Club at Wolverhampton City of Sanctuary 
There are four sewing machines available for those who would like to take part in our weekly sewing club that runs during the Wednesday drop in sessions.

services.name: Wolverhampton City Of Sanctuary
services.description:
Support for Refugees and Asylum Seekers at Wolverhampton City of Sanctuary

City of Sanctuary works to support refugees and asylum seekers who are embarking on new lives in the UK and aims to do this through welcome, integration and community hospitality. This results in new arrivals facing decreased levels of isolation, increased levels of well-being, personal empowerment and stronger social networks, whilst simultaneously strengthening communities and bringing people of all backgrounds together.

We provide activities and advice during our weekly drop in sessions

For more details get in touch by email enquiries@wolvescofs.com

services.name: Wolverhampton City Of Sanctuary
services.description:
Fortnightly Foodclub at Wolverhampton City of Sanctuary

Come & Cook Food from your own Culture to Share with Others. Everyone welcome - Men, women, young, old, volunteers and visitors. If you would like to cook one of your favourite dishes, please let Gill Kelly know at the Drop-In, and she will buy the ingredients. Come and taste and talk.

please note that this is a fortnightly food club, so please check the Wolverhampton City of Sanctuary Diary Page to confirm when the next session is running

services.name: Wolverhampton City Of Sanctuary
services.description:
Exceptional Needs Fund

Wolverhampton City of Sanctuary offers an exceptional needs fund to offer financial support to destitute asylum seekers who are sofa-surfing with friends, providing essential needs additional to a bed for the night.

services.name: Wolverhampton City Of Sanctuary
services.description: A safe, welcoming space for asylum seekers and refugees to relax, meet others, and get informal support. People can play games, chat, and mix with others from different cultures. Volunteers are on hand to offer information about local services and life in Wolverhampton. Open to all - no referral needed.

services.description:
ESOL for beginners at Wolverhampton City of Sanctuary 

We offer basic English lessons for beginners, from 10 am to 11 am during our Drop-In each Wednesday. The aims are to give learners a knowledge of basic English grammar, spelling and punctuation, and also to give learners the confidence to speak, write and read English. Just come along

services.name: Elias Mattu Foundation
services.description:
The Elias Mattu Foundation is committed to support the wider communities in need across City of Wolverhampton in time of crisis.

In addition to our food parcel deliveries which contain staple food, fresh fruit, and vegetables, when available we can provide baby items such as baby formula, nappies, wipes, and baby food.

Please get in touch if you would like to refer yourself or someone you know into our service.

services.name: Elias Mattu Foundation
services.description:
Elias Mattu Foundation Food Bank

The Elias Mattu Foundation is committed to support the wider communities in need across City of Wolverhampton in time of crisis.

We deliver Food Parcels to families, elderly, and international students in financial hardship. Deliveries are made on Saturday’s between 12pm-6pm. We do have an emergency food parcel service in place during the week, Monday - Friday for professional to arrange to collect from us.

We provide seven days worth of food in our food parcels.

The parcels are nutritionally balanced containing, staple food, fresh fruit, and vegetables. When available we can provide baby items such as baby formula, nappies, wipes, and baby food.

We have a general limit of 4 - 6 weeks of service this is to support individuals and families while other support can be established.

We are aware of exceptional circumstances and will consider extending this limit.

What’s included in our food parcels:
Cereal
Bread
Eggs
Milk (UHT, semi/skimmed)
Tea/Coffee/ Sugar
Jam/Marmalade
Biscuits
Fruit Juice/Squash
Soup/ Cuppa Soup
Rice
Pasta/Cooking Sauce
Baked Beans/Spaghetti/ Kidney Beans /Peas

Vegetables

Stop Loan Sharks - Birmingham

services.name: Rape and Sexual Violence Project [ RSVP ]
services.description:
We offer a wide range of services to both adult and child survivors and the people supporting you. 

Click on the links to view our RSVP leaflet and poster, and specific leaflet for male survivors

services.name: Rape and Sexual Violence Project [ RSVP ]
services.description:
RSVP provides specialist services to support people of any or no gender, and of any age who have been raped or sexually assaulted.

Children and Young People's Service
We have a dedicated website The Survivor Hub
We offer help called advocacy to under 18s 
Our trained staff are called ISVAs and as well as supporting you, they can also help the family and friends who are supporting you.
Our ISVAs make sure your voice is heard; they will help you understand what people are saying to you and help you say what you want to say. They will make sure your needs are met and that you are listened to.

Adult Advocacy
Our Independent Sexual Violence Advocates (ISVAs) offer practical and emotional support, ensuring that your views, opinions, wishes and feelings are respected, and listened to by all agencies and people involved.

LGBTQ+ Advocacy
 If you are lesbian, gay, bi, trans (Including but not exclusive list- non binary, non cis, gender queer, MSM, androgynous, intersex, pansexual…)* and have ever experienced rape, sexual assault or sexual abuse at any point in your life, our specialist LGBT ISVAs (Independent Sexual Violence Advocates) delivered from RSVP and within Birmingham LGBT too are here to help.

Male Survivors
Support for men and boys subjected to sexual violence and abuse
We offer a range of services for male survivors to support you in making the decisions and choices that are right for you.
Practical support whether you have chosen to report to the police or not. Our Independent Sexual Violence Advocates (ISVAs) can support you through the criminal justice process, talk to you about other ways of seeking justice, or help
you gain support from other organisations
We can offer you face to face or telephone counselling; both provide a safe place to talk and explore your feelings. We have appointments available at different times, at various locations around Birmingham and Solihull, with counsellors of different sexes for you to choose from.

Asylum Seeker and Refugee Survivors
We offer services to support asylum seekers and refugees who have experienced sexual violence, rape or sexual torture in any country.
We offer specialist counselling support, and work with interpreters so you can be supported in your own language.
A support worker can also assist you with practical issues, including destitution, housing, childcare and guidance on legal support available to you.
