services.name: Rape and Sexual Violence Project [ RSVP ]
services.description:
Sex Worker Advocacy
The Red Project is a sex worker advocacy service for people involved in sex work who may have experienced, or be at risk of experiencing, sexual violence. We meet most of our clients through outreach work, and we support you emotionally and practically. 

The Red Project has its own [website] (https://www.theredproject.co.uk) and Twitter account @TheRedProjectWM for up to date information on outreach support.

You can contact RSVP’s sex worker ISVA at isva@rsvporg.co.uk / 07432 578105

services.name: Rape and Sexual Violence Project [ RSVP ]
services.description:
Children & Young People’s Counselling at RSVP

Counselling is a safe place where you can talk to people that believe you and care about your feelings. Counselling is one way of talking about how the abuse has affected you, with someone who will listen and give you space to explore the things that are bothering you. Our trained counsellors listen with empathy and sensitivity. They don’t judge; their aim is to explore feelings and to support you in the decisions you make.

Please call us, we’re happy to talk to you about other support available to you

services.name: The Red Project
services.description:
The Red Project provides support, wellbeing, and advice for Sex Workers in Solihull and Birmingham.

The Red Project offers practical advice, specialist information & emotional support for sex workers, of all genders, affected by sexual violence.

Our project is for any sex worker working independently, via agency, indoor premises, on-street or exchanging 'sex for favours' who has been affected by sexual violence or abuse.

We are here for advice, support or just to talk. We can support with ‘Dodgy Punter’ & Incident reporting & work in collaboration with National Ugly Mugs (NUM). We know this work can be isolating, but we are here to offer you advice, support, advocacy or just to talk.

Get in touch or visit our website for more information about the support we can provide.

services.name: The Red Project
services.description:
We provide you with free condoms, lube and STI kits and support to attend sexual health services.

For more information contact your local Red Project Worker

services.name: The Red Project
services.description: As part of our holistic package of support we are able to refer you into specialist sexual violence counselling. Our trained counsellors listen with empathy and sensitivity. They don’t judge or give advice; their aim is to explore feelings and to support you in the decisions you make.

services.name: The Red Project
services.description:
Support following Sexual Violence

We can support you to attend a Sexual Assault Referral Centre (SARC) Clinic where you will be seen by specialist medical staff who can support your immediate needs. The SARC can offer medical examinations for forensic evidence if a sexual assault has happened in the last 10 days. You won't be pressured to report to the police, you can have forensics collected and stored should you choose to report at a later date.

You can have a forensic examination even if you have already washed, although there will be more DNA evidence on your body if you are able to avoid washing until after the examination.

services.name: Rape and Sexual Violence Project [ RSVP ]
services.description:
If you are a survivor of sexual violence we know it can be very difficult to attend certain types of health appointments. Intimate examinations, sexual health testing and antenatal care can trigger distressing memories.

Our Independent Sexual Violence Advocates (ISVAs) can offer support before and after certain types of health appointments; whatever your age, gender identity, or sexual orientation. 

At the moment we are unable to go with you to health appointments but we will provide telephone support before and after intimate medical healthcare, to ensure that you don’t feel alone. 

If you would like to have this type of support, please call our ISVA team 
0121 643 0301 (option 2) to discuss how we can help.

services.name: Rape and Sexual Violence Project [ RSVP ]
services.description:
Sexual health
Simple home testing kits for sexually transmitted infections (STIs) like chlamydia can also be obtained from the ISVA team.
Along with our partner service, Umbrella Health, our ISVAs provide a dedicated Abuse Survivors Clinic (ASC) offering specialised services (including contraception advice) to support anyone aged 13 or over who has been affected by sexual violence or abuse at any time in their lives.

You will need to book an appointment in advance, by calling 0121 237 5737 or 0121 237 5700. These Abuse Survivor Clinics are held out in the community. More information can be found on our website

services.name: Rape and Sexual Violence Project [ RSVP ]
services.description:
Expert sexual abuse lawyers from Irwin Mitchell Solicitors have teamed up with RSVP to provide free legal advice for survivors we have supported in the past and those currently using our services too.

The clinics offer free legal advice to survivors across a broad range of topics, including family law matters, Criminal Injuries Compensation Authority claims and civil claims. Civil claims could be made against an individual who has committed abuse, an organisation responsible for that person (usually an employer) or an organisation that should have taken steps to prevent abuse, but failed - such as social services.

An Irwin Mitchell solicitor provides free advice alongside emotional and practical support from a member of our advocacy team.

The legal clinics are generally on the last Friday of every month between 11:00am and 1:00pm

If you would like to access this service but cannot attend the scheduled session, please contact the advocacy (ISVA) team on 0121 643 0301 option 2 or isva@rsvporg.co.uk and we will look into accommodating your enquiry at a more convenient time for you.

services.name: Rape and Sexual Violence Project [ RSVP ]
services.description:
Counselling through RSVP is available to you, your partner, family, and friends. Our free confidential counselling service is open seven days a week, we offer day, evening and weekend appointments.

Our trained counsellors listen with empathy and sensitivity. They don’t judge or give advice; their aim is to explore feelings and to support you in the decisions you make. Your voice will be heard.

You can tell us what you want from counselling, the days and times that would suit you best and which gender of counsellor you would like to work with. Our counselling service is available to people of all genders from 18 in the Birmingham and Solihull areas, and there are a number of locations you can choose from. Supporters to survivors can also access counselling.

services.name: Rape and Sexual Violence Project [ RSVP ]
services.description:
RSVP have a sister organisation called GINA providing immediate, specialist counselling & bespoke products/resources for individuals subjected to sexual violence & abuse.

There is no waiting list for this service.

For more information, please get in touch with GINA:

www.gina.uk.com | hello@gina.uk.com | 0121 643 0301

services.name: Shaw Trust- Birmingham
services.description:
Health and Wellbeing

Good mental and physical wellbeing is vital to support a healthy workforce and work is a key driver for good health and wellbeing.

At Shaw Trust our aim is to help people improve their mental and physical health and to strengthen and take control of their overall wellbeing. We work in partnership with local groups and commissioners to support the wellbeing of employees and those who are unemployed. 

We connect people with the services they need, when they need them. Working across communities with a wide array of local partners we ensure those supported can improve their everyday living, tackle levels of anxiety, become more independent and confident, meet new people, get better skills and move into work which supports their health and lifestyle goals.
For Further Information: I am a link

services.name: Shaw Trust- Birmingham
services.description:
Shaw Trust is the sponsor of Shaw Education Trust. We believe education is a pathway to improving opportunity, raising aspirations and building the foundations of meaningful employment.

As a multi-academy trust sponsor we believe every child should have the opportunity to be successful whatever their starting point. Our commitment is to improve, accelerate and enable ambitious life goals among all young people in our academies.

The aim of this training is to provide learning and development opportunities to equip individuals with the skills needed for employment and achieving their career goals.
For further information:I am a link

services.name: West Midlands Anti-Slavery Network
services.description:
If you think you or someone you know might be affected by modern slavery, there is help available.

The West Midlands Anti Slavery Network has friendly, specialist support workers in the West Midlands and Warwickshire. They’re here to listen, support you, and help you get the right services.

The team offer support that is based on your individual needs. This can include:
Getting food bank vouchers
Helping you apply for housing or emergency accommodation
Setting up Universal Credit or other benefits
Connecting you to health, mental health or addiction services
Supporting you to access specialist care for victims of modern slavery
Speaking up for you if needed

You do not need to go through this alone. If you’re not sure if this applies to you, it’s okay to ask. Help is out there, and you deserve safety and support.

services.name: Birmingham Central Foodbank
services.description:
To get help, you’ll need a foodbank voucher. Call or email the foodbank and they’ll connect you with a referral agency. You can also call 0808 208 2138 (Mon-Fri, 9am-5pm) to speak to Citizens Advice, who can issue a voucher if needed.

Once you have your voucher, bring it to the foodbank. You’ll be welcomed with a hot drink and given three days of emergency food. Volunteers will check dietary needs and offer further support where possible.

services.name: Embrace Birmingham
services.description:
Embrace helps those at risk of sexual exploitation, especially women selling sex on the streets.

They offer essentials, safety advice, and follow-up support including advocacy, befriending, and help attending appointments.

Follow-up support is offered through outreach connections and tailored to each woman’s needs. This can include befriending, advocacy, attending appointments, housing support, and emotional or spiritual support if wanted. Embrace works closely with other agencies, focusing on building trusted relationships.

Open to women of all faiths or none.
Get in touch to make an appointment

services.name: Micro Rainbow
services.description:
Why we run safe houses dedicated solely to LGBTQI asylum seekers and refugees

In 76 countries homosexuality is illegal. 1,500 LGBTQI refugees from those countries come to the UK every year.

When they come to the UK they are still not safe. Because of their sexuality, gender identity, gender expression or intersex status they often:
are abused in refugee accommodation by other refugees who often come from the same countries they are escaping from
become homeless and depressed
are rejected by their ethnic community and live in poverty

What we are doing to help LGBTQI asylum seekers and refugees

Micro Rainbow opened the first safe house in the United Kingdom dedicated solely to LGBTQI asylum seekers and refugees. Our houses provide a safe and temporary shelter for all LGBTQI asylum seekers and refugees. They are located in the London area, in the North West and in the West Midlands.

If you need a translator, please email housing@microrainbow.org to arrange this in advance.
Our support line number is 0800 3585851. This number is free to call Mon-Fri 2pm-5pm. Our support line is for urgent matters

services.name: Micro Rainbow
services.description:
Moving On Programme

Micro Rainbow provides one-to-one support to LGBTQI people who have recently become refugees in order to:
obtain National Insurance numbers
register with Universal Credit
open bank accounts 
Micro Rainbow works with various partners, including the third and private sector, to:
provide one to one support over a period of six to twelve months to prepare and review a moving on plan (e.g. to find employment)
organise workshops around CV writing and interview skills
facilitate job opportunities

How to access 
Email: movingon@microrainbow.org

services.name: Micro Rainbow
services.description:
LGBTQI refugees are still rejected by their families and communities even in the UK. They become extremely isolated, without enough social safety nets and opportunities in life. They live at the margins of society, often in environments that expose them to increased abuse and violence.

Online Workshops

To protect the safety of staff and clients, we have suspended our face-to-face social inclusion activities throughout the UK, our moving on workshops and face-to-face risk assessments for the housing programme. 

However, we are working painstakingly over the phone, by email and social media to support LGBTQI asylum seekers who are homeless, feel isolated and distressed or need guidance to move on. 

We are also doing risk assessments over the phone. 

We offer weekly online social inclusion sessions like relaxation, yoga, dance and legal workshops. If you want to join but don’t have enough mobile data we can top up your phone. 

Please email social@microrainbow.org to join our online activities.

Our social inclusion programme aims to build friendships and reduce the extreme isolation faced by LGBTQI refugees, to strengthen communities where networks are fragile. 

At the point at which we are able to hold face to face activity sessions, these will take place monthly at the Birmingham LGBT Centre.

services.name: Stonewall Housing
services.description:
Housing Advice Line 
Our daily, nationwide helpline provides expert advice on housing options, tenancy rights, and navigating homelessness for LGBTQ+ individuals. Our team is ready to discuss specific situations and help create tailored solutions.

 Housing Advice and Advocacy Service based in Birmingham 
The service advocates on behalf of clients, helping to address issues with landlords, housing providers, and local authorities. Advocacy may include resolving disputes, challenging unfair housing practices, or helping clients access appropriate support services. The goal is to ensure LGBTQ+ individuals have their rights upheld in housing situations.

Should you need to access this service -please call the advice line or complete the referral form found on the Stonewall Housing website

services.name: Stonewall Housing
services.description:
Stonewall Housing are the UK’s leading organisation dedicated to supporting LGBTQ+ individuals who are homeless or at risk of homelessness. Our mission is to provide expert housing advice, advocacy, and support services tailored specifically for the LGBTQ+ community. I wanted to reach out and share more about our services, as we’re committed to ensuring our community members have access to the resources they need, particularly during challenging times.

Online Chat and Referral System

For easy access, individuals can reach us via our online chat on our website or complete an online referral form. A member of our triage team will follow up to ensure each person is matched with the support that best suits their situation.

services.name: Stonewall Housing
services.description:
Drug and Alcohol Support Service (DASS) 
Designed to meet the unique needs of LGBTQ+ individuals facing substance use challenges, our DASS programme offers specialised housing advice and support, guiding individuals towards a stable living situation with dedicated assistance.

services.name: Stonewall Housing
services.description:
Mental Health Advocacy Service (NMHA) @ Stonewall Housing

Our NMHA service provides comprehensive housing advice, advocacy, and mental health support for LGBTQ+ individuals, connecting them with the resources they need to support their mental wellbeing and secure safe housing.

services.name: WAITS [Women Acting in Todays Society]
services.description:
WAITS Domestic Abuse Service 
WAITS provides one‑to‑one support for any woman who has experienced or is experiencing domestic abuse. You will be assigned a support worker and a personalised support plan. We also help with advocacy, coordinating with other agencies, and workshops. If the service isn’t right for you, we will sign‑post you to a more suitable organisation

Referral Info 
Access via self‑referral or agency referral. Call or email the service to request an electronic referral form. Find out more on the WAITS website here

services.name: WAITS [Women Acting in Todays Society]
services.description:
Community Integration Project 
WAITS offers one‑to‑one support for women with offending or re‑offending histories and multiple complex needs (such as domestic abuse, substance use). You’ll receive a dedicated support worker, help with a personalised plan, advocacy, and co‑ordination of all your agencies. Support is open‑ended until you’re ready to move on.

Referral info 
Access via agency or self‑referral. Call or email to request an electronic referral form. ind out more on the WAITS website here

services.name: Birmingham City Mission
services.description:
Working with people experiencing homelessness 
The Care Centre team offers practical and emotional support to guests who are often living through great difficulties and loneliness.

services.name: Birmingham City Mission
services.description: Birmingham City Mission's Care Centre is able to provide toiletries and clothing to individuals experiencing homelessness in the city.

services.name: Birmingham City Mission
services.description: Hot meals are served at Birmingham City Mission's Care Centre at lunchtime, Monday-Thursday. Services are aimed at supporting people experiencing homelessness.

services.name: Birmingham City Mission
services.description: Birmingham City Mission's Care Centre is able to provide toiletries and clothing to individuals experiencing homelessness in the city.

services.name: Birmingham Mind
services.description:
Birmingham Mind Mental Health and Emotional Support Helpline 
Birmingham Mind’s Helpline offers emotional support, wellbeing advice and clear information for anyone experiencing mental health difficulties, as well as for families, professionals and the wider public. The team can help you make sense of what’s going on, talk through options and find the right next step.

You can call the Helpline every day from 9am-11pm on 0121 262 3555 or Freephone 0800 915 9292. You can also reach the team by email or through their daily webchat, available 10am-9pm. 

The Helpline provides advice, information and signposting around mental health, wellbeing, emotional concerns, social care issues and related conditions..

services.description:
Birmingham MIND Mental Health Support for African Caribbean Communities

Supporting the African Caribbean community to maintain their cultural identity. Providing signposting, well-being events and capacity building to promote mental health and well-being.
Call Uroy on 07801130660 or email UroyKelly@Birminghammind.org

Support for African Caribbean Communities is part of Birmingham Mind's Community Development Service which engages with communities across Birmingham and Solihull. We are a bridge between communities and the commissioners who pay for services. The team can help to improve physical and mental health and well-being in communities.
We offer signposting to individuals and a large range of organisations
We network throughout Birmingham and Solihull and support local events
We offer mental health and well-being sessions
Get in touch with us by email. cdw@birminghammind.org

services.name: Birmingham Mind
services.description:
Mental health is now the number one reason for staff absence and undertaking mental health training is one way, to reduce absenteeism and promote positive mental wellbeing and recovery.

Birmingham Mind is able to expertly deliver a number of training courses in order for you to understand and explore mental health and what basic steps can be taken to support someone experiencing mental illness.

For more information visit: https://birminghammind.org/training/mhfa/

services.name: Standing Tall
services.description:
We match people going through homelessness into real living wage jobs and safe homes helping them to move away from the streets for good.

Standing Tall works in partnership with businesses to help an individual out of homelessness through employment and accommodation

Standing Tall employs the individual on behalf of a business for 3 months. The business makes a contribution to the living wage salary for this period before taking on the employment from month 4. 

By offering tailored, flexible support packages, Standing Tall enables employers to make whatever commitment they are ready for. Standing Tall works alongside the business and the individual to achieve the best outcome and we also provide safe accommodation for the individual. If you want to work with us or find out more, then please get in touch and we can make a difference together.

To be able to move off the street, it’s not just about the job. An individual needs a safe home to come home to at the end of the day. Standing Tall’s Amici accommodation service is providing a safe home and a listening ear as the individual transitions away from the street.

services.name: Trident Reach
services.description:
Navigator Services 
Our Navigator Services prioritises getting people quickly into stable homes. From this point, any other support needs they might have - such as alcohol and drug dependency, physical and/or mental health problems - are addressed through coordinated and intensive support.

The service runs on the following principals:
People have a right to a home
Flexible support is provided for as long as it is needed.
Housing and support are separated
Individuals have choice and control
An active engagement approach is used
The service is based on peoples: strengths, goals, and aspirations
A harm reduction approach is used
 
Trident Reach have 12 Navigators working with a maximum of 7-8 people at any given time. We are also committed to providing property into the project.

To speak to a member of the Navigator Team, please call Azad Azam, Team Supervisor, on 0774 7218 410 or email Azad.Azam@tridentreach.org.uk

services.name: Trident Reach
services.description:
Our Rough Sleeper's Outreach team in partnership with St Basils we operate across the whole city of Birmingham. We operate daily for a total of 15 hours per day (evening into night, and early mornings) the team cover the whole of Birmingham City. 

The main aims for the team is to engage people sleeping rough and guide them into the most effective support services that are appropriate to their needs. 

The team work alongside in partnership with other providers and take referrals from Streetlink as well as taking on referrals sent through by other professionals who call through to 0800 880 7157. 

To speak to a member of the Rough Sleeper’s Outreach team, please email rsot@tridentgroup.org.uk

services.name: Trident Reach
services.description:
Trident Reach provides confidential domestic abuse support in Birmingham. Services include a helpline, emergency refuge, long‑term accommodation, and a short‑stay respite room service. Support is trauma‑informed and tailored to each person’s needs. The service is inclusive, with options for women, men, and people with complex needs.

Contact: 
Helpline: 0800 111 4223 (Mon-Fri, 9 am-5 pm)
Emergency Refuge (Birmingham): Email BhamDAreferrals@tridentreach.org.uk
Respite Room Service: Call 0121 226 5800 or email RespiteRoomService@tridentreach.org.uk

services.name: Trident Reach
services.description:
Emergency Beds Provision

Trident Reach in partnership with St Basil’s we provide 50+ emergency beds - the only commissioned emergency bed provision in the city. As part of Birmingham City Council’s change in service delivery, Trident has moved towards a more localised emergency bed provision.

Our service is operated on an ‘immediate access’ basis which means those in need of housing can be assessed and provided with a room, with the aim to stabilise people assisting with finance, addictions, health and housing options. The aim is also to have done this within a 112 day period and move people on into more settled accommodation.

To speak to a member of the Emergency Bed Provision team, please call 0121 226 5832.

services.name: Samaritans - Birmingham
services.description:
The Samaritans are available by telephone all day, all night, any day of the year.

If you need someone to talk to, we listen. We won't judge or tell you what to do
Whatever you're going through, you can call us any time, from any phone for FREE.

Call: 116 123

This number is free to call from both landlines and mobiles, including pay-as-you-go mobiles. You do not need to have any credit or call allowance on your plan to call 116 123

What happens when you call us?
A volunteer will answer

If you phone us, we will answer with something like "Samaritans, can I help you?"
You talk, we listen

We listen to you and help you talk through your concerns, worries and troubles
We give you space to be yourself

We'll focus on your thoughts and feelings, and may ask questions to help you explore how you feel.
We won't tell you what you should do

We won't make decisions for you, our advice or opinions are not important for the call.

We offer a safe place for you to talk any time you like, in your own way - about whatever’s getting to you.

services.name: Shelter - Birmingham
services.description:
Shelter National Free Helpline

If you are an individual in need of urgent housing advice - for example, you are homeless or will become homeless in the next few days - please call our Helpline on 0808 800 4444 or speak to an advisor via our webchat
Our helpline operates between Monday- Friday - 8am-6pm (Closed bank holidays). 
It is useful to have documents ready before you call, like your tenancy agreement or relevant letters or messages
Keep trying if you can't get through. We're busy but we're here to help.

services.name: Shelter - Birmingham
services.description:
Legal Services at Shelter Birmingham

We have a Legal team who can help you if you are eligible for Legal Aid. For example, we might be able to help if you need to go to court about a housing problem or challenge a council’s homelessness decision.

If you require assistance with a legal matter within the next seven days - including a court hearing - or need an appointment with our Legal team, call 0344 515 1875 between the hours of 9am-5pm, Monday to Friday. 

PLEASE NOTE THIS NUMBER IS FOR NEW LEGAL APPOINTMENTS ONLY.

services.name: Choir With No Name - Birmingham
services.description:
We offer free singing workshops in Liverpool, London, Brighton, Birmingham, Coventry and Cardiff at homeless services, as well as for people at risk of homelessness ie. those with mental health problems, addiction issues, refugees and asylum seekers, ex-prisoners and vulnerable women.

Our one-off singing workshops usually run for an hour (although we can adapt to your specific requirements), and are a really enjoyable and engaging way for participants to experience the multiple benefits of singing to health and wellbeing, as well as a soft introduction to our choirs. 

If you would like to book a workshop in Birmingham, contact choir manager sally@choirwithnoname.org / 07794 100938

Our one-off singing workshops usually run for an hour (although we can adapt to your specific requirements), and are a really enjoyable and engaging way for participants to experience the multiple benefits of singing to health and wellbeing, as well as a soft introduction to our choirs. 

We also offer longer term singing projects, where participants attend weekly workshops over several weeks, culminating in a performance at the end - a brilliant way for people to not only experience the joys of singing together, but also have something to work towards with a real sense of collective achievement at the end.

Our workshops and singing projects are led by our professional choir directors and we usually have a couple of our choir members there too, to welcome participants and support them throughout the workshop. We sing well known pop and rock songs and you don't need any singing experience or musical ability to take part. It is a fantastic opportunity for participants to engage in a new communal activity, leave their troubles at the door and have fun!

If you would like to book a workshop in the Birmingham area please contact:
Birmingham: sally@choirwithnoname.org / 07794 100938

If you are a company and would like us to host a workplace singing workshop for your employees, then what we offer is slightly different. Please click HERE for more info.

services.name: Choir With No Name - Birmingham
services.description:
Choir With No Name - Birmingham has just moved to our fabulous new rehearsal venue at St Martins in the Bullring church right in the city centre. 

Rehearsals are every Thursday evening at 6pm. 

Become a Choir Member

Can you sing? No? Oh well, come along anyway! If you are or have been homeless, or you're struggling with something difficult in your life, the Choir is the perfect place to come and let off some steam and meet some fantastic new people. No singing experience necessary.

There’s no audition or anything, all you need to do is pop down to a rehearsal. If you like it and want to come back, we’ll be delighted, but if you don’t, then it’s no big deal. We won’t hassle you for anything when you arrive, we’ll just invite you to sing and to have an enjoyable evening in the company of others.

Our choirs are a supportive, safe space for people going through a tough time to be among friends, where they can experience the joy of singing together, have fun, build confidence and skills, and feel more able to tackle life's other challenges, such as securing housing or finding work.

We sing all kinds of well known, accessible pop music

We aim to...
have a brilliant time at rehearsals
give performances that leave the audience gagging for more
support each other in our dreams and ambitions, musical or otherwise.

services.name: Citizens Advice Birmingham
services.description:
We can help you make sense of the benefits system. 
Unsure of what you are entitled to claim? 
Has your benefit been reduced or stopped? 
Do you want to challenge the decision?

Citizens Advice Birmingham can give you practical support. We can
help you to work out your entitlement to benefits
help you to fill in the appropriate forms
help you to write review and appeal letters
provide benefit checks and ‘better off’ calculations
help you if you have to pay back overpayments
help you if you have been a victim of fraud.
 
To get information or advice: 
Look online
Call us: 0808 278 7990 

 
Get help applying for Universal Credit

Our Help to Claim service can support you in the early stages of your Universal Credit claim, from the application, through to your first payment.

Help to Claim is a dedicated service from Citizens Advice. It’s free, independent and confidential. Our trained advisers can help with things like how to gather evidence for your application or how to prepare for your work coach appointment.

Call us free: 0800 144 8444 (England) or 08000 241 220 (Wales)

For online advice visit: citizensadvice.org.uk/helptoclaim

services.name: Citizens Advice Birmingham
services.description:
Our team of specialist debt advisers can help you resolve your debt problems, whatever the cause or amount you owe. 
Many people struggle to manage their money, either because of increasing costs or due to a life-changing event, such as redundancy, illness or family breakdown. 

We will look at your situation and explore the options you can take to deal with your debts. Together we will agree a plan that's right for you.

We can help with longer term budgeting and money management advice so you can manage your money more effectively in the future. 

To get information or advice:
For debt enquiries only, contact the Debt Helpline on:
0300 330 2130 (9.00am - 1.00pm, Monday - Friday)
or email: debthelp@bcabs.cabnet.org.uk

services.name: Citizens Advice Birmingham
services.description:
Housing 
Housing problems can be complex and difficult to manage alone. You may be having problems keeping up with your mortgage payments, experiencing problems with your landlord, or simply having difficulties finding a place to live.

We can help you understand your rights and responsibilities and the steps you need to take to help avoid losing your home. 

We may be able to represent you in court if you are faced with eviction, through our Mortgage Repossession Service (see below)

To get information or advice:
Look online
Call us: 0808 278 7990

Mortgage Repossession

Our advisors, based in Birmingham County Court, help people who attend possession proceedings due to mortgage arrears and are facing losing their home. 

Everyone is entitled to be represented and we can put forward your case in court, on your behalf. We have a high success rate. In 2020-21, 83% of the people we helped were able to remain in their homes. 

We can also provide information and advice to help you to avoid facing this situation in the future.

You can also seek help from Shelter, through its helpline 0808 800 4444

services.name: Citizens Advice Birmingham
services.description:
Immigration control is a complex area of law. It concerns people who come to the UK, how and why they come, and what they can do when they are here. For example, whether they can study, seek work and how long they can stay. 

We can help you understand your rights and responsibilities and know what other help is available to you.

To get information or advice:
Look online
Call us: 0808 278 7990

services.name: Citizens Advice Birmingham
services.description:
Being in work is an important part of many people's lives. If you have a problem at work, it is important that you know your rights and responsibilities. 

We can help you solve problems you face with your employment, such as contract issues, unfair dismissal, or discrimination at work.

We can also tell you what support is available to you if you are seeking work.

To get information or advice:
Look online 
Call us: 0808 278 7990

services.name: St Chads Sanctuary
services.description:
St Chad's Sanctuary is a place of welcome for asylum seekers and refugees in the city of Birmingham

We do not operate a referral process. 

Asylum seekers and refugees are welcome to access our services for themselves. 

Other agencies are welcome to help them by explaining the information on the website, contacting us by phone for information or supporting them to access our services.

services.name: St Chads Sanctuary
services.description:
English classes at St Chad’s Sanctuary

Our English classes are for asylum seekers and refugees who are not able to get a place at college. If you already attend classes at another college, we can't offer you a place here too

Click here to register for our English Class

services.name: St Chads Sanctuary
services.description:
Conversation Club on Zoom

Our online conversation club is for Refugees and Asylum Seekers in Birmingham.

Conversation Club meets on Zoom on Wednesday mornings, 11.00 - 12.30 for English conversation in small groups. 

We have a different topic each week. Some examples of topics are food and cooking, weather and climate change, free time and hobbies, keeping healthy, and education and skills. 

This group is not suitable for beginners.

Click here to register for Conversation Club.

services.name: St Chads Sanctuary
services.description:
Who can get food from St Chad's Sanctuary?
Food can be collected from St Chad's Sanctuary once a week if you are an asylum seeker or refugee. You can either drop in during our operating hours or book an appointment
It is possible to arrange for food to be delivered if you are a refugee or asylum seeker who is isolating due to covid-19. Please get in touch if this is the case.

Who can get clothing from St Chad's Sanctuary?
If you are an asylum seeker or refugee living in Home Office hostels in Birmingham, the clothes need to to be ordered via an online form. Once the form has been completed, we will make contact to arrange an appointment for the clothes to be collected. 
For asylum seekers and refugees who are not living in home office hostels in Birmingham, you can collect clothing from St Chad's Sanctuary as long as you have not accessed this service within the last three months.

Please remember to bring ID with you

For more information and to see some Frequently Asked Questions, please take a look at our website

services.name: Birmingham and Solihull Womens Aid
services.description:
Every day, Birmingham and Solihull Women’s Aid helps women who make the difficult decision to ask for help and get in contact with us.

Our helpline team is specially trained to listen and help you if you are concerned about your safety, need to leave your home, worried about money, your health or wellbeing, or your children.

Contact our free Helpline on 0808 800 0028

services.name: Tabor House
services.description: Emergency Bed Accommodation

services.name: Birmingham Homeless Health Exchange - HeX (Primary Care Services for the Homeless)
services.description:
Mental Health and Counselling at The Health Exchange

We offer a full general practice service to those who are homeless or vulnerably housed who aged 16 and over and not pregnant. Once permanently housed it is expected (under normal circumstances) you will register with a local GP within 9 months.

The service provides:
Primary care mental health service including consultant psychiatrist, CPN and counselling

If you prefer to make an appointment to see any staff at the HeX, please speak to reception. A practice leaflet and a full list of opening times is available from reception

services.name: Birmingham Homeless Health Exchange - HeX (Primary Care Services for the Homeless)
services.description:
Nurse Led Prescribing Clinic at The Health Exchange

We offer drop-in with a prescribing nurse every afternoon between 1pm & 3.30pm or until the list is full. 

All drop-in clinics are run on a first come first served basis, once the list is full we cannot add any further patients to the list. 

If you prefer to make an appointment to see the doctor please speak to reception. A full list of opening times is available from reception.

services.name: Birmingham Homeless Health Exchange - HeX (Primary Care Services for the Homeless)
services.description:
Mental Health and Counselling at The Health Exchange

We offer a full general practice service to those who are homeless or vulnerably housed who aged 16 and over and not pregnant. Once permanently housed it is expected (under normal circumstances) you will register with a local GP within 9 months.

The service provides:
Primary care mental health service including consultant psychiatrist, CPN and counselling

If you prefer to make an appointment to see any staff at the HeX, please speak to reception. A practice leaflet and a full list of opening times is available from reception

services.name: Birmingham Homeless Health Exchange - HeX (Primary Care Services for the Homeless)
services.description:
Nurse Led Clinic at The Health Exchange
We offer a full general practice service to those who are homeless or vulnerably housed who aged 16 and over and not pregnant. Once permanently housed it is expected (under normal circumstances) you will register with a local GP within 9 months

We offer a nurse clinic with booked appointments every morning except Wednesday

If you prefer to make an appointment to see any staff at the Health Exchange please speak to reception. A practice leaflet and a full list of opening times is available from reception

services.name: Birmingham Homeless Health Exchange - HeX (Primary Care Services for the Homeless)
services.description:
Treatment for Drug and Alcohol dependency at The Health Exchange

We offer a full general practice service to those who are homeless or vulnerably housed who aged 16 and over and not pregnant. Once permanently housed it is expected (under normal circumstances) you will register with a local GP within 9 months.

The service provides:
Alcohol specialist nurses for assessment and treatment of alcohol problems

If you prefer to make an appointment to see any staff at the Health Exchange please speak to reception. A practice leaflet and a full list of opening times is available from reception.

services.name: Birmingham Homeless Health Exchange - HeX (Primary Care Services for the Homeless)
services.description:
GP services at The Health Exchange

We offer a full general practice service to those who are homeless or vulnerably housed who aged 16 and over and not pregnant. Once permanently housed it is expected (under normal circumstances) you will register with a local GP within 9 months.

The service provides:
Full registration with a General Practitioner

services.name: Special Care Community Dental Service for Homeless Adults in Birmingham
services.description:
Dental Service for Homeless Adults in Birmingham 
Free, walk-in dental care for homeless adults aged 16 and over. No referral is needed, but a referral form is available on the website if you’d like to share details with the dental team in advance

How it works 
Come to the clinic at 11am to collect an appointment ticket. Then return at 1:15pm with your ticket to be seen that afternoon. This helps manage the number of patients seen safely each day.

You’ll be asked about your medical history and any medications. NHS charges apply unless you’re exempt.

services.name: Alcoholics Anonymous UK
services.description:
AA meetings are sessions run by and for, alcoholics. There are two basic types of meetings, "open" and "closed". Anyone is welcome to attend an open meeting, while closed meetings are limited to addicts and to people who think they may have a problem with alcohol. 

A comprehensive list of meeting times, locations and descriptions for the Birmingham region can be found on the AA website.

services.name: Al-Anon family groups
services.description:
Al-Anon Family Groups meeting is about helping you to find solace with and support from others who have been affected by their relationship with a drinker.
Meeting day: Tuesday
Meeting time: 19:30
Accessibility: Disabled access
Parking: Disabled Parking only outside the building. Parking available around the back of the Citadel

Due to the Coronavirus (Covid-19) pandemic, groups are following Government and venue guidelines and may not be meeting face to face.

Helpline is available every day of the year from 10am to 10pm. 0800 0086 811

services.name: Birmingham Christmas Shelter
services.description:
Birmingham Christmas Shelter is operational from 
Wednesday, 24th December 2025 (10:00am) until 
Sunday, 28th December 2025 ( 10:00am)

Guests can use hot showers and get a free haircut during their stay. Footcare services are also available. These services help guests feel more comfortable, clean, and cared for during the festive period.

services.name: Birmingham Christmas Shelter
services.description:
The shelter offers entertainment and activities throughout the week, including music, games, and festive events. These create a warm, social space where guests can relax, connect with others, and enjoy the holiday atmosphere.

Birmingham Christmas Shelter is operational from 
Wednesday, 24th December 2025 (10:00am) until 
Sunday, 28th December 2025 ( 10:00am)

services.name: Birmingham Christmas Shelter
services.description:
Birmingham Christmas Shelter is operational from 
Wednesday, 24th December 2025 (10:00am) until 
Sunday, 28th December 2025 ( 10:00am) 

When the Birmingham Christmas Shelter is open, they serve guest three hot meals a day, including a vegetarian option at each meal, with very busy sandwich and tea bar facilities. No referral needed, guests need to be over the age of 16.

services.name: Birmingham Christmas Shelter
services.description:
Birmingham Christmas Shelter is operational from 
Wednesday, 24th December 2025 (10:00am) until 
Sunday, 28th December 2025 ( 10:00am)

Guests can use hot showers and get a free haircut during their stay. Footcare services are also available. These services help guests feel more comfortable, clean, and cared for during the festive period.

services.name: Forward Thinking Birmingham
services.description:
Pause is a service delivered by The Children's Society, in partnership with Forward Thinking Birmingham.

We provide access to immediate support & speak to an Emotional Wellbeing Practitioner. We listen to you and help you find solutions.

There are no referrals or waiting lists - you choose when and how to use our service.

services.name: Love Your Neighbour - Birmingham
services.description:
Christians Against Poverty Job Club 
We run the eight-week course to support people in their journey to employment. We can also arrange 1:1 meetings with our Job Club Manager, and employability events

services.name: Love Your Neighbour - Birmingham
services.description:
The Community Shop - we have pantry-style food provision, where clients pay GBP 4.50 and can take away a food shop of at least 10 items, including fresh food, and with their ticket they can get a free tea or coffee at Colmore Coffee whilst they wait. The shop has fresh fruit and veg, fresh meat and fresh dairy, as well as frozen and cupboard essentials.

To be a member of The Community Shop you must live within 1.6km of our building, and be in receipt of means-tested benefits including child tax credits and working tax credits. We will ask to see proof of this.

You can sign up to join The Community Shop via the Love Your Neighbour website

services.name: Love Your Neighbour - Birmingham
services.description:
We have a foodbank that can provide parcels on a Wednesday afternoon. 
To access the foodbank a household needs to be referred, the referral must be made by someone from an agency or organisation who has recognised the household is in crisis, for example, a support worker, social worker, teacher, faith leader, GP surgery etc. Please ask them to contact us at loveyourneighbour@gasstreet.church and we will set up a referral for you. Each referral means you will get three food parcels, one per week.

services.name: Love Your Neighbour - Birmingham
services.description:
Christian’s Against Poverty Debt Centre 
Meeting with those in debt by appointment, and supporting them to becoming debt free. 
For support from our CAP Debt Centre call 0800 328 0006

services.name: Christians Against Poverty (CAPUK)
services.description:
The CAP Job Club at Gas Street St Luke’s offers an eight-week course to help you find work. It includes CV writing, interview practice, and one-to-one coaching in a friendly group setting. The club is free and open to anyone looking for employment support.
Contact your local coach for more information: 
Nicky Sammons, Job club coach, nickysammons@capuk.org

services.name: Al-Anon family groups
services.description:
Al-Anon Family Groups meeting is about helping you to find solace with and support from others who have been affected by their relationship with a drinker.
Polish Speaking Group
Meeting day: Sunday
Meeting time: 11:30
Accessibility: No disabled access

All those affected by someone else's drinking are welcome to all meetings
Helpline is available every day of the year from 10am to 10pm. 0800 0086 811

services.name: Relate Birmingham and Black Country
services.description: Relate Birmingham & Black Country offers counselling for couples, families, individuals, children and young people. Specialist services include psychosexual therapy. Sessions are available in person, by phone or video call. You may be eligible for free or subsidised sessions. Contact us for more information.

services.name: Relate Birmingham and Black Country
services.description: Relate Birmingham & Black Country offers counselling for couples, families, individuals, children and young people. Specialist services include psychosexual therapy. Sessions are available in person, by phone or video call. You may be eligible for free or subsidised sessions. Contact us for more information.

services.name: The Refugee and Migrant Centre West Midlands [RMC]
services.description:
RMC provides free, regulated immigration advice and representation to migrants, asylum seekers, and refugees. Their team includes 40 OISC-accredited advisors, able to support cases up to Level 3, including representation at the First-tier and Upper Tribunal. They help people navigate complex immigration rules and secure the right to remain for themselves and their families.

NB they do not assist with passport applications or visas for other nations

services.name: The Refugee and Migrant Centre West Midlands [RMC]
services.description: RMC offers free English classes for asylum seekers and people who are unemployed or not working. Classes range from conversation groups to Entry 3 level and run on a rolling basis. Staff also support learners in progressing to accredited college courses when ready. For help with joining a class, email Steven at Steven@rmcentre.org.uk

services.name: The Refugee and Migrant Centre West Midlands [RMC]
services.description:
The Refugee and Migrant Centre (RMC) offers free, confidential support to asylum seekers, refugees, and migrants. You can attend their open drop-in service on Monday, Tuesday, Thursday, and Friday mornings between 9am-1pm. Appointments are given on a first-come, first-served basis, but emergencies are prioritised.

Or phone 0800 0663 444

services.name: The Refugee and Migrant Centre West Midlands [RMC]
services.description: RMC provides practical support to help clients access the healthcare they need. A health caseworker is based at each office, and in Wolverhampton, a resident community psychiatric nurse is available to support with mental health needs. Staff can help arrange GP or dentist appointments, navigate the NHS, and resolve more complex health access issues. For support, you can drop in or speak to a team member.

services.name: The Refugee and Migrant Centre West Midlands [RMC]
services.description:
The Refugee and Migrant Centre (RMC) offers free, confidential support to asylum seekers, refugees, and migrants. You can attend their open drop-in service on Monday, Tuesday, Thursday, and Friday mornings between 9am-1pm. Appointments are given on a first-come, first-served basis, but emergencies are prioritised.

Or phone 0800 0663 444

services.name: The Refugee and Migrant Centre West Midlands [RMC]
services.description: RMC offers tailored support to help people achieve their personal goals through skills development, learning opportunities, and gaining experience. They can help with CVs, careers advice, digital skills, and access to education for adults and children. If you need support, you can ask for Victoria at the Bimringham centre or email her directly at victoria@rmcentre.org.uk

services.name: The Refugee and Migrant Centre West Midlands [RMC]
services.description: RMC provides advice in multiple languages to help people understand what financial support they’re entitled to. Whether you're working, unemployed, disabled, a parent, or an older person, RMC can support you in applying for the right benefits, accessing grants, and dealing with benefit-related issues.

services.name: The Refugee and Migrant Centre West Midlands [RMC]
services.description: RMC supports vulnerable clients facing housing issues, homelessness, or destitution. Advisors can help you understand your housing options, apply for emergency or supported housing, and access essential items like food and funds. If you’re in urgent need, drop in to the Wolverhampton centre for advice and support.

services.name: Birmingham LGBT
services.description:
Counselling at Birmingham LGBT

We offer services for people that are experiencing issues with their sexual health, sexuality or gender, providing free counselling to men, women and non-binary people.

We provide affirmative counselling, which means we will help you to explore who you are from your perspective and without an agenda of our own. You are the expert in yourself, and our role is to help you understand yourself more clearly and confidently.

We offer two different counselling routes
LGBT Counselling - this is a more generic service for LGBT people (living in Birmingham or Solihull) who are experiencing emotional difficulties that may or may not relate to being part of the LGBT community;
Trans Inclusion Counselling - this is a service specifically for trans, non-binary and gender questioning people (living in the West Midlands) experiencing concerns with their gender identity.

You are free to choose whichever service would be best for you.
There is no charge for our counselling services.

To find out more, please visit our website

Refer yourself 
Contact 0121 643 0821 or email counselling@blgbt.org

services.name: Birmingham LGBT
services.description:
Birmingham LGBT provides specialist support for LGBT people who are experiencing, or at risk of, female genital mutilation (FGM). The team offers a safe, confidential space to talk through concerns, understand your options and receive practical and emotional support. They won’t pressure you or make decisions for you - their aim is to help you feel informed, safer and more supported. 

You can get in touch through the website form, by calling 0121 643 0821, or emailing idva@blgbt.org

services.name: Birmingham LGBT
services.description:
Birmingham LGBT offers specialist support for LGBT people who are experiencing, or at risk of, forced marriage or honour-based abuse. The team provides a safe, confidential space to talk about what’s happening, explore your options and get practical and emotional support. They won’t pressure you to make any particular decision - their role is to help you feel informed, safer and more in control. 

You can contact the service through the website form, by calling 0121 643 0821, or emailing idva@blgbt.org

services.name: Birmingham LGBT
services.description:
LGBT Independent Sexual Violence Advocacy (ISVA) Service - RSVP Partnership 
This service is delivered in partnership with RSVP and offers practical and emotional support to LGBT+ people who have experienced rape, sexual assault or sexual abuse, whether recent or in the past. Specialist LGBT Independent Sexual Violence Advocates (ISVAs), based at the LGBT Centre, provide a safe, respectful space to talk and help you understand your options. They can support you through any decisions you choose to make, including reporting to the police, and offer advocacy, liaison with other agencies, and help to access wider support around health, mental health, work, family, housing, finances, addictions and safety. The service is inclusive of all genders and sexualities and is led by your wishes.

How to refer or self-refer 
You can contact the specialist LGBT ISVA, Beverley Higgins, for an appointment, informal discussion or referral by:
Calling 0121 643 0301 and pressing option 2
Emailing isva@rsvporg.co.uk

They will talk with you about what has happened, what you’re looking for, and what kind of support would feel most helpful.

services.name: Birmingham LGBT
services.description:
The Trans Wellbeing service offers a safe, confidential space for trans and non-binary people to talk about anything affecting their emotional wellbeing. It focuses on confidence, connection and steady support through life’s challenges, helping people feel more grounded and less alone.

How to Refer or Self-Refer 
You can self-refer by completing the short form found via a link on the Birmingham LGBT website, or you can contact the team directly by emailing wellbeing@blgbt.org
 or calling 0121 643 0821. 

If you’re a worker supporting someone, you can refer them with their consent. The team will then arrange an initial conversation to understand what would help. No diagnosis or formal paperwork is needed.

services.name: Birmingham LGBT
services.description:
Birmingham LGBT’s wellbeing service offers a safe, confidential space for LGBTQ+ people to talk through worries, low mood or life pressures with someone who understands. It’s gentle, relational support that helps people feel more grounded and connected. 

You can access support either face-to-face, by telephone or online and you will have dedicated time to discuss your interests, needs or concerns.

If you feel that our wellbeing support could benefit you, you can contact us by telephone, email or by coming into Birmingham LGBT.

Contact us, for more details or to book a wellbeing assessment, on 0121 643 0821 or email wellbeing@blgbt.org.

services.name: Birmingham LGBT
services.description:
Birmingham LGBT’s domestic violence service 
This service supports LGBT people in Birmingham and the West Midlands who are experiencing abuse from partners, ex-partners or family members. 

The service offers a safe, non-judgemental space to talk, with crisis intervention, advocacy, safety planning and practical support. The focus is on empowering you to make informed decisions, not telling you what to do.

How to Refer or Self-Refer 
Call 0121 643 0821 for help or to arrange support. 
Or email idva@blgbt.org.
You can also use the Contact page on our website

services.name: Birmingham LGBT
services.description:
Birmingham LGBT Services
We offer a range of services and activities for the LGBT Community in Birmingham and beyond. Including sexual health, events, domestic violence, counselling, support, arts and more.

Visit our website to find out more and how to access our services. or get in touch 
Call | 0121 643 0821 
Email | hello@blgbt.org

services.name: Birmingham LGBT
services.description:
Sexual Health testing drop-in service
Free service for LGBTQ+ people living in Birmingham and Solihull only.
Information and support with self-testing kits, and an HIV test while you wait.
Free condoms and lube available.

services.name: Birmingham LGBT
services.description:
Step by Step is a weekly, supportive group for LGBTQ+ people who want to explore their relationship with drugs or alcohol in a calm, understanding space. Run by Birmingham LGBT, it focuses on gentle progress, wellbeing and connection - the kind of early support that helps people stay steady before things escalate.

How to Access 
You can contact the team directly by emailing SubstanceSupport@blgbt.org
 or by calling or texting 07549 296 713. Workers can also refer someone in with consent. The group is free, confidential and rooted in community care.

services.name: StreetVet Birmingham
services.description:
Animal Welfare and Vet Service

StreetVet Birmingham provides free veterinary treatment to the pets belonging to people experiencing homelessness in the city.

The service runs every first Sunday of the month. 6:45pm to 7:30pm

Volunteer With Us

If you are interested in volunteering with StreetVet Birmingham, please fill in the Volunteer Expression of Interest Form: https://www.streetvet.co.uk/volunteer-expression-of-interest-form/

services.name: Turnaround West Midlands
services.description:
Turnaround West Midlands provide free, non-judgemental and confidential support for sex workers working in Birmingham. 
Find out more and how to self refer via our website

services.name: Smart Works Birmingham
services.description:
At the heart of Smart Works sits a dressing and coaching service designed to help our clients be the best version of themselves at a crucial moment in their lives.

The women who come to Smart Works are referred from Job Centres, mental health charities, women’s refuges, homeless shelters, the prison service, care service and youth organisations.

Each client receives a bespoke dressing consultation with two trained volunteers, to find a beautiful and high-quality interview outfit that will fill her with confidence. This is free of charge and the clothes are hers to keep

Once a job is secured, Smart Works provide a second dressing for a capsule collection of clothes to wear to work.

Our service is completely free. It is for any woman with a confirmed job interview who is referred to us. Ask your employment advisor or someone who is helping you to find work to refer you to Smart Works. 

They can make a quick call to 0121 643 8109 and we can make you an appointment at our centre in Birmingham.

services.name: Smart Works Birmingham
services.description:
The dressing session is followed by a one-to-one coaching session with an expert interview coach, where each client receives valuable interview preparation. This part of the appointment is a chance to speak honestly and openly, in a safe and private space. It is an opportunity to work one-to-one with a trusted coach, about anything that might be concerning you before a job interview.

 

We also offer Career Coaching which helps unemployed women secure a job interview. In each session, trained coaches work with clients to identify tangible next steps to maximise their chances of securing an interview.

 

Every woman who comes to Smart Works is referred by another organisation or charity who is supporting her on the journey to employment. This makes sure we are reaching the women who will most benefit from our service.

services.name: Dogs Trust Hope Project
services.description: Free vet care for people experiencing homelessness with dogs. Available through partner vets in Birmingham.

services.name: UK Mens Sheds Association
services.description:
Men’s Sheds are kitted out community spaces where men can enjoy practical hobbies.

They’re about making friends, learning and sharing skills. Many guys come just for the tea and banter - everyone’s welcome.

Men’s Sheds are kitted out community spaces where men can enjoy practical hobbies.

They’re about making friends, learning and sharing skills. Many guys come just for the tea and banter - everyone’s welcome.

WM Postive Pathways: Universal Prevention & Move On Support

services.name: Big Issue Birmingham and West Midlands
services.description:
Big Issue offers self‑employment opportunities for people facing homelessness or financial hardship. Vendors buy magazines for GBP 2 and sell them for GBP 4, keeping the profit. This flexible role builds confidence, work experience and money management skills. Support is also available with housing, benefits, and personal goals. 

If you would like to become a big issue vendor to help you on the path out of homelessness, get in touch with the midlands regional office on 0121 236 1936

https://www.bigissue.com/become-a-vendor/

services.name: Home Start Birmingham
services.description:
Home-Start - Support for parents and families
Being a parent has never been easy. It can be lonely, frustrating, heart breaking and over-whelming. 
All parents struggle at one time or another. You are not alone.
Home-Start’s expert staff and trained volunteers work alongside families just like yours to give non-judgmental, compassionate and confidential support.
They help you regain confidence and be the parent you want to be. Below are some of the areas we can help with.
A volunteer to support you 
Home-Start volunteers understand how hard it can be to be a parent. They work alongside parents, usually in their own homes, to help them cope with the stresses and strains of life and make sure they have the skills, confidence and strength they need to nurture their children.

Group support 
Many Home-Starts run specialist groups to provide further support, and social connection, for parents. They may also run groups for babies and children so that they can play together, while also giving parents a chance to meet others going through the same kind of experience.

Parental mental health and perinatal illness 
More than a third of parents we support ask for our help to cope with perinatal illness, their own or their child's mental ill-health.

Money issues 
We help families with organising their money if they find it overwhelming or if it's hard to make ends meet.

When a relationship ends 
If you are trying to cope after a separation, divorce, or after leaving an abusive relationship...

If you think that you could benefit from the support of a Home-Start volunteer then you can get in touch with your local Home-Start yourself
Other people may be referred to their local Home-Start by a health visitor, doctor or other professional.

services.name: Growbaby [Birmingham Vineyard]
services.description:
Growbaby @ Birmingham Vineyard

Our store rooms are open one day a week during term time for a walk-in service, where you will be offered a hot drink, a warm welcome, and a chance to browse our clothes and equipment.

To check if we have specific items in stock, 
message: 07492233654 or 
email growbaby@birminghamvineyard.com

This is a drop in, no appointment is needed to attend our city centre venue

City centre GrowBaby offer the following lightly used 2nd hand items:
clothes & coats ages 0-5yrs
shoes
sleeping bags
moses baskets
high chairs
baby baths
bouncy chairs
play mats
toys
weaning equipment 
breast pumps
baby sling/ carriers 
bottles
sippy cups
books 
newborn essentials - bibs, muslin cloths

And the following new items:
nappies, wipes and nappy sacks
baby bath, shampoo & moisturiser
maternity essentials - breast pads, maternity pads, cotton wool balls etc

We don't hand out car seats, cots, stair gates or formula milk.

For pushchairs we require an email referral from a support worker or health visitor to be added to our waiting list. Emails can be sent to growbaby@birminghamvineyard.com 

Families are welcome to attend a maximum of once a month for nappies and every few months for clothes and toys. 

At our location we also encourage attendance to our stay and play group that runs on Friday mornings 10-11.30am. No booking required. Parents can have a hot drink, meet some other parents living locally and the children have the opportunity to play with the toys, make a craft and have a snack.

services.name: Incredible Surplus
services.description:
Ladywood

Originally established in 2014 as The Real Junk Food Project Birmingham, we intercept food and other usable materials that would otherwise go to waste from supermarkets, restaurants and other sources, and provide them to individuals and community organisations on a “Pay-As-You-Feel” basis.

We welcome everyone that wants to come and shop with us at our Ladywood Site

Food Bag Distribution
Wednesdays and Fridays 12pm-2pm
At Ladywood Health and Community Centre

services.name: National Debtline
services.description:
To make sure we give you the best advice for your circumstances we need to know more about you.
We will ask you about your income and spending. You need to have this information to hand if you call. You might find it easier to complete our online budget before you call us.
We will also need details of who you owe money to and how much you owe them.

Our advisers will help you to work out what you can afford to pay towards your debt and help you to find the right debt solution.

Call us on 0808 808 4000 or (webchat)[https://www.nationaldebtline.org/contact-us/] with an adviser

Monday to Friday: 9am - 8pm, Saturday: 9:30am -1pm

services.name: Crisis Skylight Birmingham
services.description:
Crisis Skylight Birmingham coaches can provide help around 
Employment, Education and Training 
CV writing 
Confidence building 
Money management 
Job searching 
Access to training and education 
Personal development 
Volunteering

services.name: Homeless Health Peer Advocacy Service
services.description:
One-to-one support to access physical and mental health services, provided by trained Peer Advocates with lived experience of homelessness.

If you would like support, please email us on healthpeeradvocacy@crisis.org.uk or call us at 0121 348 7950 

If you would like to refer someone to our service, please email healthpeeradvocacy@crisis.org.uk to request a referral form

services.name: Crisis Skylight Birmingham
services.description:
Crisis Skylight Birmingham has a team of coaches with specialist knowledge to help our members prevent or relieve their homelessness. 

Housing Advocacy 
Finding suitable accommodation
Support with housing issues
Completing housing applications
Support with managing and maintaining accommodation

If you would like to engage in our services, please contact us and we will be happy to help.

services.name: Non Violentiam CIC
services.description: Accommodation for vulnerable adults and victims of domestic violence

services.name: Fatima House
services.description: Safe shelter for female asylum seekers who would otherwise be destitute and homeless

services.name: Cranstoun Housing Support [Birmingham]
services.description:
CRANSTOUN HOUSING SOLUTIONS are commissioned by Birmingham City Council to provide support for men and women fleeing domestic violence in the city. 

The Domestic Abuse Housing Solutions & Support Service is available to male and female victim-survivors of domestic abuse, with or without children, needing to access support, advice and accommodation with the aim of preventing or relieving homelessness.
Cranstoun’s team of specialist workers will be able to provide advice and support for people considering their options in fleeing domestic abuse, ensuring their current home is safe, ensuring people know their rights and helping find accommodation.
We also offer a women’s only space where people will be able to access the service (Location details restricted - please contact us by telephone in the first instance)

What you can expect when you access Housing Solutions
Our trauma-informed staff will take details about you and your family’s circumstances, giving you time and space to tell us your story.
We will ask whether you would like support to remain safe in your current home, if you need urgent (emergency) accommodation, or if you wish for a planned move to other accommodation.
We can support you with making housing applications, contacting accommodation providers, applying for legal orders against the perpetrator of abuse, safety planning, applying for funds to prevent your homelessness due to domestic abuse as well as onward referrals to other support agencies

How to Access Support
If you or someone you know is experiencing domestic abuse and needs support in Birmingham, you can contact Cranstoun's Birmingham Housing Solutions Service between 9am and 5pm Monday to Friday at the following:
•	Phone: 0121 272 8905 
•	Email: BHMHousingSolutions@cranstoun.org.uk

Cranstoun is committed to providing compassionate and expert support to ensure the safety and well-being of all individuals affected by domestic abuse. For more information, you can visit their official website at Domestic Abuse Support | Victims & Survivors | Cranstoun 
https://cranstoun.org/help-and-advice/domestic-abuse/birmingham-housing-solutions/

services.name: Cranstoun Housing Support [Birmingham]
services.description:
Housing Support Services at Cranstoun, Birmingham

Everyone has a right to a home. Cranstoun helps those who are struggling with housing and offers support to create healthier, safer environments for you to thrive.

We work with 
entrenched rough sleepers
those that are struggling to sustain their tenancy
those that are searching for housing stability 
those transitioning from shared facility housing to independent living.

The housing services Cranstoun can offer are
Housing First 
Housing First supports entrenched rough sleepers in Birmingham to secure, settle into, and sustain their own accommodation.
Birmingham Housing 
Cranstoun’s Lead worker and Floating Support services provide community-based floating support to Birmingham residents, assisting them to sustain the accommodation and/or find suitable alternative accommodation, preventing homelessness. 
The floating support is provided for : 
people experiencing domestic abuse 
for people experiencing mental health issues 
for single people experiencing or at risk of homelessness 
families

referrals into the service can be done via the website

https://cranstoun.org/help-and-advice/domestic-abuse/birmingham-housing-solutions/

services.name: Clifton Road Food Bank
services.description:
We aim to provide provisions to last a minimum of 3 days depending on the size of the family. In addition to the regular care package, our guests can also choose a number of items from the display shelfs. These include coffee, tea, oil, sugar, salt, cans of fruits and vegetables, soups, pasta rice etc. By offering a choice of foods we believe we can exercise some choice in our users diet. We are mindful of trying to balance choice with healthy living.

Please note, on arrival at CRFB you will be required to register and eligibility for our service will be assessed. Therefore, please remember to bring proof of your welfare entitlement or financial situation. We try our best not to turn anyone away.

services.name: Money Ready - Midlands Hub
services.description:
Money Ready is a UK-wide financial education charity offering free, expert-led programmes to help people manage their money with confidence. 

In the Midlands, we deliver tailored sessions for schools, youth groups, and community organisations, covering topics like budgeting, saving, debt, and digital finance. 

Programmes are available for children, young people, and adults, including those in or leaving care, and individuals at risk of financial hardship. 

Click here for more info about our young adult programmes suitable for those who are aged 16-25

Click here for our adult programmes suitable for those who are aged 18-37

services.name: St Basils
services.description:
St Basil’s Birmingham Youth Hub supports young people aged 16-25 who are at risk of homelessness. The Hub offers face-to-face advice and guidance for those dealing with insecure housing, mental or physical health issues, substance misuse, offending behaviour, or fleeing domestic violence. Staff assess individual needs and provide support or referrals to appropriate services.

To book an appointment:

Call our Youthline: 0300 303 0099 (free from landlines)
Email: youthline@stbasils.org.uk
Texting free from mobiles: ‘Need St Basils‘ to 62277

Young people can get help with securing and maintaining accommodation, accessing education or employment, and improving wellbeing. BYH also offers advocacy, mediation, and support with benefits, debt advice, and building community connections.
