services.name: St Basils
services.description: St Basils offers family mediation to help young people stay at home where it is safe to do so. The focus is on improving communication, not taking sides. Staff may refer young people to mediation services in some areas. St Basils also runs projects that use psychological approaches to support parents and strengthen family relationships.

services.name: Change Grow Live [CGL] Birmingham
services.description:
We offer free and confidential advice and information around alcohol and drugs at CGL Birmingham

If you’re worried about your alcohol or drug use, and want to make some positive changes, we’re here to help. You can make an appointment to talk to us during our opening hours - please give us a call on 0121 227 5890.

The Birmingham Central and West Hub supports people in Aston, Handsworth, Holyhead, Ladywood, Lozells, Nechells, Newtown, Oscott, Perry Barr, Soho & Jewellery Quarter, and surrounding areas

services.name: Change Grow Live [CGL] Birmingham
services.description:
We offer free and confidential Drug and Alcohol Recovery Treatment at CGL Birmingham

Alcohol

Everyone’s journey from alcohol problems is different. The right treatment for you will depend on your experiences and your current situation

Your Recovery Coordinator will create your care plan with you to help you make use of your strengths and achieve your goals

Treatment pathways may include
Support to help you cut down your drinking, step by step, if you are not at risk of withdrawal
Recovery Groups and Meetings, a chance for people with similar experiences to help and inspire each other through peer support
Alcohol Detox for those who are dependent
Medication to manage withdrawal symptoms

Drugs

Everyone’s recovery from an addiction to drugs is different. The best course of treatment for you will depend on your experiences and your situation.
Your Recovery Coordinator will create your care plan with you to help you make use of your strengths and achieve your goals

Treatment pathways may include
Support to help you cut down and quit your drug use, step by step, if you are not at risk of withdrawal
Recovery Groups and Meetings, a chance for people with similar experiences to help and inspire each other through peer support
Detoxification and rehabilitation options are available - a drug or alcohol detox will help you to either switch safely from a drug to a medication or come off drugs altogether. Detox can be part of a bigger recovery plan, and a medical professional will manage and guide you through it. You can complete a detox in our hubs or in one of our residential detox units. Residential detox can be followed by an extended programme of in-patient rehabilitation with providers located outside of the Birmingham area.
Medication - If you’re dependent on heroin or another opioid, you might get a prescription for medication-assisted treatment such as methadone or buprenorphine. You can use this medication to help you cut down or stop using. If you come to one of our services and decide medication is the right option for you, we will work with you to make sure you are on the right dose

You can make an appointment to talk to us during our opening hours
Please give us a call on 0121 227 5890.

The Birmingham Central and West Hub supports people in Aston, Handsworth, Holyhead, Ladywood, Lozells, Nechells, Newtown, Oscott, Perry Barr, Soho & Jewellery Quarter, and surrounding areas

services.name: Change Grow Live [CGL] Birmingham
services.description:
Needle Exchange Services @ CGL Birmingham

Needle Exchange and Naloxone are available from all our hubs during building opening hours. 

Please give us a ring on 0121 227 5890 if you’d like to collect either.

Did you know you can get needle exchange supplies posted to your door for free?
We'll simply give you a code so you can log in online and order.
Don't have access to the internet? 
You can also order over the phone Get in touch today 

The Birmingham Central and West Hub supports people in Aston, Handsworth, Holyhead, Ladywood, Lozells, Nechells, Newtown, Oscott, Perry Barr, Soho & Jewellery Quarter, and surrounding areas

services.name: Birmingham Crisis Centre
services.description:
This 24hr helpline is available to ANY women and their children who are victims of domestic violence and are seeking refuge, help, advice and support .

Just call this number and speak to one of our fully trained support workers who are always standing by for your call !

 0121 507 0707

services.name: Birmingham Crisis Centre
services.description:
Birmingham Crisis Centre Counselling Service for Female Victims of Domestic Violence

Birmingham Crisis Centre offers confidential counselling for women affected by domestic violence, providing a safe space to talk and find ways to cope. Support is delivered one-to-one by trained counsellors and key workers, following the British Association for Counselling and Psychotherapy’s ethical framework. 
Referral pathway 
Women can self-refer by calling 0121 507 0707 for help and advice

services.name: SIFA Fireside
services.description:
SIFA Fireside provides breakfast Monday-Friday.
Breakfast from 9:00am
Lunch from 12 noon

services.name: SIFA Fireside
services.description:
We strive for early intervention and homelessness prevention for single adults and childless couples aged over 25 in Birmingham. We provide tailor-made services for each individual’s set of unique circumstances. This can range from offering money and welfare benefits advice, health and wellbeing services and guidance with regards to specialist housing.

Maintaining employment is, of course, an integral part of preventing homelessness which is why SIFA Fireside hosts Job Clubs and CV workshops, English Language sessions and regularly signposts clients to employability training and budgeting workshops.

services.name: SIFA Fireside
services.description:
SIFA Fireside’s Recovery service offers a flexible approach to enable our clients to access education, training, employment and volunteering opportunities.
We offer a range of workshops around employability that include CV writing and interview techniques.
We address wider issues by offering workshops around budgeting, IT skills and healthy eating.
At different times we run drama and art programmes and other activities include cookery, football, meditation and relaxations.
There is a weekly Job Club where clients can look for jobs online, create universal job match accounts, e-mail addresses and get support to complete job applications.
Clients are able to benefit from one-to-one advice and mentoring.
We also operate an outreach service to local hostels and other organisations.
Support to sustain tenancies to prevent further homelessness.

services.name: SIFA Fireside

services.name: SIFA Fireside
services.description:
We all need support sometimes. SIFA Fireside is here for you when it feels like no-one else is. If you need support, here’s what we can do for you. 

Our Support Centre welcomes individuals over the age of 25 who are rough sleeping or in need of emergency support from 9am onwards, Monday - Friday. 

There, you’ll find job clubs, community nurse appointments, English language lessons, barber visits, cooking classes, budgeting workshops and more.

 From a hot meal and a warm shower to Tenancy Support, Employment Support and much more, we are here to get you back on track.

services.name: Chinese Community Centre - Birmingham
services.description:
The Chinese Community Centre in Birmingham supports people in accessing all welfare benefits and public services to which they are legally entitled to, in order to eradicate or minimise disadvantage and exclusion.

We provide advice and information on matters such as:
Social Welfare Benefits
Social Housing
Education and School Places
Access Health and Social Care services
Disability Support
Older People’s needs
Immigration (by a pro bono, qualified Immigration lawyer) 
General enquiries

Please Note: Our Information, Advice & Guidance service is available to everyone at a fee, with a reduced fee for members. Those with financial hardship, please still speak to us as we may be able to reduce or waive the fees. We will advise you of the fees before confirming appointments

For any questions or for further information please email service@ccc-b.org.uk

Mobile & WhatsApp: 07536 171393
WeChat ID: cccbham /WeChat Mobile No.: 0044 7536 171393

services.name: Vision Care for Homeless People
services.description: Vision Care for Homeless People run their clinics every Monday morning from 9am until 1pm at SIFA Fireside in Digbeth. Just go along if you would like to book an eye test. It is completely free of charge, as are any frames or lenses if the optician finds that you are long or short sighted. To find out when the next clinic is running or to make an appointment call 0121 766 1700, visit the SIFA Fireside reception desk or send an email to office@sifafireside.co.uk

services.name: Birmingham Care Group
services.description:
A free warm welcome space. All welcome 
Toast || Wifi || Hot Drinks || Conversation

services.name: Birmingham Care Group
services.description:
The BCG Food Pantry is here to bridge the gap between food banks and supermarkets by helping local residents with their weekly food shops. 

If you are feeling the financial impact of rising living costs then we are here to help. 
We have an annual membership of GBP 15, it’s GBP 5 a shop and you can shop up to 2 times a week. 

Find our more on our website

services.name: St Annes Hostel
services.description:
We provide support services for our residents. We can refer to outside agencies for substance misuse support. We can help our residents find permanent move-on accommodation. 
Good quality, 24 hour, direct access accommodation for homeless men over 25 years of age.
A safe and secure environment where we can offer a service which meets the immediate welfare needs of our residents
A signposting service to agencies appropriate to each resident’s individual needs
Encouragement in obtaining and then retaining move-on accommodation
A range of welfare services and advice to the homeless in Birmingham

Referring New Residents

St Anne’s takes referrals 24 hours a day, 365 days a year, if a vacancy is available.

We cater for single males 25 years old and over. There is no upper limit although residents need to be fully mobile and have only low needs. To secure accommodation they will need proof of income and identification.

The service charge we ask for covers utility costs, half board which includes breakfast and dinner and access to a support worker who will work with individuals to reach personal goals and ultimately move on into independent living. We also have an activity co-ordinator who will be looking at constructive activities with residents with a view to help build life skills and reduce isolation.

Please call 0121 772 4406 if you wish to see if a vacancy is available or you have any questions around referring.

services.name: St. Anne's Hostel
services.description: St. Anne&39;s is a hostel for homeless men 25 years old and over plus their canine companions. They take referrals 24 hours a day, 365 days a year

services.name: Miss Macaroon
services.description: Miss Macaroon’s Macaroons that Make a Difference (MacsMAD) is a free training programme for unemployed young adults aged 18-35. It supports people facing barriers like mental health issues, disability, homelessness, or an offending history. Trainees gain kitchen experience, qualifications, counselling, and mentoring. The programme runs for 7.5-10 weeks and includes up to six months of post-course support.

services.name: Birmingham Hope Community Pantry [ Your Local Pantry Network ]
services.description:
For just GBP 5 a week (only when you shop), you can get up to GBP 20 worth of groceries at our pantry.

Here’s how it works: 
You’ll receive 7 diamonds and 3 hearts to spend on 10 items.
Some items cost more, others less (look out for offers like “2 for 1 diamond”.)
We also have additional free items available. 
Our volunteers are here to help and happy to answer any questions. 
You're also welcome to visit our coffee lounge next door and enjoy a hot drink while you're here.

services.name: Birmingham City Mission
services.description: Providing for those in need, The BCM Resource Centre distributes essential goods including food, clothing and furniture

services.name: Karis Neighbour Scheme
services.description:
Karis BabyBank

Karis BabyBank is a project of Karis Neighbour Scheme supporting Birmingham mothers who are struggling to meet the financial cost of having a new baby.

Karis BabyBank is a provision for families with newborns and infants who are facing hardship and/or crisis which means they need help with essentials for their baby. This provision is based on referrals from other organisations and groups who are well placed to assess the need and identify what items families need, this includes social workers, children’s centres, health workers and other charities.

Our focus is on supporting families in and around the Ladywood area, although we do work with referral agencies more widely where there is acute need.

We currently support well over 400 families a year through this provision

You can find out more about the items we are able to provide 
on the Karis Babybank Facebook page

Referral Agencies 
Karis Baby Bank works with midwives, health visitors. social services and other professional groups in the Ladywood area to provide much needed essentials and equipment to mothers and families in need in the local area and to very vulnerable families across the city 

If you work with families in and around the Ladywood area and would like to find out if you could be a referral agency please contact 
Ruth Pedzai, Children & Families Project Co-ordinator 
ruth.pedzai@karisneighbourscheme.org for more details.

services.name: Karis Neighbour Scheme
services.description:
Karis Neighbour Scheme and The Ladywood Community Advice service

The Ladywood Community Advice service is an easy to access advice service for people living in Ladywood and the surrounding areas.
LCA helps many people in complex situations, often with chronic ill health, homelessness or language barriers

If you’re having problems with your benefits and need help or advice about this, or are struggling with filling in forms, then you’re welcome to come and see us.

We can also help to explain letters you’ve received, or help you to contact bodies like the council or utility providers if you have an issue or need to find out information.

Last but not least we can also signpost you to other specialist advice services if you have issues we’re unable to help with.

If you’d like to make an appointment to see our Money Advisor please call on 0121 454 8994 or 0121 455 7524.

services.name: Karis Neighbour Scheme
services.description:
Karis BeFriends

The Karis BeFriends project supports older people living in Ladywood, Harborne and Edgbaston, who feel isolated or lonely. We visit people regularly, so that you have someone to talk to and can get a helping hand when you need it.

Our befrienders can come and sit and chat over a cup of tea, or maybe take up a hobby you enjoy, or accompany you out for a walk or to get to an appointment. We can also help with sorting through post or making phone calls.

Alongside this we also arrange regular social activities in the community, giving you chance to get out and connect with others. From our Time for Tea afternoon teas, held bi-monthly at Queen Alexandra College in Harborne, and our weekly Senior Life Group, held at Oasis Church in Harborne on Tuesdays, to coffee afternoons, trips out and Christmas parties. We also run a weekly Art Group which takes place every two weeks at our main office in Ladywood. It’s a relaxed and friendly environment led by one of our experienced volunteers.

We want you to feel connected and supported and encouraged to continue to flourish later in life.

For more information on any of the activities, or befriending, please contact Helen or Patti on 0121 455 7524 or e-mail helen.bell@karisneighbourscheme.org.

services.name: Karis Neighbour Scheme
services.description:
Karis Befriends Advice

Karis BeFriends Advice can make sure you are getting the right benefits and offer other advice and support for people over 50 who are living in the Ladywood, Edgbaston or Harborne wards of Birmingham.

We can visit you at home to check whether you are getting the benefits you are entitled to, help with new applications, go through letters and make phone calls with you, as well as looking at additional help like the Warm Home Discount scheme.

Alongside advice around benefits and other issues, we can also connect you with other activities and services locally which you may need or be interested in.

To speak to our advisor, please call 0121 455 7524 or email katharine.harris@karisneighbourscheme.org, Katharine will make an initial appointment to visit you to discuss what areas you need advice and how best we can help.

services.name: British Red Cross
services.description:
If you are a refugee, asylum seeker or vulnerable migrant, we may be able to help you 

The British Red Cross is the UK’s largest independent provider of services and support for refugees and people seeking asylum.

We offer emergency help, one-to-one support and casework, special services for children and families, and family reunions.

If you are a refugee or asylum seeker in the UK who needs help, or someone who works with refugees and people seeking asylum, our teams will speak to you and help you figure out what you need.

We can offer help from the Red Cross, or refer you to other organisations for support.

Practical help for refugees and asylum seekers in the UK
We can help refugees by giving essentials including:
food
small amounts of cash
toiletries 
We also offer specialist services for young refugees and asylum seekers.

The Red Cross helps refugees of every religion, and none, and we will not report you to the authorities.

For more information about the support we can off you as an seeker of asylum or refuge from another country, take a look at our (website)[https://www.redcross.org.uk/get-help/get-help-as-a-refugee]

services.name: Birmingham Settlement
services.description:
Money Advice @ Birmingham Settlement

Our long-established money advice services provide free, independent and confidential advice relating to issues of debt and welfare benefits. 

We work with clients to take action and resolve immediate financial difficulties and develop financial resilience for the future. 

We help with identifying correct entitlements and priorities, income maximisation, welfare benefits appeals and support with money management and budgeting skills.

Email: money.advice@bsettlement.org.uk 
Call: 0121 250 0777 to speak to an adviser

services.name: Birmingham Settlement
services.description:
Birmingham Settlement are able to issue foodbank vouchers for and of the Trussell Foodbank distribution centres in Birmingham
Contact our telephone money advice service on 0121 250 0765 to discuss your situation and we will supply you with a foodbank voucher where appropriate.

services.name: Birmingham Settlement
services.description:
Training and Learning 

We offer a range of comprehensive programmes to upskill and build capacity both in the community and in professional settings. Subjects include mental health, addiction, budgeting, welfare benefits, adult safeguarding, equality, diversity and inclusion, dementia awareness and many more. We also offer bespoke courses upon request.

Get in touch at training@bsettlement.org.uk or call 0121 250 0773 to find out more

services.name: Birmingham Settlement
services.description:
Hardship Grants (Supporting you to make an application)

If you are in severe financial hardship and without an income we may be able to support you to make an application to a hardship fund. 
Through these funds you may be eligible to receive a one-off grant towards daily essentials such as food, toiletries, fuel supply, clothing or household appliances.

To contact our Money Advice team: 
Email: money.advice@bsettlement.org.uk 
Call: 0121 250 0765

services.name: Aston and Nechells Trussell Foodbank
services.description:
If you need help from Aston and Nechells Foodbank there are a few simple steps to follow.

Get a Foodbank Voucher 
Find out how to go about that on our website

Bring your foodbank voucher to Aston and Nechells Foodbank 
When you arrive, we’ll welcome you and our trained volunteers will chat with you about your situation. We’ll also discuss any dietary needs you may have and exchange your foodbank voucher for a parcel of three days of emergency food.

We’ll also help to support you in any other ways that we can. Our aim is to provide non-judgemental support at the point of crisis.

services.name: Birmingham Children's Trust
services.description:
Support for 18 to 21 year olds who have been in care

The 18+ Care Leavers Service is here to help young people make the move from living in care to enjoying independent life as an adult. We can support young people from age 18 to 21 and this can continue where the young person remains in education, including up to age 25.

The 18+ Care Leavers Service is part of Birmingham Children's Trust and through our links to organisations in the community we can help with access to housing, education and training, work experience and health services.

We have a drop-in service, open 
8:45am to 5:15pm (Monday to Thursday) 
8:45am to 4:15pm (Friday)

When you arrive, ask the friendly reception staff, as you go in, to let the 18+ duty team know you would like to see a Personal Adviser. Reception will call us and a team member will come to reception to see you. We have access to a quiet space where you can speak in confidence

Find out more about this service on our website

services.name: As-Suffa Institute
services.description:
All our food parcels are sufficient to feed an average size family for one week. Our parcels include non-perishable goods like pasta, UHT milk, canned soups, etc.

If you are an organisation and want to become our partner organisation and distribute referral vouchers, please click here

PLEASE NOTE: We currently do not accept self referrals. To ensure that our limited supplies get to those most in need to be able to collect a food bank parcel you must be referred by a professional eg GP, School etc.

services.name: MECC Trust
services.description:
MECC Trust provides comprehensive housing advice to support individuals facing homelessness or housing issues. Their experienced team offers personalised guidance on housing options, tenancy rights, and accessing emergency accommodation. 

Through appointments and their Mobile Advice Service, MECC Trust ensures clients receive the support they need to secure and maintain stable housing, helping to prevent homelessness and promote long-term stability

services.name: MECC Trust
services.description:
Household Support Fund

Grants of up to GBP 200 per household can be used to support pensioners with food and energy costs.

HOW TO APPLY?

You will need to provide contact details, an email address, bank details, and evidence of your benefit status.

services.name: MECC Trust
services.description:
MECC Trust offers tailored employment advice to help individuals find job opportunities and overcome barriers to employment. Their dedicated team provides support with job searches, CV writing, and interview preparation, as well as access to training and education resources. 

Through personalised appointments and their Mobile Advice Service, MECC Trust ensures that clients receive the guidance and tools they need to succeed in the job market

services.name: MECC Trust
services.description:
MECC Trust offers compassionate and professional advice to help individuals manage debt and financial problems. 

Their knowledgeable team provides personalised support through appointments and a Mobile Advice Service, guiding clients on budgeting, debt management, and accessing financial assistance. 

MECC Trust also personalised advice to help individuals manage their energy bills, including guidance on energy bill rebates and home energy grants ensuring clients can make informed decisions to maintain affordable warmth in their homes.

services.name: MECC Trust
services.description:
MECC Trust provides personalised, expert advice to help individuals understand their benefit entitlements, including housing, income tax credits, and pensions. 

Their friendly and experienced team offers support through appointments and a Mobile Advice Service, ensuring clients receive the guidance they need to navigate the complex benefits system with confidence.

services.name: Birmingham Mind
services.description:
Mental Health and Wellbeing Hub - Handsworth

The Birmingham, Mental Health and Wellbeing Hub service is a combined integrated, innovative service delivered through a partnership lead by Birmingham Mind with our partners Creative Support.

The new service operates around four Recovery Hubs based in Erdington, Handsworth, Yardley and Northfield in order that the service can be accessible citywide.

Each Hub offers 1:1 recovery support planning, recovery focused activities and support to develop peer-led support networks and groups. However we have developed the service to offer a blended mix of virtual activities and face to face support sessions.

Support is available via face-to-face sessions in the Hubs, online sessions, but also via private peer social media groups and outdoor sessions (using parks & garden space).

This integrated service allows service users to move freely across all 4 locations, with the opportunity to choose from support sessions available on each Hub timetable.

Online Referrals and current timetables are accessible via the service website

We accept referrals from all parties, including GP’s, CMHT’s and self-referrals.
Please complete the referral form via the website

The manager of the Handsworth Hub is David Tresize

services.name: Adavu
services.description:
Adavu supports adult survivors of modern slavery across the West Midlands, many of whom are starting again in unfamiliar places. Some are moving on from Safe House accommodation through the NRM, while others are waiting for decisions on their cases. 

Support Workers meet each person, identify immediate needs like safe accommodation, food, clothing, healthcare, and benefits, then help with longer-term steps such as college, employment, volunteering, and building local connections. Isolation is common, so Adavu also runs occasional social events and drop-ins with the help of volunteers. 

Referral information is available on their website

Please note that Adavu does not investigate or ‘rescue’ people

services.name: JERICHO
services.description:
Social Enterprises 
 
Our family of social enterprises offer an excellent range of goods and services with the added benefit of providing supported employment opportunities for people facing extreme challenges in getting a job. This includes marginalised young people and survivors of modern slavery.

JERICHO Cleaning is a commercial cleaning company providing a professional high-quality service to customers across the West Midlands.

JERICHO Construction are experts in high-end large domestic extensions, full house refurbishments and rebuilds across Birmingham. They also do small/medium sized commercial projects.

JERICHO Workspace is a friendly co-working and training venue in Birmingham

Miracle Laundry provides a fast, affordable and professional laundry service 7 days a week from our premises in Kings Heath, Birmingham.

The ReUsers is a charity department store that rescues, restores and recycles second-hand items

The Wood Shack collects waste wood to prevent it going to landfill and sells it in their Timber Yard in Sutton Coldfield, Birmingham

Change Kitchen CIC JERICHO has a long-standing joint venture partnership with award-winning vegan and vegetarian catering Social Enterprise, ChangeKitchen CIC.

Employed in one of our social enterprises, apprentices can expect a real job in a real business with a real wage plus a recognised qualification thanks to our partnership with Next Level Training. Learn more about JERICHO apprenticeships

Our JERICHO Workwise project provides year 10/11 pupils, who are at risk of educational and future social exclusion, with real work experience in one of our social enterprises. It is designed to smooth the transition between school and work, raise aspirations, build self-esteem and improve educational achievement to prevent what can be the life-long damaging consequences of educational exclusion.
Discover JERICHO Workwise

Our Equiano Plus project is an employment-focused recovery project which provides long-term sustained support for Survivors of Modern Slavery. Learn more about Equiano Plus

services.name: Hope Projects
services.description:
Destitution Fund

Hope provides cash grants for people left destitute while challenging flawed refusals of asylum. People are usually staying in Hope Housing, with friends or family, or with other charities. Support provided on a case by case basis according to circumstance.

Referral Form

services.name: Hope Projects
services.description:
We give advice to everyone referred. You cannot access our service without having the legal case looked at. Therefore, if you are referred for a grant, you will get advice too.

Referral Form

services.name: Baobab Women's Project
services.description:
Currently we coordinate a monthly influencers group as part of the policy and advocacy project, to bring women together to find strength from each other as well as produce information to improve policy.

We also work with the Women with Hope group to encourage positive social change on issues, as well as other groups, including CARAG and CMWH, standing in solidarity with lived experience led groups campaigning for change.

services.name: Hope Projects
services.description: We have 12 houses in Birmingham and the Black Country that are home to over 30 people left homeless and destitute while challenging flawed refusals of asylum. We cover all utility costs.

services.name: Street League - West Midlands
services.description:
Free Employability Programme for NEET 16-29s 
Street League provide their services in Birmingham, and are looking to support 16-29 year olds who are not in education, employment, or training into their next steps via an eight week employability programme

What we offer:
Build Life Skills
Optional Sports Activities
8 Week Employabilility Support
Work Experience
 Maths and English support (Qualificiations if needed*)
Job Interviews and Opportunities
Travel Reimbursement
Gift vouchers on sign up and completion

Street League aims to reduce unemployment in the area. 

If you have any referrals or would like to hear more about what Street League do in Birmingham, please contact: 
Connor Belle 
Youth and Community Coach 
07584 507 977 
westmidlands@streetleague.co.uk

services.name: Sparkhill Trussell Foodbank
services.description:
If you need help from Sparkhill Foodbank there are a few simple steps to follow.

Get a Foodbank Voucher 
If you call or email our foodbank (at any time) we can talk through your situation and put you in touch with a relevant local agency who can issue you with a voucher.

Visit the referral agency 
They will discuss your situation and supply you with a foodbank voucher where appropriate.
If you are in financial crisis and live in England or Wales, please call 0808 2082138 for free (open Monday to Friday, 9am-5pm) to talk confidentially with a trained Citizens Advice adviser. They can help address your crises and provide support to maximise your income, help you navigate the benefits system, and identify any additional grants you could be entitled to. If needed, they’ll issue you with a voucher so you can get an emergency food parcel from your local food bank.

Bring your foodbank voucher to Sparkhill Foodbank 
When you arrive, we’ll welcome you with a warm drink and our trained volunteers will chat with you about your situation. We’ll also discuss any dietary needs you may have and exchange your foodbank voucher for a parcel of three days of emergency food.

We’ll also help to support you in any other ways that we can. Most of our foodbank centres offer a cafe style environment and our aim is to provide non-judgemental support at the point of crisis.

services.name: Roshni Birmingham
services.description:
Roshni in Birmingham offers emotional support and guidance to those affected by forced marriage, domestic abuse, and female genital mutilation (FGM). Their team provides a safe, confidential space for individuals to be heard, supported, and connected to further help if needed.

We help you to access information about your rights to make informed decisions, including immigration advice, housing, schools, and welfare benefits. We also provide support to access solicitors who can help with court orders and develop safety plan.

Please call 0800 953 9777 for our 24 hour multi lingual West Midlands Forced Marriage & Honor Based Abuse Helpline.

Reduce your weekly food expenditure at Christ Church Pantry based at South Aston URC Church. A membership community shop for families and individuals struggling to meet the costs of food. Open every Thursday 10am-12

For a small weekly subscription of GBP 5.00, members of the Christ Church Pantry are able to purchase a weekly food shop including fresh fruit and vegetables and family favourites to stock up the cupboard and fridge.

Find out how to become a member via the website

services.description: To find out what activities we are running at the Nature and Wellbeing centre, check our timetable on the website.

services.name: Forward Thinking Birmingham
services.description:
Pause is a service delivered by The Children's Society, in partnership with Forward Thinking Birmingham.

We provide access to immediate support & speak to an Emotional Wellbeing Practitioner. We listen to you and help you find solutions.

There are no referrals or waiting lists - you choose when and how to use our service.

services.name: Anawim
services.description:
Help to find work or do a course

Whether it’s training to get a job or to improve your knowledge or confidence, we have a wide range of free courses available to you.

Many of these can enhance your work skills and be useful if you are looking for a job. Our pre-employment courses focus on everything from how to budget and manage debt to help with creating a CV. You can also get tips on going to interviews or how to be more confident in a workplace.

Refer or self refer via the website

services.name: Anawim
services.description:
Anawim supports women with a wide range of mental health needs, from loneliness and stress to more complex challenges linked to trauma, neglect or harmful relationships. The team understands how these experiences can lead to panic attacks, flashbacks and other difficulties, and they offer steady, compassionate help.

Support includes courses, one to one guidance and practical or holistic activities. The centre provides a relaxed, safe place to socialise, join wellbeing sessions, enjoy craft or pamper activities and build confidence. Group courses and the onsite Donations Hub also offer chances to make friends and gain work experience.

Refer or self refer via the website

services.name: Anawim
services.description:
Domestic and financial abuse affects many women in the UK, and Anawim offers steady, informed support to help women regain independence and confidence. The team includes a specialised Domestic Violence worker who listens carefully and walks alongside each woman as she decides her next steps.

Support can include guidance on reporting to the police, attending court, completing assessments, and accessing services that help keep women and their children safe. Anawim also offers advice on finances and housing, access to counselling and free legal advice, and referrals to refuge when needed.

Refer or self refer via the website

services.name: Anawim
services.description:
Whatever your circumstances, at Anawim, we can help you to find a safe place to live.

Our teams can support you to overcome difficulties with housing applications or tenancies, arrange urgent access to temporary accommodation or a refuge and point you to services you need to prevent you becoming homeless.

Our Outreach team works hard to engage with homeless women, providing them with clothing, food and a hot shower through our drop-in centres or arranging a safe haven to settle in.

We also provide accommodation at Dawn House for women who have just been released from prison as they transition back into the community.

Refer or self refer via the website

services.name: Anawim
services.description:
Anawim’s women’s justice services support women at every stage of the criminal justice system, from first-time offenders to those leaving prison. The focus is on stability, confidence and practical help, whether that means navigating housing and benefits, improving mental health, building skills, or working with probation to keep support plans on track. The open-door approach gives women a place to turn for advice during what can be a difficult transition back into the community.

This work includes Prison In-reach at HMP Foston Hall and HMP Drake Hall, temporary accommodation at Dawn House for women newly released from prison, early intervention through Project New Chance, and tailored employability support. Each strand helps women build life skills, reduce the risk of reoffending and move toward a more settled, independent future.

Refer or self refer via the website

services.name: Anawim
services.description:
Drop-in is a space for women to attend Anawim's centre and speak with a support worker one-to-one, no appointment or referral necessary.

Our centre, and Anawim's friendly support workers, are here to help women explore issues relating to wellbeing, relationships, finances and housing in a safe and confidential space.

Want to talk? Stop by 10am-2pm, Monday to Friday. No need to let us know in advance.

Prefer to speak remotely? We get that. Call our helpline on 0800 019 8818, or visit our live chat at www.anawim.co.uk, and you'll be put straight through to a support worker. 9am-5pm, Monday to Friday.

services.name: Forward Thinking Birmingham
services.description:
Forward Thinking Birmingham Mental Health Services

Welcome to Forward Thinking Birmingham (FTB). We are a unique, innovative community and inpatient mental health partnership. We, alongside our partners offer care pathways of mental health assessment and treatment for young people from 0-25-year-old.

At Forward Thinking Birmingham we work with children, young people and young adults who are struggling with their mental health, we aim to involve families/guardians/ carers in their care and treatment wherever possible.

Click Here if you are a professional and wish to make a referral

We are not accepting self-referrals at this time

Note that the opening days and times might change, you can check the most up to date information here.

Any questions, you are welcome to get in touch via our email bigfeed@theaws.org

services.name: Incredible Surplus
services.description:
Winson Green

Originally established in 2014 as The Real Junk Food Project Birmingham, we intercept food and other usable materials that would otherwise go to waste from supermarkets, restaurants and other sources, and provide them to individuals and community organisations on a “Pay-As-You-Feel” basis.

We welcome everyone that wants to come and shop with us at our Winson Green site.

All we ask is that you please:
Respect our volunteers and each other.
Please park on the approach road and walk to the Sharehouse, and request taxis drop-off/pick-up there too - we need access for deliveries, as do our neighbours - there is no room for customer/volunteer cars.
We have trolleys and can help you to take your shopping to your vehicle if needed - please just ask.
Please sign in with your name and postcode - everyone is welcome, you don’t have to be local; we just like to know where people are travelling from.
Food is for personal use only - you cannot shop for friends/family, or to sell on. By all means tell your friends/family to come down and shop with us too, though!
Only take what you need and leave what you don’t - we may ask you to put some things back if you take too much of a single item - it’s only fair to leave enough for others.
Any questions, just ask.

services.name: Greencoat Nursery [Supporting Families]
services.description:
Kids Clothing Bank at Greencoat Nursery

We initially started our clothing bank during the Covid-19 pandemic but due to rising cost of living, which has seen more families struggle, we've expanded our support.

As part of our effort to help we started the Kids Clothing Bank. Due to limited space we are only able to offer clothing for Children who are 0-5.

We have various options to drop off clothing.

services.description:
Riverside Money Advice offers free, confidential and independent budgeting and debt advice and practical help to escape debt in the south Birmingham area. 
Find out more about how we help here 
We offer advice to residents with B11, B12,B13 and B14 postcodes. 

We do not offer advice on PIP/DLA unless part of a debt advice journey

Come to our drop-ins from 10:00am to 2.30pm on Wednesdays to arrange an appointment with an advisor. Our advisors are trained and experienced. We understand that debt can be stressful and difficult.

We have a free café running alongside our Money Advice drop-ins during school term times.

Our service differs from Citizens Advice and phone-based advice services - we will meet you face-to-face, and as we work together we will keep meeting with you from that first appointment, right through until everything is sorted, no matter how long it takes. While you still want to get out of debt or get your money issues sorted, we’ll keep helping.

We have a free café running alongside our Money Advice drop-ins during school term times.

Our service differs from Citizens Advice and phone-based advice services - we will meet you face-to-face, and as we work together we will keep meeting with you from that first appointment, right through until everything is sorted, no matter how long it takes. services.name: Gilgal Birmingham
services.description:
First and foremost, Gilgal provides emergency short term accommodation for women and children escaping domestic abuse. 

Members of our team are available at the refuge at all times including evenings, overnights, weekends and public holidays. This is to maximise safety and security, ensure residents support needs are met and deal with any emergency or admission which occurs out of hours.

Our team are ready and willing to listen to women in need of support, who are experiencing domestic violence.

We are inclusive 
If we have a suitable room in the refuge available, then providing the woman referred meets our criteria, the referral is always accepted and the woman can move in immediately.

Who refers women in need? 
You can refer yourself by phoning us directly or someone can ring on your behalf.

The process 
Rooms are allocated on a first come basis, we do not operate a waiting list.

We talk to the woman over the phone initially to give details of the refuge and to allow her to ask us any questions.

A more detailed admission and risk assessment process is completed once she arrives at Gilgal.

If you feel worried about your circumstances, please don’t suffer in silence. You don’t have to be alone, we are here to help.

Contact Us Now : 0800 008 6622

services.name: POhWER Advocacy Charity
services.description:
The Birmingham Advocacy Hub is delivered by a partnership which includes POhWER, Advocacy Matters and the Ashiana Community Project, delivering person centred and high quality advocacy that is accessible across Birmingham to everyone who needs it.

services.description:
Here at St Germain's we run a shop in partnership with The Real Junk Food Project
The food and items that we provide are Pay As You Feel, or PAYF for short.
That means you contribute however you can to the success of our project: donating your time, skills, money, or something even more imaginative! If you need to get in touch, please contact food@stgermains.org.uk.

services.description: Our Drop-In runs alongside the church’s Community Café and provides an opportunity to get help with emotional and practical problems, without the need for an appointment. You can just turn up and speak with a member of our team, which includes Emotional Wellbeing Practitioners, Listening Volunteers, local Community Network Support Officers from the Council and Welfare Rights Advisers (who can help with benefits issues). If you are interested in specific support with practical concerns, e.g. housing or benefits, it’s best to email (wellbeinghub@stgermains.org.uk) or call (0121 517 0476) us first to check when the relevant support professional will next be at the Drop-In.

services.name: St Germains Community Hub
services.description: Our friends at The Real Junk Food Project (Central) have opened a Pay As You feel cafe in the church hall. Open from 12-2.30pm every Monday and Friday, the menu depends on what produce is available. If you need to get in touch, please contact food@stgermains.org.uk.

services.name: Narthex Sparkhill
services.description:
Narthex Food Hub - Resource for registered referring partners only 

The Narthex Food Hub (NFH) is a dedicated resource for food provision organisations, designed to make food more affordable and accessible. Whether you run a food bank, pantry, or community food service, the NFH provides a cost-effective way to stock up on essential items and improve the support you offer.

If you’re a food provision organisation, we’d love for you to join the NFH network. Registration is quick and easy - just fill in the form linked from our webpage, and we’ll be in touch to guide you through the next steps

services.name: Birmingham Narthex Pantry [ Your Local Pantry Network ]
services.description:
Narthex opened St John's Your Local Pantry in April 2024, as part of their commitment to support families to budget and have access to low-cost food in a planned way. One of the aims is to reduce the incidence of families reaching crisis-point when they have to seek support from a food bank.

In addition, Narthex St John's Pantry provides opportunities for volunteering and work experience to gain valuable skills. This Your Local Pantry at St Johns Road is ideally situated off the main Stratford road.

For a small weekly subscription of GBP 5, members of this Pantry will be able to purchase a weekly food shop including fresh fruit and vegetables and family favourites to stock up the cupboard and fridge.

services.name: Narthex Sparkhill
services.description:
Our objective is to provide a range of advice and guidance to anyone who needs help. This is done by helping clients directly through our team of advisers. Through their intervention, clients obtain better services, benefits and grants of which they may have been unaware and to which they are entitled.

Clients faced with creditors or being evicted are helped by interventions to mitigate these conditions. Budgeting of a client’s overall income and expenditure and then helping to put in place regular payment plans to creditors, is frequently part of the work. In more difficult cases for those clients with significant debt, help can be given to establish a Debt Relief Order (DRO).

All Narthex advisers are appropriately qualified and have gained considerable experience in bringing positive outcomes to the situations presented by clients. The team of advisers has been expanded in 2021 and demand for its services is still growing. All consultations are conducted on the telephone or online. If you need support in any way please call Sandra on 07467 045294 Monday to Friday or email sandra1@narthex.org.uk as we are not open for face-to-face consultations at present.

services.name: Sparkhill Trussell Foodbank
services.description:
If you need help from Sparkhill Foodbank there are a few simple steps to follow.

Get a Foodbank Voucher 
If you call or email our foodbank (at any time) we can talk through your situation and put you in touch with a relevant local agency who can issue you with a voucher.

Visit the referral agency 
They will discuss your situation and supply you with a foodbank voucher where appropriate.
If you are in financial crisis and live in England or Wales, please call 0808 2082138 for free (open Monday to Friday, 9am-5pm) to talk confidentially with a trained Citizens Advice adviser. They can help address your crises and provide support to maximise your income, help you navigate the benefits system, and identify any additional grants you could be entitled to. If needed, they’ll issue you with a voucher so you can get an emergency food parcel from your local food bank.

Bring your foodbank voucher to Sparkhill Foodbank 
When you arrive, we’ll welcome you with a warm drink and our trained volunteers will chat with you about your situation. We’ll also discuss any dietary needs you may have and exchange your foodbank voucher for a parcel of three days of emergency food.

We’ll also help to support you in any other ways that we can. Most of our foodbank centres offer a cafe style environment and our aim is to provide non-judgemental support at the point of crisis.

services.description:

services.name: Open Door Friendship Centre [ Azadi Trust ]
services.description:
The Open Door Friendship Centre offers friendly, practical help for anyone needing support with everyday issues. Their Advice & Form-Filling sessions are open twice weekly and provide a safe, welcoming space for people to get one-to-one support.

Here’s what’s available:
Form-Filling Help 
Support with a wide range of paper and online forms, including housing applications, benefits claims, or other essential services. Some forms may require more than one appointment to complete, so ongoing support is available if needed.
Advice 
Confidential advice is offered around housing, benefits, welfare support (such as food), family issues, and more. The team listens without judgment and aims to guide people through what can often feel like overwhelming processes.
Signposting 
If they can’t help directly, they’ll do their best to connect you with someone who can. This includes making contact with other organisations on your behalf, helping you access specialist services with less stress.

If English isn’t your first language, you’re encouraged to bring someone who can help translate. In some cases, the centre may also be able to arrange a translator for you

services.description:
Our pantry stocks an abundant range of top-quality food including fresh fruit and veg, frozen and chilled food, meat, dairy products, long-life tins and packaged food.

For only GBP 6 a week, members can ‘shop’ at our pantry and take home an average of GBP 20-GBP 30 worth of groceries.

services.name: Brushstrokes Community Project
services.description:
Our Bump Start packs contain essential items for new and expectant mothers, such as nappies, clothes, blankets, bottles, Moses baskets, baby wipes and toys. These are our most requested item and we are always in need of donations of items for newborns.

We distribute donated items to benefit the asylum seekers, refugees and others in need who we support. Occasionally, if we have items which are unsuitable for distribution or we haven’t capacity to store them, we either offer them to other charities supporting vulnerable groups, or sell them to raise valuable funds for our work.

services.name: Brushstrokes Community Project
services.description:
We support families and individuals in Birmingham and the Black Country, especially asylum seekers and refugees with little or no access to public funding by providing practical resources of food, clothing and household essentials to people who are experiencing great need.

We give out non-perishable food items, clothing, blankets and bedding, and other essential household items. The needs of the people we help change according to the time of year. We therefore appeal for seasonal items such as hats, scarves and gloves in autumn and winter.

We distribute donated items to benefit the asylum seekers, refugees and others in need who we support. Occasionally, if we have items which are unsuitable for distribution or we haven’t capacity to store them, we either offer them to other charities supporting vulnerable groups, or sell them to raise valuable funds for our work.

services.name: Brushstrokes Community Project
services.description:
Housing advice
Refugee Homelessness Prevention

Brushstrokes is helping to deliver a unique approach for refugees in Sandwell. 
Working alongside Sandwell Council we are providing tailored support to help people manage the transition from asylum support to settled status as refugees. 
 
Through outreach and office based work, everyone who receives a positive decision on their asylum claim while they are accommodated in Sandwell, is offered dedicated casework support. The service includes advice and support to address housing options, accessing benefits, advice on their education, employment and training options and provides ongoing resettlement support.
 
Anyone granted refugee status in the other areas where we are working, such as west Birmingham, can also receive assistance with resettlement from our advice team.

services.name: Brushstrokes Community Project
services.description:
Through the provision of ESOL and volunteering opportunities individuals have been able to improve their work readiness this year. Since September 2016 the provision of a weekly work club has supported 63 individuals.

 

Refugees, EU migrants and individuals who have come to the UK to join family have been making use of this service seeking help with writing CVs, Job search and developing the skills and capacity to complete applications and write cover letters.

 

Referrals come from the Job Centre, other community organisations and other Brushstrokes projects, such as our Homelessness Prevention Pathway. Weekly attendance at work club ranges from 5 to 10 at present. 

We are open every Wednesday but people need to book appointments.

services.name: Brushstrokes Community Project
services.description:
Brushstrokes offers advice and support for people seeking asylum in Sandwell and West Birmingham. Trained staff and volunteers provide one-to-one guidance to help people understand and navigate the asylum process. This includes outreach visits, help with housing transitions, and support through the Asylum Guides programme.

You can also train as a volunteer Asylum Guide to support others on their journey.

Contact: elmugiera@brushstrokessandwell.org.uk

services.name: Brushstrokes Community Project
services.description:
With over 200 learners, Brushstrokes is one of the largest providers of ESOL in the Smethwick area. Staffed by a dedicated and enthusiastic team of volunteer teachers and classroom assistants and a qualified ESOL Coordinator, we provide courses ranging from compete beginners to academic IELTS.

ESOL

We have no criteria for acceptance onto any of our ESOL courses but prioritise asylum seekers wherever possible. Our largest ESOL cohort is always beginners and we encourage learners to access college provision when they feel confident to do so. ESOL courses range from beginners to Entry 3 including a phonics class to help people with no reading skills. 

 

 
If you would like to learn English at Brushstrokes, please click on the link and complete our enquiry form.

 

https://forms.gle/vDojQQ6oXH8Bk2Ni6

services.name: Brushstrokes Community Project
services.description:
Life in the UK

We run a Life in the UK class runs every Wednesday from 10 - 11.30am. This course runs for two terms and prepares people for the Life in the UK test. We use comprehensive resources and multimedia to bring the course to life and help people understand the, often, bewildering amount of information they need to learn. Learners should be at Entry 2 or Entry 3 to access this course.

services.description:
Immigration Clinic
 
Brushstrokes offers free, regulated immigration advice for people at any stage of the immigration process. Support is available up to Level 3, including help with applications, appeals, visa extensions, settlement, and family reunion. The service is accredited by the Immigration Services Commissioner.

services.name: Brushstrokes Community Project
services.description:
The Friday Community Cafe, run by staff and volunteers, is open to all members of the community.

The Cafe is a great place of welcome serving approximately 46% of meals to refugees and asylum seekers with the remaining 54% to individuals who are homeless or who are local residents.

 

We also invite our neighbours and local residents to our special events, such as sharing food from around the world at Interfaith Lunch, Big Lunch, St Patrick’s Day Lunch and Easter celebrations.

services.name: Brushstrokes Community Project
services.description:
We support families and individuals in Birmingham and the Black Country, especially asylum seekers and refugees with little or no access to public funding by providing practical resources of food, clothing and household essentials to people who are experiencing great need.

We give out non-perishable food items, clothing, blankets and bedding, and other essential household items. The needs of the people we help change according to the time of year. We therefore appeal for seasonal items such as hats, scarves and gloves in autumn and winter.

We distribute donated items to benefit the asylum seekers, refugees and others in need who we support. Occasionally, if we have items which are unsuitable for distribution or we haven’t capacity to store them, we either offer them to other charities supporting vulnerable groups, or sell them to raise valuable funds for our work.

services.name: Brushstrokes Community Project
services.description:
Our Bump Start packs contain essential items for new and expectant mothers, such as nappies, clothes, blankets, bottles, Moses baskets, baby wipes and toys. These are our most requested item and we are always in need of donations of items for newborns.

We distribute donated items to benefit the asylum seekers, refugees and others in need who we support. Occasionally, if we have items which are unsuitable for distribution or we haven’t capacity to store them, we either offer them to other charities supporting vulnerable groups, or sell them to raise valuable funds for our work.

services.name: Job Centre Plus
services.description:
Job Centre Plus provides support into employment. 
Employment related benefits such and ESA can also be applied for and dealt with in the JobCentre Plus offices. 
If you wish to use the JobCentre Plus services, you can start the process by telephoning your local office and making an appointment or popping in and talking to someone face to face. This office now offers services to a whole range of people, from the employers advertising jobs, unemployed people looking for work, part time employees looking to get more work, students and school leavers looking to enter the job market and people with special needs who need a bit more assistance in getting a job. 
Offering schemes to help people find work or develop skills, they work closely with the local communities organising work initiatives and volunteering schemes to help people gain experience in their chosen field of work.

services.name: Dorothy Parkes Community Centre
services.description:
Cocaine Anonymous

Support group for anyone with issues around alcohol and drugs.

For more information, please call Tony on 07538 588986

Meeting every Monday 7.30pm - 8.30pm

services.name: Dorothy Parkes Community Centre
services.description:
Place of Welcome @ Dorothy Parkes Centre

Sessions take place every Friday morning, with a cuppa and some conversation offered to anyone who drops in - and you can stay as little or as long as you like during the session time of 10-12. Support and signposting to local services is also available.

A member of the national Places of Welcome scheme

services.name: Dorothy Parkes Community Centre
services.description:
Dottie's Community Fridge

This exciting project offers free surplus food to anyone in need, thanks to generous funding from Hubbub and Heart of England Community Foundation.

Dottie's Community Fridge aims to reduce food waste while supporting our local community. The fridge will be stocked with surplus food, available free of charge on Tuesdays and Fridays. It's our hope that this initiative will make a real difference, providing people with access to healthy, nutritious food while reducing unnecessary waste.

How Dottie's Community Fridge Works

Dottie's Community Fridge is here to serve everyone. Whether you're facing financial challenges, looking to reduce your own food waste, or simply want to access surplus food in a convenient location, the fridge is available to all. It operates on a no-questions-asked basis, ensuring that anyone who needs food can easily access it without judgment.

Simply visit the Dorothy Parkes Centre on Tuesdays and Fridays between 10am and 2pm to see what’s available. Whether it’s fresh fruit, vegetables, bread, or packaged items, there will always be a variety of options for you to take home.

services.name: The Active Wellbeing Society
services.description:
The Big Feed Community Café @ Hay Hall, Tyesley

The Big Feed project provides a safe and welcoming space for people to come together over food. The cafés offer Free meals, and welcome optional contributions such as donating time, money, or skills.

The Big Feed at Hay Hall welcomes guests on Tuesdays and Fridays, 12pm - 1:30pm 
There are also other activities available at this site;
TAWS hosts Table Tennis sessions on Tuesdays & Fridays, 12pm - 1.30pm
TAWS hosts the Share Shack on Tuesdays & Fridays, 11am - 4pm
TAWS hosts a Social Walk on Tuesdays & Fridays, from 1pm
Note that the opening days and times might change, you can check the most up to date information here.

Any questions, you are welcome to get in touch via our email bigfeed@theaws.org

services.name: The Active Wellbeing Society
services.description:
Listen and Connect - The Active Wellbeing Society

Listen and Connect is a telephone support service that offers a safe space for people to feel heard and supported. 

It can provide up to 10 weeks of support, offering practical solutions and advice to live well and be active. 

It can connect people to opportunities and people locally to improve people’s physical and mental wellbeing.

This service is by referral only
Go to https://theaws.co.uk/listen-connect/ to find out more and fill in a request for support form.

For any general enquiries about the service please email listenandconnect@theaws.org or phone us on 0121 728 7030

services.name: The Active Wellbeing Society
services.description:
Activities facilitated by The Active Wellbeing Society

Virtual Wellbeing activities

A range of activities are available online which people can join live or watch any other time. Activities include Zumba, afro beats, cardio, chair-based exercises, and cooking. 
Find out more about the Virtual Activities offered here

Other Activities

We provide other activities such as led runs, walks and bike rides. 
Learn more about the activities near you

services.name: Aston and Nechells Trussell Foodbank
services.description:
If you need help from Aston and Nechells Foodbank there are a few simple steps to follow.

Get a Foodbank Voucher 
Find out how to go about that on our website

Bring your foodbank voucher to Aston and Nechells Foodbank 
When you arrive, we’ll welcome you and our trained volunteers will chat with you about your situation. We’ll also discuss any dietary needs you may have and exchange your foodbank voucher for a parcel of three days of emergency food.

We’ll also help to support you in any other ways that we can. Our aim is to provide non-judgemental support at the point of crisis.

services.name: Smethwick Trussell Foodbank
services.description:
If you need help from Smethwick Foodbank there are a few simple steps to follow.
Get a Foodbank Voucher If you call or email our foodbank (at any time) we can talk through your situation and put you in touch with a relevant local agency who can issue you with a voucher.
Visit the referral agency They will discuss your situation and supply you with a foodbank voucher where appropriate.

If you are in financial crisis and live in England or Wales, please call 0808 2082138 for free (open Monday to Friday, 9am-5pm) to talk confidentially with a trained Citizens Advice adviser. They can help address your crises and provide support to maximise your income, help you navigate the benefits system, and identify any additional grants you could be entitled to. If needed, they’ll issue you with a voucher so you can get an emergency food parcel from your local food bank.
Collecting your food parcel We are not currently offering a service to the public indoors. Food will be provided to those who have a referral voucher or e Code at the door of Holy Trinity Church. Clients are encouraged to wait in line with social distancing and to wear a mask.

services.name: Smethwick Pantry [Your Local Pantry Network]
services.description:
We are open every Wednesday from 10:00-3.00 for Pantry Members only. The weekly membership fee is GBP 5 and each member is assigned a time slot to complete their shop. Please remember to bring your freezer bags.

Please note that Your Local Pantry: Smethwick is not currently accepting new members. If your application is accepted, we can place you on our waiting list and will get in touch when a space becomes available.

This pantry is part of Smethwick Church Action Network which is a joint response from Smethwick’s churches to serve our neighbours in times of crisis and help facilitate a transition from a place of need, to one of opportunity, hope and self-sufficiency.

services.name: Birmingham Narthex Pantry [ Your Local Pantry Network ]
services.description:
Narthex Pantry is committed to supporting members to budget and have access to low-cost food in a planned way. One of our key aims is to reduce the number of occasions members reach into crisis when looking for support from a food bank.

For a small weekly subscription of GBP 5, members of this Pantry will be able to purchase staples including fresh fruit and vegetables and supermarket favourites to stock up their cupboards and fridge.

In addition, Narthex Pantry provides opportunities for volunteering and work experience to gain valuable skills and knowledge. We are situated in the heart of the Tyseley community at Rovex Business Park.

services.name: Birmingham Spaghetti Pantry [Your Local Pantry Network]
services.description:
For a small weekly subscription of GBP 5.00, members of the Spaghetti Pantry will be be able to purchase a weekly food shop including fresh fruit and vegetables and family favourites to stock up the cupboard and fridge.

To become a member, please sign up via the [webpage](https://www.yourlocalpantry.co.uk/pantry-listings/birmingham-spaghetti-pantry/

services.name: Change into Action Coventry
services.description:
If you are an organisation in Coventry supporting people out of street homelessness, you can apply to become a Change into Action delivery partner. Once your organisation is a delivery partner you will be able to request funding for rough sleeper applicants. 
The link to the application form can be found on the Change into Action Website

services.name: Dogs Trust Hope Project
services.description: Free vet care for people experiencing homelessness with dogs. Available through partner vets in Coventry.

services.name: Stop Loan Sharks
services.description:
Stop Loan Sharks - Coventry
Support for anyone affected by illegal money lending.
Access: Call 0300 555 2222 or visit www.stoploansharks.co.uk
Available: Nationwide, including Coventry

services.name: St Giles Trust
services.description:
St Giles Pantry in Coventry offers healthy, sustainable food to people experiencing poverty in the surrounding area. 
People using the Pantry pay a weekly subscription of GBP 3.50 and in return are able to access an abundance of affordable, nutritious food and added support to help them move towards independence.

Contact The Coventry Pantry - info@stgilestrust.org.uk to find out more or complete the Pantry Referral form via the link found on the [St Giles Trust website]https://www.stgilestrust.org.uk/how-to-get-support/)

services.name: St Giles Trust
services.description:
St Giles Trust offers tailored, one-to-one employment support for adults and young people aged 16 to 25 who face complex barriers. Their team, many with lived experience, helps clients prepare CVs, search for jobs, practise interviews and build confidence. They also support with wider issues like getting ID, finding childcare, securing housing, and accessing mental health or digital support to help people move into sustainable work. This service is personal, practical, and focused on long-term change.

Referrals can be made into this service via the form found on the St Giles Trust website

services.name: St Giles Trust
services.description:
The Reflections Project offers tailored support for women aged 18 and over who have been released from police custody in Coventry. The service helps with practical and emotional challenges such as housing, mental health, domestic abuse, debt, and family issues. Caseworkers, many with lived experience, provide trauma-informed care and create personalised plans to reduce the risk of reoffending and support long-term stability.

If you would like to refer someone into the Reflections Programme, please contact us via the St Giles Trust website

services.name: Central England Law Centre
services.description:
Legal advice with housing issues, including homelessness prevention and tenancy disputes.
Assistance with benefits claims, appeals, and related issues
Legal advice and representation for immigration and asylum matters
Support with employment rights, unfair dismissal, and workplace discrimination

Services are primarily by appointment. Individuals can contact the Law Centre via phone or email to schedule an appointment. Some services may have specific eligibility criteria such as having a low income; please inquire directly for more information

services.name: Coventry Citizens Advice
services.description:
Provide free, confidential, impartial and independent advice on many issues including debt, benefits, housing and employment.

Our goal is to help everyone find a way forward, whatever problems they face.

Coventry Citizen's Advice operates a Telephone-First advice model

Call Advice Line : 0800 1448848.
For digital help go to www.advicebuddy.org
or the publicly available national website www.citizensadvice.org.uk
Webchat/email may be available from this site.

services.name: Bardsley Youth Project
services.description:
Informal sessions for inividuals aged 16-25 offering support, social activities, and access to food and clothing banks. 
For more info visit: https://www.bardsleyyouth.org/dropinatbardsley

services.name: Bardsley Youth Project
services.description:
We offer food parcels for young people who are moving into supported housing that have not yet been able to make a claim for benefits. This helps them to survive the few weeks until they make a claim and get a payment.

Food parcels can also be used to help out young people who are in tenancies but have had an unexpected expenditure and find themselves low on food.

We can supplement our food parcels with food bank vouchers if required.

services.name: Bardsley Youth Project
services.description:
If you are short of clothes, we have a small clothes bank where you can come and get free clothing. Most of it has been kindly donated, but items such as underwear we always buy new.

We provide essential furniture and kitchen packs to young people aged 16-25 moving into unfurnished homes. While waiting for government grants-which can take up to 11 weeks-we offer basic items like a bed, fridge, and freezer on loan. Our kitchen packs include new items, a microwave, and a grill to help you cook and settle in straight away.

Self Referrals are accepted: Call Kim 07943 688760 
Find out more on our website

services.name: Bardsley Youth Project
services.description:

Our kitchen packs include new items, a microwave, and a grill to help you cook and settle in straight away.

Self Referrals are accepted: Call Kim 07943 688760 
Find out more on our website

services.name: Bardsley Youth Project
services.description:
Bardsley Youth Project provides Young People with a range of practical and emotional support to gain the skills they need to find accommodation and keep it. Young people can come to one of our drop-in sessions Mon/Thurs 1-4, or contact the team to arrange 1:1 support meetings outside of drop-in hours.
For more information visit : https://www.bardsleyyouth.org/dropinatbardsley

Make a referral 
Who can make a referral?
Young people can self-refer (you can ask a friend or family member to help you complete the form - but they should have your permission)
Those working with/on behalf of a young person 

How do I submit a referral? 
Download the referral form from our website
Attach it to an email and send it to kim@bardsleyyouth.org
Put "New Referral" as your email subject

services.name: Micro Rainbow
services.description:
Why we run safe houses dedicated solely to LGBTQI asylum seekers and refugees

In 76 countries homosexuality is illegal. 1,500 LGBTQI refugees from those countries come to the UK every year.

When they come to the UK they are still not safe. Because of their sexuality, gender identity, gender expression or intersex status they often:
are abused in refugee accommodation by other refugees who often come from the same countries they are escaping from
become homeless and depressed
are rejected by their ethnic community and live in poverty

What we are doing to help LGBTQI asylum seekers and refugees

Micro Rainbow opened the first safe house in the United Kingdom dedicated solely to LGBTQI asylum seekers and refugees. Our houses provide a safe and temporary shelter for all LGBTQI asylum seekers and refugees. They are located in the London area, in the North West and in the West Midlands.

If you need a translator, please email housing@microrainbow.org to arrange this in advance.
Our support line number is 0800 3585851. This number is free to call Mon-Fri 2pm-5pm. Our support line is for urgent matters

services.name: Micro Rainbow
services.description:
Moving On Programme

Micro Rainbow provides one-to-one support to LGBTQI people who have recently become refugees in order to:
obtain National Insurance numbers
register with Universal Credit
open bank accounts 
Micro Rainbow works with various partners, including the third and private sector, to:
provide one to one support over a period of six to twelve months to prepare and review a moving on plan (e.g. to find employment)
organise workshops around CV writing and interview skills
facilitate job opportunities

How to access 
Email: movingon@microrainbow.org

Micro Rainbow provides one-to-one support to LGBTQI people who have recently become refugees in order to:
obtain National Insurance numbers
register with Universal Credit
open bank accounts 
Micro Rainbow works with various partners, including the third and private sector, to:
provide one to one support over a period of six to twelve months to prepare and review a moving on plan (e.g. to find employment)
organise workshops around CV writing and interview skills
facilitate job opportunities

How to access 
Email: movingon@microrainbow.org

services.name: Rough Sleeper Outreach Team - Coventry
services.description:
The Rough Sleeper Outreach Team work to accommodate all known rough sleepers or those people we find rough sleeping. 

Alongside offers of accommodation the team work holistically to provide support, advice and referrals to specialist organisations on a range of issues including debt/money advice, mental & physical health, substance misuse etc.

The Outreach team operates 5 days a week and undertakes regular outreach sessions and respond to reports of anyone sleeping rough in the city.

If you know someone is rough sleeping you can report their whereabouts via the website/app Street Link. 
All referrals go to the outreach team to respond.

services.name: The Roma Project
services.description:
Legal advice for members of the Roma community is available by phone from The Roma Project. Call Monday to Friday between 9am and 5pm.

Consiliere juridică pentru membrii comunității de romi este disponibilă telefonic prin Proiectul Romilor. Sunați de luni până vineri între orele 9:00 și 17:00.

07306017999 or 07306413888 (between 9:00am-5:00pm).

services.name: The Roma Project
services.description:
The Roma Project offers free advice to support social inclusion and reduce exploitation within the Roma community in Coventry. They can help with benefits, self-employment, and immigration issues. Call to speak with someone or book an appointment.

Proiectul Roma oferă consiliere gratuită pentru a sprijini incluziunea socială și a reduce exploatarea în cadrul comunității de romi din Coventry. Pot oferi ajutor cu beneficii, muncă pe cont propriu și probleme de imigrare. Sunați pentru a vorbi cu cineva sau pentru a face o programare.

Call 07306 017999

services.name: Job Centre Plus
services.description: Jobcentre Plus helps people find work and access benefits. You can get support with job searching, applications, interviews, and accessing training. Work Coaches are available to guide you based on your circumstances. They also help with benefit claims and connecting to local vacancies.

services.name: Job Shop [Coventry City Council]
services.description:
You can now register online to get free 1:1 job coaching from the Job Shop. We offer tailored support with job hunting, CVs, interviews, and confidence building. You’ll have access to local job vacancies and events with employers and training providers. We also help with career planning, skills training, money advice, and wellbeing. Extra support is available for travel, childcare, and interview clothing.

Register Here or For more information

services.name: Job Shop [Coventry City Council]
services.description:

services.name: Job Shop [Coventry City Council]
services.description:
The Job Shop holds various training courses and events all year round for residents of Coventry.

Our events and workshops are updated regularly - please see more details on our website
