services.name: POhWER Advocacy Charity
services.description:
POhWER aims to support people who face difficult issues and want to make their voice heard. All POhWER's services are free, independent and confidential.

POhWER has worked in Sandwell since 2006. 

We offer the following services in Sandwell:
NHS Complaints Advocacy
Independent Mental Capacity Advocacy (IMCA), including Deprivation of Liberty Safeguards (DoLS) and Relevant Person's Paid Representative (RPPR)
Independent Mental Health Advocacy (IMHA) including an issue based advocacy service for informal inpatients of Sandwell (Hallam St) Hospital via drop ins.
Independent Care Act Advocacy

To find out more and how to request support from an advocate, please visit our website

Click here to visit POhWER West Midlands Facebook Page

services.name: Job Centre Plus
services.description:
Job Centre Plus provides support into employment. 
Employment related benefits such and ESA can also be applied for and dealt with in the JobCentre Plus offices. 
If you wish to use the JobCentre Plus services, you can start the process by telephoning your local office and making an appointment or popping in and talking to someone face to face. This office now offers services to a whole range of people, from the employers advertising jobs, unemployed people looking for work, part time employees looking to get more work, students and school leavers looking to enter the job market and people with special needs who need a bit more assistance in getting a job. 
Offering schemes to help people find work or develop skills, they work closely with the local communities organising work initiatives and volunteering schemes to help people gain experience in their chosen field of work.

services.name: Black Country Housing Group Accommodation
services.description: Social Housing in the Black Country (Birmingham, Dudley, Sandwell, Walsall, Wolverhampton)

services.name: Sandwell Borough Council - Housing Support
services.description:
The Housing Solutions team offers support to those who are homeless or at risk of homelessness.

Our advice and assistance is free and confidential.

For customers who cannot access services online or via the telephone, the Local Centres are open to support customers in person. In addition to this Housing Officers will be holding surgeries the Library in Blackheath to receive any housing-related enquiries in person

If you find yourself with nowhere to stay outside office hours or over the weekend please contact Housing Solutions out of hours 0121 569 6883 (24 hour callback service). We can only give advice in emergencies

services.name: St Basils
services.description:
St Basils in Sandwell offers mediation for young people at risk of homelessness due to family conflict or breakdown. The service helps resolve issues so young people can stay or return home if it’s safe, or access interim support while alternative housing is found. Support includes one-to-one mediation, family meetings, advocacy, and signposting to other agencies.

Referrals are taken through Sandwell Metropolitan Borough Council (Housing Solution Team) 
TEL: 0121 368 1166 0p 2

Out of hours housing support for young people 
16/17: 0121 569 3100 
18+: 0121 569 6883

The council initiates its severe weather emergency provision whenever the outside temperature is predicted to hit zero degrees or below. Access to this provision is co-ordinated by the council’s Housing Solutions team. 

To access severe weather emergency provision please contact the Housing Solutions team by calling 0121 368 1166 - option 2 or 0121 569 6883 outside of office hours

services.name: EWA CIC [European’s Welfare Association CIC]
services.description:
EWA CIC provides free English classes for adults whose first language is not English. The lessons are designed to help people gain confidence, build independence, and take part in local life.. EWA CIC also works with local councils and education partners to improve access to ESOL across the region.

For those seeking more information about our ESOL services, we encourage you to contact us directly at 0121 740 0824 and ask to speak with Natalia or Elizabeth.

services.name: EWA CIC [European’s Welfare Association CIC]
services.description:
Through Talking Therapies Plus, EWA CIC also offers support for people facing alcohol or drug-related challenges. Sessions are designed to help individuals understand their behaviours and take steps towards recovery. This service is delivered in partnership with the Black Country ICB and focuses on the needs of Polish and Ukrainian communities. 

For more information about our services and the assistance we provide, please feel free to contact us directly at info@ewacic.com or by calling 0121 740 0824. 
Please note that an appointment is necessary to see an advisor. 
Thank you for your understanding!

services.name: EWA CIC [European’s Welfare Association CIC]
services.description:
EWA CIC provides culturally sensitive mental health support for Polish and Ukrainian nationals through the Talking Therapies Plus project. This includes tailored one-to-one sessions to help with anxiety, low mood, and emotional wellbeing. The service is funded by the Black Country ICB and aims to make mental health care more accessible for migrant communities.

For more information about our services and the assistance we provide, please feel free to contact us directly at info@ewacic.com or by calling 0121 740 0824. 
Please note that an appointment is necessary to see an advisor. 
Thank you for your understanding!

services.name: EWA CIC [European’s Welfare Association CIC]
services.description:
Homes for Ukraine Scheme 
EWA CIC offers tailored support for Ukrainian nationals arriving through the Homes for Ukraine Scheme. Over 200 people in Sandwell and Birmingham have received help with housing, benefits, healthcare, English lessons, and finding work. The team also provides welfare checks, cultural activities, and practical day-to-day support. Their work has been recognised nationally as a model of good practice. 

For more information about our services and the assistance we provide, please feel free to contact us directly at info@ewacic.com or by calling 0121 740 0824. 
Please note that an appointment is necessary to see an advisor. 
Thank you for your understanding!

services.name: EWA CIC [European’s Welfare Association CIC]
services.description:
EWA CIC is registered with the Office of Immigration Services Commissioner (OISC) in Level 1 Immigration Asylum and Protection and EUSS Immigration. 
Advice is also available around matters such as housing, health, education, employment, welfare benefits and debt management. 

Support is aimed at Central and Eastern European migrants in the West Midlands 

For more information about our services and the assistance we provide, please feel free to contact us directly at info@ewacic.com or by calling 0121 740 0824. 
Please note that an appointment is necessary to see an advisor. 
Thank you for your understanding!

services.name: EWA CIC [European’s Welfare Association CIC]
services.description:
EWA CIC is registered with the Office of Immigration Services Commissioner (OISC) in Level 1 Immigration Asylum and Protection and EUSS Immigration.

services.name: Cranstoun: Sandwell
services.description:
Support around Drugs and Alcohol at Cranstoun Sandwell 
We know that the occasional alcoholic drink can quickly become two or three glasses every night.
Drinking alcohol can move from being an enjoyable activity to something that can damage your health, happiness and other areas of your life.
We also know that using drugs can be harmful, and can lead to difficulties with your health, housing, employment, money and family.
cranstoun: sandwell provides free and confidential advice and support to adults in Sandwell, who would like to talk about alcohol or drugs.
We want to empower and support people to make positive changes. 
We are here to help you, your family and friends.

services.name: Momma Claire Bear Foodbank
services.description:
Momma Claire Bear Foodbank can provide those in need with food parcels.
Get in touch if you need help.
You can also join the facebook group and request support there.

services.name: Yemeni Community Association in Sandwell
services.description:
The YCA has been running a number of activities with the aim of improving access to learning opportunities for adults and supporting children with school work. 

Course on offer at the YCA

Parent and Toddler at the Lodge Community Centre.

Wednesdays -10:00am - 12.00pm, (term-time only)

Please contact us on 0121 525 3909 for more information.

services.name: West Bromwich Food Bank
services.description:
The West Brom food bank opened in December 2007 and since then has fed literally thousands of residents in the town and the wider area of Sandwell. The food bank collects, sorts and stores food ready to freely give to those in need.

To access support from the food bank, you will need to visit one of our partner agencies who will carry out an assessment and issue a food voucher as appropriate. Once you have a voucher, bring it along to our centre and you will be able to exchange it for food.

On arrival at the food bank, clients will receive enough food for three days and we try and make it as nutritious as possible. In addition to food, we can offer toiletries etc and at times have even given out pet food!

services.name: Micro Rainbow
services.description:
Why we run safe houses dedicated solely to LGBTQI asylum seekers and refugees

In 76 countries homosexuality is illegal. 1,500 LGBTQI refugees from those countries come to the UK every year.

When they come to the UK they are still not safe. Because of their sexuality, gender identity, gender expression or intersex status they often:
are abused in refugee accommodation by other refugees who often come from the same countries they are escaping from
become homeless and depressed
are rejected by their ethnic community and live in poverty

What we are doing to help LGBTQI asylum seekers and refugees

Micro Rainbow opened the first safe house in the United Kingdom dedicated solely to LGBTQI asylum seekers and refugees. Our houses provide a safe and temporary shelter for all LGBTQI asylum seekers and refugees. They are located in the London area, in the North West and in the West Midlands.

If you need a translator, please email housing@microrainbow.org to arrange this in advance.
Our support line number is 0800 3585851. This number is free to call Mon-Fri 2pm-5pm. Our support line is for urgent matters

services.description:
SAWA runs a Befriending Club to provide services (including advice, free information, outreach advice, etc) to isolated refugee older women

This club also deliver classes on the use of Internet for the 50+ refugee women and asylum seekers from French speaking countries

services.description:

This is part of the SAWA Community Development Programme:

Under this programme, SAWA gives African refugee women, asylum seekers and girls a voice and chance to express themselves and represent the needs and aspirations of their communities. 

The Sewing & Tailoring Training Club meets on a Wednesday morning

services.description:
SAWA gives African refugee women, asylum seekers and girls a voice and chance to express themselves and represent the needs and aspirations of their communities.

services.description:

SAWA gives African refugee women, asylum seekers and girls a voice and chance to express themselves and represent the needs and aspirations of their communities.

services.name: The Pet Food Bank - Sandwell and Surrounding Areas
services.description:
The Pet Food Bank - Sandwell and Surrounding Areas is an initiative providing emergency help and support for pet owners who are experiencing financial hardship. 

Anyone referred into these services must provide a valid reason for needing this support.
Pet food parcels can be provided to those eligible on a short term emergency basis up to three times within a six month period. 

We currently only accept referrals for people living within the Sandwell and surrounding area. If you live outside of the eligibility area, unfortunately we cannot help at this time but feel free to contact us and we may be able to signpost you to another organisation.

Please fill in the Pet Food Bank referral form to apply for short term help with pet food. 

Any questions please call or email louisecolledge.petpantry@gmail.com or Kellyfletcher.petpantry@gmail.com

services.name: The Pet Food Bank - Sandwell and Surrounding Areas
services.description:

services.name: Black Country Womens Aid
services.description: BCWA offers expert training across the West Midlands on topics like domestic abuse, coercive control, sexual violence, forced marriage, FGM, modern slavery, and complex needs. Courses are available at all levels - from awareness to strategic development - and can be tailored for your organisation. BCWA is an Open College Network centre. Contact to discuss your training needs.

services.name: Black Country Womens Aid
services.description: Support for women referred by police after arrest, as a safe alternative to court. New Chance helps women address the reasons behind offending and avoid a criminal record. BCWA provides tailored support in Sandwell and Dudley. This includes one-to-one help, group sessions, and advice on housing, mental health, domestic abuse, and more. Women can also access food parcels and well-being packs. Police referral only. Referral form required.

services.name: Black Country Womens Aid
services.description:
Supportive courses for women affected by domestic abuse. Programmes include The Freedom Programme (understanding abuse and building self-esteem), The Power to Change (confidence, rights, and resilience), and You and Me, Mum (supporting children after abuse). All courses are safe spaces to learn, connect, and rebuild. Open to self-referral or referral - contact to join.

idva@blackcountrywomensaid.co.uk

0121 553 0090

services.name: Black Country Womens Aid
services.description:
Support for women who are homeless or at risk of homelessness in the Black Country. This includes women sleeping rough, hidden homeless, in refuge or supported housing. The team helps women find and keep safe accommodation, working with local partners. You can be referred by a professional or contact the team directly by phone or email.
 
tel: 0121 5530 090

email: willowproject@blackcountrywomensaid.co.uk

services.name: Black Country Womens Aid
services.description:
Support for women and children who have experienced rape, sexual violence, or childhood sexual abuse - whether recent or historic, and whether or not reported to police. Services include emotional support and practical help. Speak to an advisor to find out how BCWA can support you.

If you are from an agency and would like to refer someone you are working with please see our referral form.

services.name: Black Country Womens Aid
services.description: Support for people at risk of forced marriage, so-called honour-based abuse, or female genital mutilation (FGM). BCWA offers emotional support, safety planning, and practical help. They can advise on rights and legal protection, and help you stay safe. These are serious crimes. If you're worried, please call or email - talking to someone can really help.

services.name: Black Country Womens Aid
services.description: Black Country Women’s Aid supports people affected by domestic abuse, coercive control, sexual violence, and exploitation. They offer refuge, counselling, advocacy, and help with complex needs. Support includes children’s services, therapeutic care, and help for female offenders. Services cover Dudley, Walsall, Wolverhampton, and Sandwell. Most support is by referral - call or email to find out how to get help.

services.name: Ask Marc
services.description:
Domestic violence and abuse services @ Ask Marc

Support for men (16+) in Sandwell, Dudley, and Walsall facing:
Domestic abuse
"Honour” based violence
Forced marriage
We offer confidential advice and one-to-one support, including:
Independent Domestic Violence Advisors (IDVA)
Access to refuge accommodation if needed
Practical help and emotional support 
You don’t have to face it alone. We’ll listen, support you, and help you decide what’s right for you - without judgment.

&128222; 0121 289 6402 
&128231; info@askmarc.org.uk 
&128279; askmarc.org.uk/domestic-abuse 
&128196; Referral form for professionals

services.name: Ask Marc
services.description:
We support men and boys across Sandwell, Dudley, Walsall, and Wolverhampton who’ve experienced:
Rape
Sexual assault
Childhood sexual abuse 
It doesn’t matter when it happened or whether you’ve reported it. We’ll listen without judgment and support you at your pace.

You can speak to a male or female support worker. We'll help you feel safer, make informed choices, and move forward.

&128222; 0121 289 6402 
&128231; info@askmarc.org.uk 
&128279; askmarc.org.uk/sexual-violence 

&128196; Referral form for professionals

You’re not alone. We will believe you.
A project of Black Country Women’s Aid.

services.description: Support for survivors of modern slavery referred through the National Referral Mechanism (NRM). BCWA offers safe refuge for women, emotional support, trauma counselling, and help with healthcare and legal advice. They support people to rebuild confidence and plan next steps. If you think you are a victim of modern slavery, speak to the police, a support worker, or call the Modern Slavery Helpline on 08000 121 700 - they can help you access the NRM.

services.name: Sandwell Borough Council - Housing Support
services.description:
The Housing Solutions team offers support to those who are homeless or at risk of homelessness.

Our advice and assistance is free and confidential.

For customers who cannot access services online or via the telephone, the Local Centres are open to support customers in person. In addition to this Housing Officers will be holding surgeries the Central Library in West Bromwich to receive any housing-related enquiries in person

If you find yourself with nowhere to stay outside office hours or over the weekend please contact Housing Solutions out of hours 0121 569 6883 (24 hour callback service). We can only give advice in emergencies

services.name: The Kaleidoscope Plus Group
services.description:
At KPG, our counselling sessions offer you a safe space to talk about the issues you are facing and explore difficult feelings in a confidential, non-judgemental environment. 

We have a team of qualified and student counsellors from a wide range of counselling and psychotherapy backgrounds who are experienced in a diverse range of therapies. 

Our counselling sessions are flexible and open to individuals, couples, and families. We will aim to see you as quickly as possible, and our team of qualified and trainee counsellors can tailor sessions to offer you both long and short-term support. 

We aim to provide counselling to everyone who needs it, especially those who otherwise wouldn’t have access to the therapy they require. Whilst we do receive some donations, there is a cost attached to our counselling sessions. Where possible, and if funding through donations are available, you may be offered some free sessions to support you with how you are feeling, your wellbeing and your mental health

As we are a charity we do have to charge for our sessions, however on occasion we do receive funding to support our local communities. On occasion this means we may be able to reduce the cost for you to receive support. Whilst this isn’t always possible we are always here to talk and offer some support should you need it

Prices per session start at GBP 30, and depend on your income.
Do get in touch or visit our website to find out more: 

Due to social distancing restrictions surrounding COVID-19, our counselling service will not be taking place face-to-face. However, we’re still here to help.
 
Our counsellors are continuing to offer support through either telephone or virtual online chat, held via Zoom or Microsoft Teams.

If you would like to find out more, 
email: counselling@kaleidoscopeplus.org.uk 
call: 0121 565 5605 
Click the link to have a look at our counselling information leaflet
Self refer via this online form

services.name: The Kaleidoscope Plus Group
services.description:
Primary Mental Health Workers

Supporting children, young people, families and carers

About

If you’re going through a difficult time or are struggling with how you’re feeling, it can be scary and upsetting and you might not know who to turn to for help.

At Kaleidoscope, our Primary Mental Health Workers (PMHW’s) specialise in children and young people’s emotional and mental health and wellbeing and can offer support to both you and your family when things get tough.

We will listen to you without judgement in a safe environment and work with you to improve your social skills as well as your wellbeing and take away some any immediate pressures

What type of support will I receive?

Our PMHW’s will carry out an assessment to find out more about what kind of support might be suitable for you. The type of support you will be offered will be dependent on this assessment

Who can access this service?

Our PMHW service is for children and young people aged 16 and under, however the support we offer is suitable for the whole family.

If you are a parent or carer and are finding life a little difficult, need additional support to help manage your child’s wellbeing or are worried about violence or substance abuse, we can help.

We can also offer support to help you understand what a care giving role looks like and how it should be received. 

How can I get a referral?

To be referred to our PMHW service please email our partners CAMHS (Child and Adolescent Mental Health Service).

CAMHS will act on your behalf to get a referral to our service.
Email: Bchft.sandwellspa@nhs.net 
Tel: 0121 6126620

Download our information leaflet for more details

services.name: The Kaleidoscope Plus Group
services.description:
Sanctuary Hub
At the Kaleidoscope Sanctuary Hub you will be able to speak to a friendly support worker, who will give you a safe space to talk. We will listen, support, offer advice and empower your recovery journey. This service offers face to face appointments, along with telephone, text and email support.

Our service runs from Hope Place which is situated on the High Street in West Bromwich and is designed to support you personally or if you are concerned about a family member or friend.

Our Kaleidoscope Sanctuary Hub is available 365 days a year

Am I eligible?

The Kaleidoscope Sanctuary Hub is can be accessed by
*People over 18 years of age
Those who have a home to return to following attending
People who have the capacity to make an informed decision regarding support
People willing to work with the staff
Those identified as having primary mental health needs
Residents of Sandwell or are registered with a Sandwell GP

Call - 0800 008 6516⁠ any day of the week during operating hours for a phone consultation
Email - Hub@kaleidoscopeplus.org.uk⁠
Text/WhatsApp - 07800006472⁠

services.name: The Kaleidoscope Plus Group
services.description:
Independent Living Service (ILS)

You may find you require a little extra support to be able to live independently and this is where we can help.

Our Independent Living Service (ILS) provides support in your own home to increase your independence so that you can live a healthy and enjoyable life.

How much support and what type of support you receive is dependent on your needs

Our Support Workers will work with you to create a package of care which will include:
Teaching you skills including cooking, cleaning and budgeting.
Helping you to access activities within the local community.
Helping you to maintain a tenancy.
Ensure your utility bills are paid.
Encourage you to keep the property to a good standard.
Offering emotional support and guidance to improve your mental health and wellbeing.

We will ensure your medical and social care needs are monitored and offer you guidance on how and when to take your medication. Should you need further care or support, we work in partnership with community teams and organisations and can signpost to these if necessary.

If you require 24-hour support, you must be happy to house share with one other person and feel comfortable with a support worker sleeping in a third bedroom overnight. However, if you only require a number of hours support per week, we will devise a care package with you to meet your needs.

People accessing this service have been assessed to be safe in the community but could potentially become unwell quite quickly so need additional support to live well and maintain some independence.

You can complete a referral for yourself or someone you support by clicking this link

Download our information leaflet for more details

For more information please email Vicki Fox, Care Services Manager:
E: Vicki.Fox@Kaleidoscopeplus.org.uk

services.name: The Kaleidoscope Plus Group
services.description:
Midlands Suicide Bereavement Support

This free bereavement service is available to anyone aged over 18 who has been affected by suicide

First Tuesday of every month 7:30pm-9pm

To join the group, or for more information, get in touch: 
 - SPPARK@Kaleidoscopeplus.org.uk
 - 07970040016

services.name: The Kaleidoscope Plus Group
services.description:
Shout Text Support Line

Text TeamKPG to 85258 at any time 24/7 for free, confidential support for your mental health that does not show on your phone bill. A volunteer will be on hand to offer you immediate support helping you to reach a calm and safe solution to the problem you are facing.

services.name: The Kaleidoscope Plus Group
services.description:
Mental Health Training Courses

Whether you are an individual or a business, we can provide you with the right tools and coping strategies, helping to promote positive mental wellbeing and recovery.

Our friendly qualified Trainers are committed to delivering high quality, evidence-based training to help break the stigma and discrimination associated with mental health.

You will always be welcomed with an approachable friendly face in a relaxed and comfortable environment.

Our Training

We offer a wide range of training courses, workshops and taster sessions which will help you to understand mental ill health, identifying what steps you should take to support others as well as yourself.

Our courses can be bespoke and tailored to meet your specific needs or requirements and our team are flexible and will work with you on your preferred dates, times and durations.

Please note: Due to the current national restrictions all our Live mental health courses have been moved to a virtual offering until further notice.

View Training Calendar

services.description:

We offer the following advice:
Debt referrals
Welfare benefit application form filling
Housing related support (i.e. accommodation form filling) -Private & Social landlords
British/Yemeni passport application form filling
Advocacy
Winter fuel benefit advice
Maximising Welfare Benefit Income Checks
Adult Social Care referrals

Fridays from [10:30am - 1.30pm]

services.name: The Salvation Army - Oldbury
services.description:
Employment Plus Local

Every Tuesday our Employment Plus team provide an open access employability service. No need for an appointment just visit us during the above time with a form of identification, whereupon our team of Employability professionals are on hand to support your needs - whether this be
Help with Job Searching and advice meeting your Claimant Commitment
Support navigating the benefit system, including making your Job Centre Plus claim
Help improving your CV
Money Management, Tenancy Support, Interview Techniques etc
If you're struggling on Universal Credit we can offer help and advice around payments and deductions
Digital Inclusion - helping you access the internet and use a computer safely

To find out more get in touch via email employmentplus@salvationarmy.org.uk or by phone 0800 652 4276

services.name: The Salvation Army - Oldbury
services.description:
Community Cafe

A place where people can COME, MEET, BE.

We want people to come together to meet other people from the community and just be themselves in a safe, friendly and welcoming environment.

The Community Cafe is to be a place for all people, of all ages, at the heart of their local community. A place where as a Church we can radiate God’s love and reach out in practical ways to the people we come into contact with. We aim to build relationships that are long lasting, offer help, support, prayer and a listening ear.

The Community Cafe also wants to give people the opportunity to explore their more creative side. We aim to work towards a variety of 'craft' projects throughout the year to contribute to different aspects of our community.

services.name: The Salvation Army - Oldbury
services.description:
DEBT ADVICE SERVICE

By Appointment only please call 0121 552 6901 or 07342 999496

services.name: The Salvation Army - Oldbury
services.description:
GARDENING GROUP

The church and community centre is on a 2 acre plot and during the growing season requires a lot of love and attention. We have a volunteer team who work in all weathers on a Friday morning to love and nurture God’s creation, please come and be part of this group for enjoying God’s creation and companionship together. 

We meet Thursday mornings weather permitting
For more details please contact 0121 552 6901.

services.name: Citizens Advice - Sandwell and Walsall
services.description:
The Citizens Advice service offers information and advice through face-to-face, phone and online services.

CA Smethwick
Mondays - Thursday feel free to drop in during opening hours
Fridays - face to face sessions are appointment only

With our drop in service we aim to help you with any issues you may have, big or small. 

If you drop in to one of our offices we will make every effort to deal with your issue at the time, however some queries will require more in depth advice, and we can book you in with one of our specialist advisers. 

We will initially ask some questions to find out about your issue, so that we can work out the best way that we can help you.

All of our advisers are trained and able to deal with your queries. We are here to give people the knowledge and confidence to move forward, whatever their problem may be.

Contact Us
smethwick@citizensadvicesandwell-walsall.org

services.name: New Beginnings Community
services.description:
The Birthday Project

Celebrations bring people together, promote well-being, give a sense of tradition, and help us to remember the things in life that truly matter. Birthday celebrations allow us to acknowledge those in our lives who are important to us and celebrate the gift of their lives.

When a child’s birthday approaches, some parents often get excited and prepare in advance to celebrate the occasion. But for some families it can be a difficult time of year. For Children living in extreme poverty rarely get to celebrate their birthdays. 

We at New Beginnings Community believe that every child deserves to feel special and celebrated on their birthday.

The Birthday Project provides children in need (up to the age of 11) with a ‘Birthday-In-A-Bag’ to ensure they do not go without on this special occasions. Each pack contains at least 2 presents, chocolates, or sweets, wrapping paper, sellotape, a birthday card, and party decorations. Other items that may be included are party hats, badges, cake mix, frosting and candles depending on supplies

Referrals are made via the help of health professionals, local food banks, community navigators, faith groups, who work directly with these families. Our Birthday Project volunteers then lovingly collect sort and package a ‘Birthday-In-A-Bag’ for the child based on the child’s age and interests. These are then collected by the referral agent and delivered to the parent of the child hopefully about a month before the child’s birthday.

Most of the contents of our packs will be donated by our generous community who already donate toys to New Beginnings Community on a regular basis.

For more details or to refer into the service, please email thebirthdayproject@newbeginningscommunity.co.uk 
You can also visit our Birthday Project Facebook page

services.name: New Beginnings Community
services.description:
New Beginnings Baby Bundles

New Beginnings provides Moses Basket packs for the most vulnerable mothers and their new babies in our community. To safeguard the recipients of our New Beginnings packs we do not meet the end user but take referrals from midwives, health visitors and other agency workers. The packs are then taken out to the families by the person who has made the referral.

Our New Beginnings Baby Bundles packs contain 
a Moses Basket 
clothing
toiletries 
essential equipment gifted to families in need.

Most of the contents of our packs are donated by our generous community. We process the donations as they come in and pack up lovely parcels of Moses Basket, clothes, toiletries and other essential items ready to be taken out as gifts to families in real need. We believe that for some of our families this may be the nicest thing that they have ever received and take pride in making our newborn bundles the very best we can.

At present we are only able to supply starter packs to women in the Sandwell & West Birmingham area due to storage and the fact our items are donated.

Referrals are made via the help of midwives, health visitors and other professional groups, who work directly with these families. Our New Beginnings volunteers then lovingly collect sort and package a Moses Basket newborn bundle of clothing, toiletries, and essential baby equipment as an attractive gift to the new mothers, who then receive the gift hopefully about a month before the due date.

 Details of items you can expect to be included in the baby bundle can be viewed on our website

This service is offered free of charge, simply to care for those in need within our community.

More information can also be found on our dedicated New Beginnings Baby Bundles Facebook Page

services.name: New Beginnings Community
services.description:
Warm Space @ New Beginnings

At Warm Spaces, you can also have a chat with staff about other support services available. Get advice and information about benefits, energy support, managing bills, how local charities can help, and how to access community support to combat isolation.

Wherever you live in Sandwell, you can access any of our Warm Spaces.

Fancy a Brew? 
Fancy a brew is the warm space and place of welcome at St Mark's. It is held during school term time on a Wednesday

As well as somewhere warm for a hot drink and company, Fancy a Brew also offers attendees a free breakfast.

services.name: Smethwick Pantry [Your Local Pantry Network]
services.description:
We are open every Wednesday from 10:00-3.00 for Pantry Members only. The weekly membership fee is GBP 5 and each member is assigned a time slot to complete their shop. Please remember to bring your freezer bags.

Please note that Your Local Pantry: Smethwick is not currently accepting new members. If your application is accepted, we can place you on our waiting list and will get in touch when a space becomes available.

This pantry is part of Smethwick Church Action Network which is a joint response from Smethwick’s churches to serve our neighbours in times of crisis and help facilitate a transition from a place of need, to one of opportunity, hope and self-sufficiency.

services.description: Supported housing project for women with mental health issues.

services.name: Smethwick Trussell Foodbank
services.description:
If you need help from Smethwick Foodbank there are a few simple steps to follow.
Get a Foodbank Voucher If you call or email our foodbank (at any time) we can talk through your situation and put you in touch with a relevant local agency who can issue you with a voucher.
Visit the referral agency They will discuss your situation and supply you with a foodbank voucher where appropriate.

If you are in financial crisis and live in England or Wales, please call 0808 2082138 for free (open Monday to Friday, 9am-5pm) to talk confidentially with a trained Citizens Advice adviser. They can help address your crises and provide support to maximise your income, help you navigate the benefits system, and identify any additional grants you could be entitled to. If needed, they’ll issue you with a voucher so you can get an emergency food parcel from your local food bank.
Collecting your food parcel We are not currently offering a service to the public indoors. Food will be provided to those who have a referral voucher or e Code at the door of Holy Trinity Church. Clients are encouraged to wait in line with social distancing and to wear a mask.

services.name: St Basils
services.description:
St Basils’ Live and Work Scheme in Sandwell offers low-cost, supportive housing for young people aged 18-25 who are working, in an apprenticeship, or have a confirmed offer of work. Residents can stay for up to two years or until the day before their 26th birthday, with a minimum tenancy of 9 months. The scheme includes 86 properties at Hallam Close, designed for young people to manage their tenancies independently, with guidance available from friendly on-site staff. Rent is kept low to help residents cover expenses without relying on benefits.

Young people - Apply to Live and Work 

or contact liveandwork@stbasils.org.uk.

services.name: Job Centre Plus
services.description:
Job Centre Plus provides support into employment. 
Employment related benefits such and ESA can also be applied for and dealt with in the JobCentre Plus offices. 
If you wish to use the JobCentre Plus services, you can start the process by telephoning your local office and making an appointment or popping in and talking to someone face to face. This office now offers services to a whole range of people, from the employers advertising jobs, unemployed people looking for work, part time employees looking to get more work, students and school leavers looking to enter the job market and people with special needs who need a bit more assistance in getting a job. 
Offering schemes to help people find work or develop skills, they work closely with the local communities organising work initiatives and volunteering schemes to help people gain experience in their chosen field of work.

services.name: YMCA - High Street
services.description: Supported Housing for young people

services.name: Dorothy Parkes Community Centre
services.description:
Cocaine Anonymous

Support group for anyone with issues around alcohol and drugs.

For more information, please call Tony on 07538 588986

Meeting every Monday 7.30pm - 8.30pm

services.name: Dorothy Parkes Community Centre
services.description:
Dottie's Community Fridge

This exciting project offers free surplus food to anyone in need, thanks to generous funding from Hubbub and Heart of England Community Foundation.

Dottie's Community Fridge aims to reduce food waste while supporting our local community. The fridge will be stocked with surplus food, available free of charge on Tuesdays and Fridays. It's our hope that this initiative will make a real difference, providing people with access to healthy, nutritious food while reducing unnecessary waste.

How Dottie's Community Fridge Works

Dottie's Community Fridge is here to serve everyone. Whether you're facing financial challenges, looking to reduce your own food waste, or simply want to access surplus food in a convenient location, the fridge is available to all. It operates on a no-questions-asked basis, ensuring that anyone who needs food can easily access it without judgment.

Simply visit the Dorothy Parkes Centre on Tuesdays and Fridays between 10am and 2pm to see what’s available. Whether it’s fresh fruit, vegetables, bread, or packaged items, there will always be a variety of options for you to take home.

services.name: Dorothy Parkes Community Centre
services.description:
Place of Welcome @ Dorothy Parkes Centre

Sessions take place every Friday morning, with a cuppa and some conversation offered to anyone who drops in - and you can stay as little or as long as you like during the session time of 10-12. Support and signposting to local services is also available.

A member of the national Places of Welcome scheme

services.name: Brushstrokes Community Project
services.description:
Brushstrokes offers advice and support for people seeking asylum in Sandwell and West Birmingham. Trained staff and volunteers provide one-to-one guidance to help people understand and navigate the asylum process. This includes outreach visits, help with housing transitions, and support through the Asylum Guides programme.

You can also train as a volunteer Asylum Guide to support others on their journey.

Contact: elmugiera@brushstrokessandwell.org.uk

services.name: Brushstrokes Community Project
services.description:
Immigration Clinic
 
Brushstrokes offers free, regulated immigration advice for people at any stage of the immigration process. Support is available up to Level 3, including help with applications, appeals, visa extensions, settlement, and family reunion. The service is accredited by the Immigration Services Commissioner.

services.name: Brushstrokes Community Project
services.description:
We support families and individuals in Birmingham and the Black Country, especially asylum seekers and refugees with little or no access to public funding by providing practical resources of food, clothing and household essentials to people who are experiencing great need.

We give out non-perishable food items, clothing, blankets and bedding, and other essential household items. The needs of the people we help change according to the time of year. We therefore appeal for seasonal items such as hats, scarves and gloves in autumn and winter.

We distribute donated items to benefit the asylum seekers, refugees and others in need who we support. Occasionally, if we have items which are unsuitable for distribution or we haven’t capacity to store them, we either offer them to other charities supporting vulnerable groups, or sell them to raise valuable funds for our work.

services.name: Brushstrokes Community Project
services.description:
Through the provision of ESOL and volunteering opportunities individuals have been able to improve their work readiness this year. Since September 2016 the provision of a weekly work club has supported 63 individuals.

 

Refugees, EU migrants and individuals who have come to the UK to join family have been making use of this service seeking help with writing CVs, Job search and developing the skills and capacity to complete applications and write cover letters.

 

Referrals come from the Job Centre, other community organisations and other Brushstrokes projects, such as our Homelessness Prevention Pathway. Weekly attendance at work club ranges from 5 to 10 at present. 

We are open every Wednesday but people need to book appointments.

services.description:
Our Bump Start packs contain essential items for new and expectant mothers, such as nappies, clothes, blankets, bottles, Moses baskets, baby wipes and toys. These are our most requested item and we are always in need of donations of items for newborns.

We distribute donated items to benefit the asylum seekers, refugees and others in need who we support. Occasionally, if we have items which are unsuitable for distribution or we haven’t capacity to store them, we either offer them to other charities supporting vulnerable groups, or sell them to raise valuable funds for our work.

services.name: Brushstrokes Community Project
services.description:
Housing advice
Refugee Homelessness Prevention

Brushstrokes is helping to deliver a unique approach for refugees in Sandwell. 
Working alongside Sandwell Council we are providing tailored support to help people manage the transition from asylum support to settled status as refugees. 
 
Through outreach and office based work, everyone who receives a positive decision on their asylum claim while they are accommodated in Sandwell, is offered dedicated casework support. The service includes advice and support to address housing options, accessing benefits, advice on their education, employment and training options and provides ongoing resettlement support.
 
Anyone granted refugee status in the other areas where we are working, such as west Birmingham, can also receive assistance with resettlement from our advice team.

services.description:
Our Bump Start packs contain essential items for new and expectant mothers, such as nappies, clothes, blankets, bottles, Moses baskets, baby wipes and toys. These are our most requested item and we are always in need of donations of items for newborns.

We distribute donated items to benefit the asylum seekers, refugees and others in need who we support. Occasionally, if we have items which are unsuitable for distribution or we haven’t capacity to store them, we either offer them to other charities supporting vulnerable groups, or sell them to raise valuable funds for our work.

services.name: Brushstrokes Community Project
services.description:
The Friday Community Cafe, run by staff and volunteers, is open to all members of the community.

The Cafe is a great place of welcome serving approximately 46% of meals to refugees and asylum seekers with the remaining 54% to individuals who are homeless or who are local residents.

 

We also invite our neighbours and local residents to our special events, such as sharing food from around the world at Interfaith Lunch, Big Lunch, St Patrick’s Day Lunch and Easter celebrations.

services.name: Brushstrokes Community Project
services.description:
Life in the UK

We run a Life in the UK class runs every Wednesday from 10 - 11.30am. This course runs for two terms and prepares people for the Life in the UK test. We use comprehensive resources and multimedia to bring the course to life and help people understand the, often, bewildering amount of information they need to learn. Learners should be at Entry 2 or Entry 3 to access this course.

services.name: Brushstrokes Community Project
services.description:
With over 200 learners, Brushstrokes is one of the largest providers of ESOL in the Smethwick area. Staffed by a dedicated and enthusiastic team of volunteer teachers and classroom assistants and a qualified ESOL Coordinator, we provide courses ranging from compete beginners to academic IELTS.

ESOL

We have no criteria for acceptance onto any of our ESOL courses but prioritise asylum seekers wherever possible. Our largest ESOL cohort is always beginners and we encourage learners to access college provision when they feel confident to do so. ESOL courses range from beginners to Entry 3 including a phonics class to help people with no reading skills. 

 

 
If you would like to learn English at Brushstrokes, please click on the link and complete our enquiry form.

 

https://forms.gle/vDojQQ6oXH8Bk2Ni6

The Housing Solutions team offers support to those who are homeless or at risk of homelessness.

Our advice and assistance is free and confidential.

services.name: Kings Community Church, Oldbury
services.description:
King's Community Church has partnered with Christians Against Poverty CAP to offer free and confidential debt counselling in the community

CAP provides free professional debt help, job clubs, life skills groups and money education in the heart of communities like KC Church's. All CAP's services are delivered face-to-face through local churches, which means you’ll receive both the practical and emotional support you need on your journey.

CAP and Kings Community Church can provide debt counselling, advice and practical help to empower people to manage their money better and learn to budget, save and spend well.

How do I get help?

Anyone who wishes to access the support of CAP at Kings Community Church will need to contact CAP in the first instance.
To get help with debt or to access the money course, please call 0800 328 0006 to arrange an appointment.

services.name: Handsworth Birmingham Trussell Foodbank
services.description:
If you need help from Handsworth Foodbank there are a few simple steps to follow.
Get a Foodbank Voucher
If you call or email our foodbank (at any time) we can talk through your situation and put you in touch with a relevant local agency who can issue you with a voucher.
Visit the referral agency
They will discuss your situation and supply you with a foodbank voucher where appropriate.

If you are in financial crisis and live in England or Wales, please call 0808 2082138 for free (open Monday to Friday, 9am-5pm) to talk confidentially with a trained Citizens Advice adviser. They can help address your crises and provide support to maximise your income, help you navigate the benefits system, and identify any additional grants you could be entitled to. If needed, they’ll issue you with a voucher so you can get an emergency food parcel from your local food bank.
Bring your foodbank voucher to Handsworth Foodbank
When you arrive, we’ll welcome you with a warm drink and our trained volunteers will chat with you about your situation. We’ll also discuss any dietary needs you may have and exchange your foodbank voucher for a parcel of three days of emergency food. 

We’ll also help to support you in any other ways that we can. Most of our foodbank centres offer a cafe style environment and our aim is to provide non-judgemental support at the point of crisis.

services.name: Family Hub Network - Dudley
services.description:
All Family Hub Networks in Dudley can provide Food bank vouchers for the Black Country Foodbank

Black Country Foodbank helps vulnerable individuals and families in crisis through the provision of 3 days emergency food supplies while a longer-term solution is developed.

You must have a voucher or a code to be able to receive a food parcel at the distribution centres

services.name: Al-Anon family groups
services.description:
Al-Anon Family Groups meeting is about helping you to find solace with and support from others who have been affected by their relationship with a drinker.
Meeting day: Monday
Meeting time: 20:00
Accessibility: No disabled access

Helpline is available every day of the year from 10am to 10pm. 0800 0086 811

services.name: Churches Housing Association of Dudley District [ CHADD ]
services.description:
New Beginnings: Supporting Victims of Domestic Abuse @ CHADD

New Beginnings offer a wide range of support, projects and services to help those who are suffering domestic abuse (DA). These services, help support individuals to overcome domestic abuse as well as help build resilience, self confidence and a brighter future
Refuge accommodation: We offer emergency accommodation and ‘breathing space’ to help you focus on personal issues without pressure and fear. The accommodation is a secured safe haven for you and your children.
Outreach Team We have an outreach team who work with an individual to explore the tailored support required and help create a plan that ensures they and their immediate family are safe and not alone. The support offered is provided through general outreach programmes of support groups, drop-in, and one-one support and in addition through a number of specialised projects

How to contact us 
If you are suffering from domestic abuse, there is help available from people who understand what you’ve been going through and won’t judge you.
Please call 01384 864334 (24hr operated) if you require refuge accommodation
Please call 01384 864232 if you wish to speak with the outreach team.
Alternatively, you can email our team in confidence on dat@chadd.org.uk

services.name: Churches Housing Association of Dudley District [ CHADD ]
services.description:
On Route Foyer: Support for Young People @ CHADD

The Foyer works with young people who are homeless or at risk of homelessness. Providing a safe, stimulating and supportive environment where they have the opportunity to develop Skills 4 Life including employability skills and making new friends along the way. Young people journey towards independence is supported by their key worker who will provide guidance and support for young people to reach their goals and aspirations.

How do I apply for accommodation on the Foyer? 
Young people can visit the Council Plus, Homeless Persons section, 259 Castle St Dudley and request a referral to the Foyer or if you have a social worker, Connexions worker, college tutor or other agency worker they can support you with a referral. Many of these support agencies have the Foyer application forms or you can contact the Foyer directly for a form or down load an application from our web page.

Contact On Route Foyer 
01384 456465 (During office Hours) 01384 455464 (Out of Office Hours)
foyer.admin@chadd.org.uk

services.name: St Germains Community Hub
services.description: Our Drop-In runs alongside the church’s Community Café and provides an opportunity to get help with emotional and practical problems, without the need for an appointment. You can just turn up and speak with a member of our team, which includes Emotional Wellbeing Practitioners, Listening Volunteers, local Community Network Support Officers from the Council and Welfare Rights Advisers (who can help with benefits issues). If you are interested in specific support with practical concerns, e.g. housing or benefits, it’s best to email (wellbeinghub@stgermains.org.uk) or call (0121 517 0476) us first to check when the relevant support professional will next be at the Drop-In.

services.name: St Germains Community Hub
services.description: Our friends at The Real Junk Food Project (Central) have opened a Pay As You feel cafe in the church hall. Open from 12-2.30pm every Monday and Friday, the menu depends on what produce is available. If you need to get in touch, please contact food@stgermains.org.uk.

services.name: St Germains Community Hub
services.description:
Here at St Germain's we run a shop in partnership with The Real Junk Food Project
The food and items that we provide are Pay As You Feel, or PAYF for short.
That means you contribute however you can to the success of our project: donating your time, skills, money, or something even more imaginative! If you need to get in touch, please contact food@stgermains.org.uk.

services.description:
Green Doctors offer free home visits to help people stay warm, save money, and reduce energy use. Our team gives advice on cutting fuel bills and making your home more efficient. We support people with health conditions, low incomes, or poor housing. We also look for issues like damp and mould that affect your wellbeing.

If you would like a visit from our Green Doctors please email 
 wmgreendoctor@groundwork.org.uk

services.name: Groundwork West Midlands
services.description:
Groundwork West Midlands delivers the Restart Scheme in partnership with Serco and the Department for Work and Pensions. This service supports people on benefits to move into long-term work. Our team works with each person to build a tailored plan. We connect participants to local employers, including well-known national brands.

Email - wmenquiries@groundwork.org.uk

services.name: Citizens Advice - Sandwell and Walsall
services.description:
The Citizens Advice service offers information and advice through face-to-face, phone and online services.

CA Tipton
Face to face advice sessions will be available Mondays and Wednesdays.

With our drop in service we aim to help you with any issues you may have, big or small. 

If you drop in to one of our offices we will make every effort to deal with your issue at the time, however some queries will require more in depth advice, and we can book you in with one of our specialist advisers. 

We will initially ask some questions to find out about your issue, so that we can work out the best way that we can help you.

All of our advisers are trained and able to deal with your queries. We are here to give people the knowledge and confidence to move forward, whatever their problem may be.

Contact Us
cradleytipton@citizensadvicesandwell-walsall.org

services.name: Cranstoun: Here4YOUth - Dudley
services.description:
Cranstoun Here4YOUth in Dudley, offers a safe space for young people (aged 11-18 yrs, up to 25 with additional need or a care leaver) to talk about and receive support for alcohol and other drugs and connects to health and wellbeing interventions. We empower young people to make positive changes, to improve their well-being for a brighter, safer future

You’re welcome to come along during our open access time Wednesdays 3.00pm - 6.30pm where you can meet our friendly team.

services.name: Cranstoun: Here4YOUth - Dudley
services.description:
At Here4YOUth we can connect you to the Brook Sexual Health Service

Here4YOUth can support you to access free condoms, pregnancy testing and Chlamydia/Gonorrhoea testing 

No appointment necessary, give us a call during opening hours, book an appointment via our website or come along during our drop in sessions.

services.name: Cranstoun: Here4YOUth - Dudley
services.description:
Here4YOUth is here to help you learn facts about alcohol, your drinking and support with making any changes. 

When you work alongside Here4YOUth, you will have access to the following:
Information and harm reduction advice for alcohol and other drugs
Set goals to make changes if using alcohol and other drugs
Help to stop smoking (16-18 year olds)
*Attend Smashed our alcohol programme

You can make a self referral via our website or come to our walk-in on a Wednesday evening 15:00-18:30.

services.name: Job Centre Plus
services.description:
Job Centre Plus provides support into employment. 
Employment related benefits such and ESA can also be applied for and dealt with in the JobCentre Plus offices. 
If you wish to use the JobCentre Plus services, you can start the process by telephoning your local office and making an appointment or popping in and talking to someone face to face. This office now offers services to a whole range of people, from the employers advertising jobs, unemployed people looking for work, part time employees looking to get more work, students and school leavers looking to enter the job market and people with special needs who need a bit more assistance in getting a job. 
Offering schemes to help people find work or develop skills, they work closely with the local communities organising work initiatives and volunteering schemes to help people gain experience in their chosen field of work.

services.name: Incredible Surplus
services.description:
Winson Green

Originally established in 2014 as The Real Junk Food Project Birmingham, we intercept food and other usable materials that would otherwise go to waste from supermarkets, restaurants and other sources, and provide them to individuals and community organisations on a “Pay-As-You-Feel” basis.

We welcome everyone that wants to come and shop with us at our Winson Green site.

All we ask is that you please:
Respect our volunteers and each other.
Please park on the approach road and walk to the Sharehouse, and request taxis drop-off/pick-up there too - we need access for deliveries, as do our neighbours - there is no room for customer/volunteer cars.
We have trolleys and can help you to take your shopping to your vehicle if needed - please just ask.
Please sign in with your name and postcode - everyone is welcome, you don’t have to be local; we just like to know where people are travelling from.
Food is for personal use only - you cannot shop for friends/family, or to sell on. By all means tell your friends/family to come down and shop with us too, though!
Only take what you need and leave what you don’t - we may ask you to put some things back if you take too much of a single item - it’s only fair to leave enough for others.
Any questions, just ask.

services.name: Birmingham and Solihull Womens Aid
services.description:
Every day, Birmingham and Solihull Women’s Aid helps women who make the difficult decision to ask for help and get in contact with us.

Our helpline team is specially trained to listen and help you if you are concerned about your safety, need to leave your home, worried about money, your health or wellbeing, or your children.

Contact our free Helpline on 0808 800 0028

services.name: Solihull Churches Action on Homelessness [SCAH]
services.description:
SCAH will fund debt relief orders (DROs) which can prevent a tenant caught by rent arrears and with limited resources from being evicted, thus avoiding homelessness. 

DROs are a simplified, quicker and cheaper alternative to bankruptcy as an insolvency measure in the United Kingdom, which came into effect in England and Wales on 6 April 2009. 

DROs are suitable for debtors who have relatively low liabilities, little surplus income and few assets; can (depending on eligibility) be a viable alternative to other insolvency measures, such as Individual Voluntary Arrangements (IVAs), and when bankruptcy would be disproportionate; and allow vulnerable people trapped in debt to have a fresh start. 

Solihull Community Housing (SCH) is our main partner with regard to DROs. 

The fee is GBP 90 which can be funded by SCAH.

To request support please email secretary@scah.org.uk

services.name: Solihull Churches Action on Homelessness [SCAH]
services.description:
Starter Packs

Currently, the bulk of SCAH's work consists of the assembling and distribution of 'starter packs' in liaison with our partners, including 
Solihull Metropolitan Borough Council (SMBC)
Age UK
Solihull Integrated Addiction Services (SIAS)
Bromford Housing
Green Square Accord,
BSWA
SCH
CRC Probation, 
St. Basil's 

A 'starter pack', generally consists of new, value-for-money, non-food, household items such as bedding, crockery, cutlery, kitchen and cleaning items etc. 

The 'starter pack' helps those people of limited resources, those leaving homelessness, those leaving prison etc. to set up home in a new tenancy. 

The shopper, in conjunction with the partner organisation (which works directly with the client(s)) tailors the starter pack to the specific requirements of the client

To request support please email secretary@scah.org.uk

services.name: Micro Rainbow
services.description:
Why we run safe houses dedicated solely to LGBTQI asylum seekers and refugees

In 76 countries homosexuality is illegal. 1,500 LGBTQI refugees from those countries come to the UK every year.

When they come to the UK they are still not safe. Because of their sexuality, gender identity, gender expression or intersex status they often:
are abused in refugee accommodation by other refugees who often come from the same countries they are escaping from
become homeless and depressed
are rejected by their ethnic community and live in poverty

What we are doing to help LGBTQI asylum seekers and refugees

Micro Rainbow opened the first safe house in the United Kingdom dedicated solely to LGBTQI asylum seekers and refugees. Our houses provide a safe and temporary shelter for all LGBTQI asylum seekers and refugees. They are located in the London area, in the North West and in the West Midlands.

If you need a translator, please email housing@microrainbow.org to arrange this in advance.
Our support line number is 0800 3585851. This number is free to call Mon-Fri 2pm-5pm. Our support line is for urgent matters

services.name: Samaritans - Solihull
services.description:
The Samaritans are available by telephone all day, all night, any day of the year.

If you need someone to talk to, we listen. We won't judge or tell you what to do
Whatever you're going through, you can call us any time, from any phone for FREE.

Call: 116 123

This number is free to call from both landlines and mobiles, including pay-as-you-go mobiles. You do not need to have any credit or call allowance on your plan to call 116 123

What happens when you call us?
A volunteer will answer

If you phone us, we will answer with something like "Samaritans, can I help you?"
You talk, we listen

We listen to you and help you talk through your concerns, worries and troubles
We give you space to be yourself

We'll focus on your thoughts and feelings, and may ask questions to help you explore how you feel.
We won't tell you what you should do

We won't make decisions for you, our advice or opinions are not important for the call.

We offer a safe place for you to talk any time you like, in your own way - about whatever’s getting to you.

services.name: Mildenhall House
services.description: Semi-Supported scheme

services.name: UK Mens Sheds Association
services.description:
The Marie Curie Men’s Shed group is for local men who are bereaved, or are living with a palliative diagnosis themselves, or are caring for a loved one with a palliative diagnosis.

This group started meeting in 2016. The founder members worked together with Marie Curie hospice, and the Men’s Shed group is now very well-established and growing. Money was raised to purchase a large, free-standing, purpose built shed which was erected in 2020 in the hospice grounds surrounded by our beautiful gardens.

The Men’s Shed offers an environment where men of all ages can get together for support and companionship. It is a ‘drop in’ group run by experienced volunteers. Each session lasts approximately 2.5 hours and group size varies but is usually around 10-15. The programme includes a variety of activities, including games, art therapy, speakers and outings.

The supportive environment created in the Shed is a safe space for men to not only socialise with camaraderie but also to talk about their troubles if they choose to - without any pressure.

New members welcome!

For further information please contact:

T: 0121 703 3600 - E: lisa.shyamalan@mariecurie.org.uk

Men’s Sheds are kitted out community spaces where men can enjoy practical hobbies.

They’re about making friends, learning and sharing skills. Many guys come just for the tea and banter - everyone’s welcome.

WM Postive Pathways: Universal Prevention & Move On Support

services.name: Clouds End CIC
services.description:
Hoarding Awareness Training @ Clouds End CIC

We are currently the UK’s leading training provider for Hoarding Awareness training. 

Why learn with Clouds End Training Ltd?
We bring both experience and now an accredited qualification which can take you further in your career or in further education.

Qualification: The first CPD accredited Hoarding Awareness training in England.

CPD Accredited - guaranteeing updated content throughout the training year.

Experience

Heather Matuozzo and Sharon McLoughlin bring over 40 years of experience in the fields of hoarding behaviour and local authority/housing implementation. They live their work so their examples are always fresh.

Our training courses cover a variety of topics:
The present situation of hoarding in the UK
How to understand the condition Hoarding Disorder
How to assess a situation
How to work with clients and develop a working plan for them
How to monitor and measure progress
We can tailor our courses to suit the specific needs of your organisation.

Courses are being delivered virtually and upcoming courses can be found on our website

services.name: Clouds End CIC
services.description:
Support for people with hoarding issues at Clouds End CIC

One-to-One Support

This involves working with people with Birmingham post codes in their homes with a gentle, non-judgemental approach. The client is always in control and the plan developed will always be determined by the needs and abilities of the client themselves, this way a successful outcome is achievable and the possibility of future sustainability is stronger.

Our aim is to gain trust with our clients to help them develop the skills and confidence needed to regain control over the possessions that have overwhelmed them. We like to work with support workers or carers that may be involved with the individual’s progression.

We work with private individuals, social landlords, housing associations and any service who may work with people with hoarding disorder.

We also have support groups, online and physical (https://www.cloudsend.org.uk/hoarding-support-services/support-groups/) where we meet twice monthly. We offer support and understanding to anyone affected by hoarding, discussion of useful tactics for reducing belongings. There will be tea and biscuits!

services.name: Clouds End CIC
services.description:
Chaos 2 Order helping agencies in the city better understand hoarding behaviour in their citizens.

Since 2019 Clouds End CIC has been working with Birmingham City Council’s Preventions and Communities department to help agencies in the city better understand hoarding behaviour in their citizens.

Hoarding affects 2-5% of the population. Understanding why people hoard helps us to work in a supportive and compassionate way. This produces better results and engagement - which ultimately saves time, money and pain.

The aim of this project is to better educate and upskill the agencies who encounter hoarding behaviour and help them integrate that understanding into their everyday procedures.

Heather Matuozzo of Clouds End offers mixed-agency training sessions online.

Dates can be found on the website
Please contact Maz.Williams@birmingham.gov.uk to book a place.

Heather will also upskill through mixed-agency huddles on Zoom for 2022, again, dates are listed on the website.
Please contact Heather at help@cloudsend.org.uk for places on these huddles.

Adult Social Care is also working with Heather to provide mentoring for student social workers who have expressed an interest in specialising in hoarding behaviour during their work placements. Places are limited but contact adulthoarding@birmignham.gov.uk for availability.

There is also a limited amount of funding to help with extras services such as clearing, cleaning and one-to-one work but this can only be applied for after agencies have used their usual funds to address these issues. This will be checked on the referral form. There is a waiting list for extra services and citizens have to consent to be part of the project to access them. They must also agree to a visit including an interview about how the intervention helped them.

Contact Heather at help@cloudsend.org.uk for a referral form.

The aim of Chaos 2 Order project is to make Birmingham the first Hoarding Aware City in the world. We do hope that everyone will join in with the spirit of this through the Hoarding Charter. Ask about this on the help@cloudsend.org.uk email also.

services.name: Renewal Church
services.description:
Baby Basics Renewal

Partnered with Baby Basics UK, Baby Basics Renewal is a volunteer-led project aiming to support new mothers and families who are struggling to meet the financial and practical burden of looking after a new baby. 

Baby Basics provides much needed essentials and equipment to mothers and families who are unable to provide these items for themselves; including but not limited to teenage mums, people seeking asylum and women fleeing domestic abuse and trafficking.

Working with midwives, health visitors and other professional groups to provide support directly where it is most needed, Baby Basics volunteers lovingly collect, sort and package a ‘Moses Basket’ of clothing, toiletries and essential baby equipment as an attractive gift to new mothers.

Baby Basics is a Christian led initiative providing support to those in need regardless of faith or belief. 

If you work with vulnerable women or families who are struggling to provide for their newborn baby please get in touch with 
Naomi Hodges 
babybasics@renewal.church.
0121 711 7300

services.name: Renewal Church
services.description:
Toy Offering @ Renewal CC

What is Toy Offering? 
Every Christmas Renewal delivers Toy Offering as a way of supporting those at Christmas time who would otherwise have nothing to open on Christmas morning. We partner with organisations, charities and individuals who donate brand new toys, games, crafts and this year, the addition of a pyjama set for each child.

Social Services, Women’s Aid, local schools and other agencies as well as our own staff team refer families in need to the Toy Offering Appeal. When a referral is made, the name, age and gender of each child is recorded to ensure they get age appropriate toys.

Do you know someone who needs help this Christmas? 
We don’t want anyone to struggle this Christmas. If you know someone who may be facing financial hardship or would otherwise go without this Christmas do not hesitate to get in touch. The referral needs to come through an agency or a member of the Renewal church family. The referrer will be contacted with the details of collection and distribution arrangements.

How can you refer a family this Christmas? 
Contact hello@renewal.church and they will be able to put you in touch with the project lead who will share the referral form with you.

services.name: Renewal Church
services.description:
Helping Hands emergency food parcels @ Renewal

Renewal supports individuals and families in the local community who are experiencing food poverty through the provision of emergency food parcels 

Food parcel delivery times are between 
12.00pm-4.00pm 
Monday - Friday, (excluding Bank Holidays).

How to access
Helping Hands work on a referral basis only, if you or someone you know need to access this service, please call Solihull Council on 0121 704 8001 to request a referral.

services.name: Rape and Sexual Violence Project [ RSVP ]
services.description:
RSVP provides specialist services to support people of any or no gender, and of any age who have been raped or sexually assaulted.

Children and Young People's Service
We have a dedicated website The Survivor Hub
We offer help called advocacy to under 18s
Our trained staff are called ISVAs and as well as supporting you, they can also help the family and friends who are supporting you.
Our ISVAs make sure your voice is heard; they will help you understand what people are saying to you and help you say what you want to say. They will make sure your needs are met and that you are listened to.

Adult Advocacy
Our Independent Sexual Violence Advocates (ISVAs) offer practical and emotional support, ensuring that your views, opinions, wishes and feelings are respected, and listened to by all agencies and people involved.

LGBTQ+ Advocacy
If you are lesbian, gay, bi, trans (Including but not exclusive list- non binary, non cis, gender queer, MSM, androgynous, intersex, pansexual…) and have ever experienced rape, sexual assault or sexual abuse at any point in your life, our specialist LGBT ISVAs (Independent Sexual Violence Advocates) delivered from RSVP and within Birmingham LGBT too are here to help.

Male Survivors
Support for men and boys subjected to sexual violence and abuse
We offer a range of services for male survivors to support you in making the decisions and choices that are right for you.
Practical support whether you have chosen to report to the police or not. Our Independent Sexual Violence Advocates (ISVAs) can support you through the criminal justice process, talk to you about other ways of seeking justice, or help you gain support from other organisations
We can offer you face to face or telephone counselling; both provide a safe place to talk and explore your feelings. We have appointments available at different times, at various locations around Birmingham and Solihull, with counsellors of different sexes for you to choose from.

Asylum Seeker and Refugee Survivors
We offer services to support asylum seekers and refugees who have experienced sexual violence, rape or sexual torture in any country.
We offer specialist counselling support, and work with interpreters so you can be supported in your own language.
A support worker can also assist you with practical issues, including destitution, housing, childcare and guidance on legal support available to you.

services.name: OASIS Mental Health Support
services.description:
Oasis Mental Health Support can provide advice on managing your finances, budgeting, debt, benefits etc. 

We are registered with the Financial Conduct Authority (recognition number 754680) to provide advice on debt. This means that we can advise you on managing repayments, including negotiating with companies you owe money to, or challenging companies who may have not taken into account your mental health issues when selling you products or services

For more information about the practical help with can offer around money management and getting support you need, please visit our website

services.name: OASIS Mental Health Support
services.description:
Oasis Mental Health Support can provide advice on managing your finances, budgeting, debt, benefits etc. 

We are registered with the Financial Conduct Authority (recognition number 754680) to provide advice on debt.
